summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend's feud began when Merson criticized Townsend's England call-up, stating it would open selection to "anybody." After Townsend scored an equalizer for England against Italy, Merson admitted his mistake, praised the goal, and explained his original view stemmed from Townsend's early substitution at Manchester United. Townsend responded on Twitter, and despite temporary resolution, Merson reignited the dispute by commenting on Townsend's seven-minute substitute appearance in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, confirmed by club president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer proceeds, Muto would join Vitesse Arnhem on loan before moving to Chelsea. Ogane stated the offer is unrelated to Chelsea's £200m sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and 11 Japan caps. He acknowledged the offer as an honor but has not decided, and would be Chelsea's first Japanese player if he joins. A £4m deal is under consideration.

A large-scale study links antibiotic use in infants to higher toddler obesity rates, contributing to England's obesity epidemic where a third of 10-11 and over a fifth of 4-5 year olds are overweight or obese. Repeated antibiotic exposure before age two increased risk, especially in boys, possibly via gut bacteria changes. Researchers warn of antibiotic overuse exacerbating obesity and resistance, including superbug risks.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell. He lost balance, knocked his bearskin, dropped his rifle, and quickly scrambled up embarrassed. The slip was due to metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment. The Changing of the Guard occurs daily in summer, every other day in winter, and the guards are fully operational soldiers.

A&E, Lifetime, and History are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally drew over 100 million viewers, for a 2016 simulcast. Co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, the new version draws from Alex Haley's novel and consults historians for authenticity. It addresses contemporary issues like Obama's presidency, "12 Years a Slave's" Oscar win, and racial unrest, aiming to introduce the story to new generations unfamiliar with its significance.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that Clarence House aides attempted to force him into an orgy in 1978. He reported being pinned, groped, and threatened during his first day, leaving immediately. His initial complaint was ignored for months before being escalated to Scotland Yard after inquiries into historical child abuse. A retired aide denied involvement, and the Palace stated it would cooperate with police, who declined to comment on the ongoing investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a 'Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' theme rap video that surpassed 1.7 million YouTube views. The video features lyrics about their conception journey, a positive pregnancy test, and a sonogram reveal. Created to share the news with distant family, its viral success was unexpected. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and a Phoenixville couple previously used the same theme for a pregnancy announcement.

A Vivien Leigh dress worn as Scarlett O'Hara in *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. The jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring black zigzag applique, had faded from slate blue-gray to light gray. Part of James Tumblin’s collection, he acquired it for $20 in the 1960s after finding it discarded. Other top auction items included a $52,500 straw hat, $55,000 Clark Gable suit, and $30,000 bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland. The 1939 film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s book, celebrated its 75th anniversary, with Hattie McDaniel becoming the first African-American Oscar winner.

A two-year-old boy fell 10-12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing. Rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived, he sustained minor injuries and was in stable condition. Zoo officials confirmed cheetahs did not attack him. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the mother, and the exhibit was closed.

A speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham, was repositioned to face a house but has been inactive since 2013 when all fixed cameras in the West Midlands were decommissioned due to obsolete technology. Birmingham City Council is aware and will assess the site, possibly removing it, though it will not be included in a new digital pilot. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA). Bolt stated he is fit, healthy, ready to run, and expressed happiness at being part of the team. He noted the event's good atmosphere last year, Jamaica's relay tradition, and his commitment to making the country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle confirmed Bolt's availability, referred to him as the world's fastest man, and expected sprint magic. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended Barcelona's Euro League basketball El Clasico against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80, though Real Madrid remain top of their division by points difference. Neymar led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile at the Emirates, with Gary Medel stamping on him during the match. Barcelona had previously won their La Liga El Clasico before the international break to move four points clear, and now face Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble. Neymar's sister Rafaella was present at the basketball game.

Italy is coping with a rising wave of migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 rescued from Friday to Monday and 20 SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children reported 400 missing from a capsized ship carrying 550, but the Italian coast guard has not confirmed the incident. According to the IOM, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued in early April. At least 480 deaths occurred this year due to dangerous conditions and overcrowded vessels, with most migrants originating from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria via Libya. Last week, 978 migrants were rescued in a single day.

Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool after being courted by elite clubs, scoring 19 goals this season. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger does not know his exact reason but is glad he joined, acknowledging Liverpool's interest may have been used in Luis Suarez's transfer negotiations. Wenger praised Sanchez's qualities, dismissed Raheem Sterling transfer rumors, and commended Brendan Rodgers for Liverpool's performance post-Suarez and Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Lee Valley VeloPark, aiming to surpass the current 52.491km record set by Australia's Rohan Dennis in February under revised UCI regulations. Recent attempts include Jens Voigt (51.115km), Matthias Brandle (51.852km), Jack Bobridge (failed), and Alex Dowsett's May 2 attempt. Tickets go on sale April 19, with live coverage on Sky Sports. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who recently finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, also targets an eighth Olympic medal at Rio 2016.

Serena Williams described her Fed Cup singles victory over Sara Errani as an 'eye-opener', admitting she is unprepared for clay court season. The US team lost 3-2 overall, leading to relegation to World Group II after a doubles defeat by Errani and Flavia Pennetta. Despite two French Open titles, Williams considers it her least successful major. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stated the team must work harder to return to the World Group next year.

River Plate aims to sign Radamel Falcao despite complications, with vice president Matias Patanian stating they "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open." Falcao previously spent eight years at the club, leaving for Porto in 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances over four seasons. Currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, he scored only four Premier League goals this term, with his future uncertain. He recently scored three times in two games for Colombia to tie their all-time record of 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, a 2012 X Factor finalist, is the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, her first brand collaboration. The campaign features her in multiple hairstyles against a blurred city background, including wavy hair with a black blouse and leather jacket, a half-ponytail with a maxi dress, and a black lacy dress. Partnered through MILES agency, the TV ad includes her single "Mirror Man." Henderson uses Batiste regularly, and her manager highlighted the natural synergy between her and the brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosham, Wisconsin, are shocked by a billboard featuring Torres erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. The billboard, stating "Thank you for your support, Kenosha," has been called disrespectful by Siler's family, with a friend saying it felt like thanking people for killing him. The police association claims no offense was intended and the billboard was to thank the community for support. Siler was wanted on a felony warrant and shot during a pursuit. Torres also shot 66-year-old Terry Knight 10 days prior, which was ruled justified. Siler's investigation remains ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with three militants killed by Iranian forces. The attack, claimed by the Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal, involved militants crossing from Pakistan's Balochistan province. The group, which targets Shiites to counter Iranian influence, previously killed 14 Iranian border guards in a 2013 attack. Iran accused Pakistan of failing to rein in terrorists, while Pakistan condemned the attack and stated it would apprehend any militants who entered its territory.

Japan's political discussion on the real-life counterparts of the video game "Space Invaders" featured Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirming the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. Responding to former wrestler Antonio Inoki's query, Nakatani stated sightings were limited to birds or non-aircraft objects. Inoki, known for his wrestling career and political activities, claimed personal UFO sightings but uncertainty about aliens' existence. The discussion followed a 2007 comment by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba on legal implications of extraterrestrial defense under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep leg and buttock cuts after breaking a toilet by standing on its rim at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport due to cleanliness concerns. He initially told friends he was squatting but later claimed to police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities confirmed it was an accident and reminded people to sit, not stand, on toilets.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, traced to him. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The girl reported Rebbie watched her undress and sleep for years, molesting her from age nine to thirteen. Investigators found 41 videos, 34 showing showering victims with close-up images of genitalia, uploaded by Rebbie. He admitted to filming multiple juveniles, specifically purchasing the camera to record the victim. The relationship with the family is unknown. Police Chief William Albany described the case as "particularly horrific," and his preliminary hearing is May 1 with $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's 'Daughter and Salary Man' series features po-faced teenagers next to leaping fathers in suits at Japanese landmarks, with daughters smiling in each image. The images showcase fathers expressing a fun side as 'heroes jumping the sky,' some with pained expressions, gaining online attention despite limited details.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director shifted focus to the county championship, but Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team dominates discussions. Downton's sacking has cleared the way for Pietersen, axed controversially in 2014, to rejoin the international setup after last playing in the 2013-14 Ashes whitewash. Rejoining Surrey to force his way back into the Test squad, Pietersen was seen in reflective yet jovial moods during Surrey's team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of their April 19 campaign start, joking with photographers and teammates.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian relegation-threatened club, sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially dismissed on Wednesday due to poor results, he was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. After a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, he was fired again, leaving the team 16th, six points from safety. The 41-year-old former Brazil international (25 caps) and ex-Inter Milan and Parma player had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach this season and will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, former Monaco teammate of Radamel Falcao, states Falcao regrets his Manchester United loan move despite unhappiness at Monaco. Falcao has scored only four goals this season and struggled to recover from a knee injury, making it unlikely for United to exercise the £46m permanent transfer option. Dirar believes he would have played in the Champions League had he stayed at Monaco.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt, described as very tall. The incident occurred at Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30pm on Saturday, with the suspect stealing approximately $1,500. No weapons were used, and the offender remains at large. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice. First arrested March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing and allowing breast touching in April of the previous year. She was later arrested again for a separate incident where another 15-year-old accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. Both arrests resulted in bail releases, and she was suspended with administrative leave. The school district confirmed taking action but cited privacy laws restricting further details.

A video showing a crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, carrying a dead dog (owned by a local bike shop owner) for hours has been viewed over 500,000 times. Witness Tim Weston described the crocodile near a sanctuary 200m upriver, where the dog likely approached out of curiosity. American Crocodiles, reaching 6 meters, are common in the mangrove-rich area due to urbanization, leading to frequent human encounters. Social media users reacted with horror, though the species is native to the region.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City will avoid relegation despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, leaving them two points above the drop zone with six remaining fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. He attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Diame, Chester, Dawson, Jelavic, and Snodgrass, stating eight or nine wins may suffice instead of the initial 10-target. Southampton's Ronald Koeman addressed Sadio Mane's attempt to take a penalty over James Ward-Prowse, vowing to reinforce team rules.

Ian Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years after altering pupils' SATs answers post-exam and allowing changes at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, resulting in the annulment of all 2014 results. He admitted the conduct but claimed he only made answers legible. The panel found his actions dishonest but not fraudulent, though deliberate, and he showed remorse. He has 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper for Manchester United, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is third-choice due to David de Gea and Victor Valdes. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri (with Albanian roots) in a Mauritius beach wedding last year; they have a son and have been dating since 2012. Beqiri, with over 17,000 Instagram followers, posts modeling photos, and Lindegaard shared a post about their time together.

The Yankee Stadium blue letters failed to sell at Sotheby's auction despite a $300,000-$600,000 estimate, with only a Sotheby's employee bidding $260,000 to jumpstart bidding. Owned by Reggie Jackson since 2008, the 1976-installed letters were removed after the stadium's final game; Jackson aimed for a new generation to own the iconic signage. A Mets bullpen car sold for $112,500, exceeding its $20,000-$30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe over incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes, stressing professional responsibilities without disciplinary action. He emphasized the importance of conduct for elite athletes and aims to move on from the matter. Rodgers confirmed Steven Gerrard's availability for the FA Cup semi-final but did not confirm his inclusion, focusing solely on reaching the final. He referenced past near-misses in the title race and Capital One Cup, stating losses are part of the journey toward success.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after international duty, sharing a photo with his dog captioned 'Home Sweet Home'. Germany defeated Georgia 2-0 in their Euro 2016 qualifier. The £42.5m Real Madrid signing missed Arsenal's Newcastle game due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool, with manager Arsene Wenger dismissing nightclub rumors. Since January, he has recorded four assists and three goals, stating he has adjusted well to English football's demanding schedule.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu confirmed the club has no plans to replace Luis Enrique, stating they are "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year contract until 2016, remains focused on La Liga and the team. Despite speculation, Bartomeu emphasized Barcelona's potential to win three trophies, as demonstrated by their recent 2-0 victory over Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has signed a new Liverpool contract worth £100,000 per week until 2020, making him the third key player to extend after Sturridge and Coutinho. He contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season and is expected to become captain following Steven Gerrard's departure. Raheem Sterling has rejected a new deal, with talks set to resume in summer.

Filipe Luis insists he wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has struggled to secure the left-back position at Stamford Bridge. After representing Brazil in recent friendlies against France and Chile, he now focuses on Chelsea's Premier League title run-in, with manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing the need for focus in nine remaining challenging matches.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally colliding with George North's head while scoring a try was overturned on appeal, with the red card rescinded. The appeal panel ruled no foul play occurred, stating the incident was accidental, following criticism from figures like James Haskell and Austin Healey. North suffered his third concussion in two months and must rest for a month. Hughes missed the Champions Cup game against Toulon but is now eligible to play, though he will not feature in the upcoming match against London Welsh and is unlikely to return until April 26.

Fiery sunsets in Washington and the Pacific Northwest were caused by smoke from Siberian wildfires. Farmers' grass burning in southeastern Siberia ignited the fires, which spread rapidly due to strong winds on April 14, destroying dozens of villages. Though extinguished, lingering smoke was carried across the Pacific by atmospheric winds. Smoke particles filtered out shorter light wavelengths (greens, blues, etc.), allowing red and orange hues to dominate during sunrises and sunsets, intensified by the longer atmospheric path. As smoke dissipates, the reddish hue fades and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway a month after purchase. Police recovered it on April 1 after a tip, returning it with red spray-painted rims, side detailing, and orange steering wheel accents. She thanked the thieves on Facebook, calling the modifications "pimped out," though the car required cleaning due to cigarette and marijuana smells. She created a smoothie named "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, who reported the car. A friend described her as vibrant and happy.

Manchester City players face £500,000 bonus losses per player if they fail to qualify for the Champions League, with £12 million total at stake. Currently fourth in the Premier League, they are four points ahead of Liverpool after a derby defeat. The top three secure automatic qualification, while fourth place requires a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the season has "disintegrated" with seven losses and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a mini-derby at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning free-kick. The free-entry match drew nearly 1,000 fans, featured 13 English players (10 Mancunian), and used a first-team formation. Rashford missed chances, while City's injury issues contributed to their loss in both play-off series matches. United trail leaders Middlesbrough by two points with a game in hand, showcasing talents deserving senior opportunities.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart also reached his 50th cap in the same match, stating he is inspired by Buffon's career at 37 and aims to continue accumulating more international appearances.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with Postmates to offer delivery in 67 cities, charging a 9% service fee and delivery fees starting at $5. The chain previously declined third-party delivery offers but has now partnered with Postmates, which uses independent contractors. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also expanding into delivery services, while presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have been spotted at Chipotle locations.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, urge the Justice Department to remove the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. They advocate for life imprisonment without parole and waiving appeals to avoid prolonged legal proceedings that would retraumatize their family, particularly their remaining children. They state they are speaking only for themselves and seek to move forward for their family, Boston, and the country.

A mystery billionaire's £400 million custom Boeing 747-8 conversion includes bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room with kitchen, a state room, an aeroloft with eight beds, a conference room, and hotel-style interiors, accommodating the owner and dozens of guests despite its original 600-passenger capacity.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. An attempt to land the rocket stage on a droneship failed, with the rocket tipping over after landing. Elon Musk aims to reuse rockets to reduce space access costs. Dragon delivered over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including ISSpresso, and will return with 3,000 pounds of cargo before splashing down in the Pacific. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and the second attempt after a weather-related scrub on Monday.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel at Las Vegas' Westgate Hotel (formerly Las Vegas Hilton) on April 23. She collaborated with NBC's Today show for a contest where a winning couple receives a free wedding reception, two-night hotel stay, airfare, and Elvis Experience concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized it's "first-class" with no impersonators and helped design the chapel as part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples must submit videos/photos and explanations to enter.

Jordan Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City in the Premier League despite being four points behind, after a 2-0 win over Newcastle with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen. Henderson and Simon Mignolet each played their 47th game this season, matching a top European league record. Henderson acknowledged recent poor results but emphasized the need to keep winning, with City having lost 4-2 to Manchester United.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak with a victory over Napoli in a key Champions League places match. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak reached five matches. Tight security measures were implemented due to past incidents but no problems occurred. Roma played without Totti and Gervinho, and Insigne returned from injury.

Doncaster Rovers drew 0-0 with Fleetwood Town in League One, prompting their media team to create a 27-second YouTube highlights video featuring only 14 seconds of match action (kickoff, goal kick, final whistle), described as a must-see for football fans at the Keepmoat Stadium.

Roland Giroux's blood parrot cichlid responds to stroking by relaxing, returning for more, and following his hand when removed. After removing two bullying tank mates, hand-feeding frozen blood worms increased sociability, with the fish now requiring daily 15-minute interactions. The hybrid was first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

Ben Stokes' fiery temperament, demonstrated through incidents like breaking his wrist punching a locker, clashing with Marlon Samuels, and confronting Mitchell Johnson during the Ashes, is managed by Peter Moores to balance aggression with control. England seeks to maintain his natural exuberance while focusing on delivering runs and wickets, avoiding pigeonholing. Despite a slight back niggle, he has recovered, and the team prioritizes his inclusion with Chris Jordan to develop their potential, even when considering alternatives like Adil Rashid.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at Cardiff City Stadium on June 12 is a 33,000 sell-out. Both teams lead Group B, with Wales moving to the top after a 3-0 win over Israel, their best position since the 1958 World Cup. The Football Association of Wales cited overwhelming ticket demand. UEFA rules prevented moving the match to the Millennium Stadium, and the squad prefers Cardiff City's smaller venue.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they are defending champions after defeating Holland on penalties last year. They qualified with a 100% record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their opening match is against Italy on May 7 in Burgas, followed by games against Holland (May 10) and Ireland (May 13). The squad includes Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (both first-time call-ups), and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (recalled after missing qualifiers).

Manchester City are keen to sign 14-year-old Belgian playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis from Anderlecht, a top talent also attracting attention from Arsenal and Barcelona. He rejected Barcelona's La Masia at 12 to continue studies. City have held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock for a compensation package as Manuel Pellegrini is looked to build for the future by snapping up hot property Evangelos Patoulidis.

A 23-year-old man was arrested for the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Romily Court, Fulham on March 28. She was pronounced dead at the scene with head and neck injuries. The suspect has been bailed and must return for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her before her death, particularly those who saw her on Friday or Saturday. Her website stated she worked in London, Paris, and Miami, described herself as visiting from Miami seeking upscale gentlemen, and expressed love for London and Paris. Authorities did not confirm if her profession was central to the investigation but vowed to do everything to solve the case.

Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages and buried one child (Daniel James), accused family friend Jamie (a convicted burglar living with her and her partner, also named Jamie) of stealing £207 intended for Daniel's £500 gravestone. A lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show confirmed Jamie's guilt, and he confessed to stealing but blamed Carol. Dawn expressed feeling betrayed and devastated.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, with counts reported as 217 and 228. Arab tribal leaders coordinated the release, though the motivation was unclear. The freed were sent to Irbil. Following ISIS' attack on Sinjar last summer, a humanitarian crisis occurred with massacres, enslavement, and displacement. An international coalition responded with airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes. The U.S. estimates 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, accounting for less than 1% of the population.

Harry Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A Copa90 animation featuring his key goals against Chelsea, Arsenal, and his England debut, along with celebrations, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of Sunday's awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool manager despite a trophy-less season and probable failure to qualify for the Champions League. He argues Rodgers' future shouldn't be judged on one game, citing players not yet settled and the need for correct signings to improve the squad. Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his community work through the 23 Foundation, which coaches in deprived Merseyside schools, emphasizing his commitment to helping underprivileged areas like his hometown Bootle.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport for resembling a prohibited item under security regulations. His parents criticized the action as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous" but complied to avoid missing their flight. The airport apologized, citing government rules requiring the seizure of items that mimic replica guns, and offered to mail the toy back, though the family later bought a replacement after returning from holiday.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife. He requires a non-drinking, non-smoking partner who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, skilled in housework and cooking, and good in bed, with a love for the outdoors but ability to be a "princess when needed." He describes himself as athletic, tattooed, with brown hair and eyes, no drugs, doesn’t drink or smoke, enjoys travel, outdoor activities, sports, fishing, and camping. He is 175cm tall, well-endowed, owns property, earns well, loves cars and bikes, and is independent. He offers accommodation, free gym membership, a phone of choice, and promises to spend on his partner, considering all reasonable offers while excluding former partners. Daily Mail Australia could not contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke, supported by five former England managers, proposes raising home-grown player quotas from eight to 12 and redefining 'home-grown' as trained in England before age 18. They warn opposition risks England falling behind global football nations and hindering World Cup success, citing only 36.8% of Premier League starters were England-eligible and a shrinking pool of top English talent despite emerging players like Kane, Barkley, and Sterling needing more opportunities.

The passage describes the TV show *Poldark* depicting Demelza Poldark's pregnancy progressing from announcement to birth in an unrealistically short timeframe, with no indication of time passing between episodes. Fans criticized the rushed timeline, with one noting, "If you are pregnant in Poldark times expect to have it in the next 10 minutes," a comment also made during a prior pregnancy storyline involving character Elizabeth.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus solely on their own matches and ignore relegation rivals despite being bottom of the Premier League and three points from safety after back-to-back wins, including Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner against West Brom. He stressed their survival depends on their own results, warned against over-optimism, and emphasized that external factors only matter if they perform in their own games.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set the record for the longest mammal migration at nearly 14,000 miles, surpassing a previous humpback whale's 10,190-mile trip. She traveled from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, visiting three eastern gray whale breeding areas. Bruce Mate of Oregon State University stated her journey suggests she may be an eastern gray whale despite being thought western, which could impact conservation estimates given only about 150 western gray whales exist. Fourth baby orca born this season.

Residents on Hokkaido's Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu observed a new landmass emerging overnight, rising 30-50ft above sea level and measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Geologists attribute this to a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the seabed upward. Locals reported no tremors or sounds during the event. Authorities confirmed it is unrelated to Nepal's recent earthquake and expect no further expansion, with marine organisms still present on the new land.

Gregory van der Wiel denied plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain, stating he loves the club, city, and teammates, and wants to sign a new contract despite a dispute with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea. However, PSG's link to Dani Alves leaves his future uncertain.

Carlos Tevez aims to terminate his Juventus contract (valid until 2016) to return to Boca Juniors. Boca confirmed nearing a deal but requires contract termination first. Juventus, though reluctant, accept his departure and seek replacements. Tevez, Serie A's top scorer with 17 goals, has reportedly decided to leave this summer. His manager states the move won't affect his Argentina future and Boca is not a step down from Juventus.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in the Champions League, advancing to the semi-finals after overturning a two-goal deficit from the first leg. Guardiola tore his trousers during the match, exposing his underwear, and joked about needing new ones, while also removing his blazer later. Goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski (brace).

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three-vehicle crash on Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man and five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries and chest pain, respectively. A 27-year-old woman and six-year-old girl were also flown out with arm injuries and abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or assessment. A man had hand lacerations, and two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed with diversions south of Fernvale; emergency crews used hydraulic tools to free a trapped person, and Rescue 500 helicopter airlifted patients. Police stated the closure would last a few hours.

Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining as they host the table-toppers this weekend. Mesut Ozil shared his new Apple Watch on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's device from Knight Rider. Jack Wilshere returned from a five-month injury, featuring on the bench in the FA Cup semi-final, with Ray Parlour stating his potential depends on staying fit, citing Abou Diaby's injury struggles.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby despite sending off three players from United and City this season (two United in the Premier League, Vincent Kompany internationally). Accused of favoring United, his Premier League red cards were both to United players. United have won five straight games and lead City by a point after the champion's 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, with the derby likely deciding second place behind expected winners Chelsea. Assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official, will support Clattenburg.

Bob Katter, a Lebanese-descended federal MP, accused the Queensland Government of viewing Billy Gordon as a 'little black puppet on a string' expected to resign after domestic violence allegations and concealing his criminal history. Gordon left the Labor Party but remains an independent, throwing the government's razor-thin majority into chaos. Katter questioned why resignation was expected here when federal cases didn't see similar resignations, citing Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents becoming puppets but vowing Gordon would not. His use of 'black puppet' drew criticism, which he defended by citing his dark complexion and Cloncurry background to address racial overtones.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old Illinois teen with cerebral palsy, creates dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others, aiming to change disability representation in media. She addresses bullying and misconceptions, emphasizing she drives, attends college, and lives similarly to peers despite doctors' early warnings. She also does motivational speaking at Chicago-area schools.

Orlando City (MLS) has expressed interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is struggling during his Real Madrid loan. The club, with a large Latin-American fanbase and Kaka as captain, sees him as a commercial asset. Eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested, with United seeking £8 million. Hernandez has one year left on his contract. Separately, United offered a revised contract to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who rejected their initial offer; PSG, Juventus, PSV, and Feyenoord have contacted his father, and he was on the bench against Aston Villa.

A gang of at least three people attempted to carjack a driver at a South Los Angeles 76 Station around 12:15am Saturday, then poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire with two passengers inside. No injuries occurred, but the car was destroyed. The LA County Fire Department is investigating the arson with suspects still at large, using surveillance video.

Charles Manuel, a southern Iowa chiropractor, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement to avoid reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the circumstances of revocation no longer exist. Despite this, he received perfect 5/5 patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. The passage states he recommended patients stop taking medication he prescribed, and his practice was located at a residential address in Lamoni.

The US has complained to Russia after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a US RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace over the Baltic Sea, with the Pentagon stating the Russian maneuvers were unsafe and unprofessional. Russia claimed the US plane's transponder was off, which the US denied. This follows a similar incident a year ago where a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a US plane in the Sea of Okhotsk, described as one of the most dangerous close passes in decades. US and Russian aircraft frequently encounter each other in Northern Europe and near the Russian Far East-Alaska region.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a secured hard case in his car's window at Salt Lake City's Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot overnight March 27, days before President Obama's Utah visit. Despite being properly secured with padlocks and chains, the thief broke the rear window, used a rope or cable, and pulled the case out. Gear bags, clothing, and tools were also stolen; some items were found across the street at a Residence Inn, but the rifle remains unrecovered. Police found skid marks and broken parts at the scene. The hotel has no surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified but declined to comment on security measures. Detectives are unsure if the theft was targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his neighbor Terrence Freebody in Red Hill, Canberra, in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. A jury heard Costa allegedly suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified Costa's mental state deteriorated leading up to and during the incident, citing triple 0 calls showing mood fluctuations and a trail of faeces indicating confusion. Mullen stated dementia combined with alcohol caused a confused state where Costa would not understand his actions or consequences. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa feigned memory issues, which Mullen denied. Costa's mental state is critical, as a proven unstable mindset could lead to a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley taking a penalty over Leighton Baines in their 1-0 win against Burnley, as Barkley's saved spot-kick didn't cost them after Mirallas scored the winner. Martinez stated Barkley was within his rights to take it, noting multiple players can step up, referencing a prior incident where Mirallas took a penalty from Baines in January.

Two passengers found dead on Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico appear to have died in a murder-suicide, according to the cruise line. The cabin was secured, and authorities including the FBI were notified. The ship departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan, where cleaning staff discovered the deceased after knocking on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, as coach of Curacao, led the team to advance to the second round of 2018 World Cup qualifying with a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat (2-1 home win, 2-2 away draw), with Charlton Vicento scoring the decisive goal in the 87th minute. They will face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a 1998 World Cup semi-finalist as a player and assistant coach for the Netherlands in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan star who won 15 trophies including the Champions League and multiple Serie A titles, states that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning a major trophy. Despite being seven points from safety with eight games remaining and a winless streak since January, he remains confident the team can avoid relegation. He expressed satisfaction with his family's situation in Leicester and hinted at the possibility of extending his one-year deal.

A 23-year-old mother of two children under five faces potential ban from seeing them after handing them to her mother Debbie at four months old. Debbie, who took custody following social services' threat to remove the children, cites Gemma's drinking, partying, use of legal high MKat, and stealing (including an iPad, which Gemma denies but admits past thefts). Debbie has raised the children, who call her "mum," and states Gemma is unfit and needs to grow up.

Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed John Terry fouled Radamel Falcao during the build-up to Eden Hazard's opening goal for Chelsea against Manchester United. Souness cited an elbow strike, Henry supported the foul call, and Redknapp stated it should have been punished despite Falcao possibly staying on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning after a rear tire blowout, with all occupants safely evacuated. Video footage showed flames and smoke. Scott confirmed via Instagram that only her Bible survived the fire in the back lounge, while band members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus. The group is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University proposes using satellites with mirrors to convert sunlight into laser energy beamed to Earth for home heating and disaster recovery, with trials moving from Scotland to Portugal. The lasers are too weak for sci-fi-style weapons. Separately, Tokyo researchers suggest ISS lasers to clear space debris by targeting sub-centimeter particles, also non-weaponizable. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about satellite control.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with a fanatical obsession with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, last seen on Tuesday at 6:15pm. Described as 5ft 8in tall, heavy build, dark hair, possibly shaved his beard, he was convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old on a bus (denied as accidental) and possessing indecent images of children (ten unrelated offences). Detained under the Mental Health Act with a hospital order, he has autism and learning difficulties. Police urgently seek information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay $2.63 million in gifts from Donald Sterling after his wife, Shelly Sterling, sued her, claiming he used their money to buy her luxury cars, a $1.8 million duplex, and items like a $391 Easter bunny costume and a $12 lace thong. Stiviano denied wrongdoing. Donald Sterling was banned from the NBA, fined $2.5 million, and forced to sell the Clippers following an audio recording where he made racist comments about Stiviano associating with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings, stating they need four top players—a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to win the Premier League. He said Olivier Giroud, despite scoring 14 goals, cannot lead them to the title, citing Chelsea's signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as a model. Arsenal are third in the league, level on points with Manchester City with a game in hand.

A young woman testified about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, who pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses including persistent sexual abuse of a child. She kept the abuse secret until his arrest, then attempted suicide. She expressed fear for future relationships, did not realize the abuse was wrong as a child, and worries about lasting effects on her relationships with men. She has suffered depression since age 14 with hospitalizations for self-harm and suicide attempts. The hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Germany Under-21 international and Arsenal midfielder, impressed last season before suffering a serious knee injury in March 2014. He has now returned to play 90 minutes for the Under 21s against Reading, stating he feels "better and better," is over injury concerns, and is looking forward to the next game.

Jacob Phillips, 23, a graduate accountant, died after falling 70ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing a taxi to avoid payment. He and friends ran off due to insufficient funds, leading to his accidental death. Found the next day by a dog walker at the disused Northern Promenade; coroner ruled accidental death, citing disorientation and lack of awareness of the danger.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delays received no compensation despite the Passport Office’s £42.3 million surplus and managers receiving bonuses up to £3,500. Only 2,191 claims were approved (total £203,066, average £92.68), with ministers refusing blanket refunds to avoid setting a precedent. Examples include a couple losing £1,500 on a Morocco trip, and only one of over a dozen contacted individuals received compensation.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged for over 80 years, is for sale with original features including a wood-panelled hallway with stained-glass windows depicting ships, living room windows with coats of arms, oil-fired central heating, mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and wallpaper, vintage kitchen cupboards, brick open-fire, dated sink, and original tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar, and Colman’s Mustard. Guide price £200,000-£250,000. Despite double glazing, renovation costs may deter developers. Auctioned April 30 at County Ground, Bristol, suitable for antique enthusiasts.

Colin Kaepernick began his career as Alex Smith's backup with the 49ers, became the starter mid-2012 after Smith's concussion, led the team to their first Super Bowl since 1994, and lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent her early life there before moving to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, formed Blur after meeting Graham Coxon at Stanway School. Blur's debut album Leisure (1991) received mixed reviews. Influenced by alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop, the band released a self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn's solo debut album Everyday Robots (2014), co-produced by Richard Russell, featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, known locally as Hamar, and hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 debut EP Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter.

The 2007 film 'Shooter' stars Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The TV series features Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, Leno La Bianca, and Rosemary La Bianca—with the murders carried out by his followers at his instruction, notably Sharon Tate. He also received first-degree murder convictions for Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Commercial recordings of his songs were released after he was charged.

Sean Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began with a TV role in *Little House on the Prairie* (1974) and film debut in *Taps* (1981). His 1980s roles included *Fast Times at Ridgemont High* and crime dramas like *At Close Range*, *State of Grace*, and *Carlito's Way*. He earned his first Oscar nomination and Berlin Best Actor award for *Dead Man Walking* (1995), followed by Oscar nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001), then won Best Actor Oscars for *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman AC (1908–2001), an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time, retained a pre-eminent position in the sport for three decades after retirement as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer of Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, with 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was a Democratic politician and Texas's second female governor (1991–1995), known for her 1988 DNC keynote address, defeat by George W. Bush, and outspoken feminism. Ann Richards (1935–1982) was an American jazz singer and Stan Kenton's wife.
Drake Bell independently released his EP 'A Reminder' in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927 – October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar (1783–1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where a number of aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began as Alex Smith's backup but became the 49ers' starter mid-2012 after Smith's concussion. He led them to their first Super Bowl since 1994, losing to the Ravens, and in 2013, his first full season as starter, reached the NFC Championship, losing to the Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an openly sponsored, nonpersonal audio or visual marketing communication used to promote products, services, or ideas. It differs from personal selling by not targeting specific individuals and is delivered through mass media including traditional channels (newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor advertising, direct mail) and new media (search results, blogs, websites, text messages).
Private Lives is a 1930 three-act comedy of manners by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (1894–1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, on the northern periphery of Classical Greece. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at age 17 or 18 and remained until 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato's death, he tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC at Philip II of Macedon's request.

David Mordechai Packouz (born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur who invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is CEO of Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. Drafted first overall in 1979, he won a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season and added four more titles in the 1980s. After protests from fellow players, he retired again for four years but returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games before retiring for the third and final time. Named one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony in 2009, he has business interests and was a Lakers part-owner.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, composed of Jack Black (lead vocalist and guitarist) and Kyle Gass (lead guitarist and vocalist). They released three albums: *Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006), and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012), gaining popularity in 1997 through their eponymous television series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I (1566–1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death. The kingdoms were separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, united under his personal rule. He advocated for a single parliament, achieved most of his aims in Scotland but faced great difficulties in England, including the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, the eighteenth series of the British reality television series, is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born 4 October 1967, has narrated the UK version of the Dutch reality show Big Brother since 2000, worked for Channel 4 until July 2011, then continued narrating the revived series on Channel 5, with his Geordie accent making him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a German federal state bordering Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships), and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec, Ústí nad Labem Regions). It is the tenth largest state by area (18,413 km²) and sixth most populous (4 million people). Its history spans over a millennium in a formerly German-speaking region. Saxony is a quality wine region and, along with Saale-Unstrut, is one of Europe's northernmost wine regions and the only two German wine regions in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End" is a song by Linkin Park.
Mel B . Brown began her solo career by releasing `` I Want You Back '' with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with supporting roles by Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally considered for the female lead, Divya Bharti completed many scenes before her death, replaced by Raveena Tandon. The film is noted for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure and singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor known for writing the 1987 action film hit Lethal Weapon and directing his debut film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film and the seventh and final one starring Roger Moore.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, comprising most of western New Guinea. It was formerly called Irian Jaya (previously West Irian or Irian Barat) and encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus probably died from natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggest his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in 1999 with "On the 6" and "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to top both album and film charts simultaneously with "J.Lo" and "The Wedding Planner." After her second divorce, her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album "This Is Me...Then" and overshadowed the failure of "Gigli" (2003). After marrying Marc Anthony, she rebounded with the box office success of "Shall We Dance?" She gave birth to twins in 2008, then returned to prominence in 2011 as an "American Idol" judge and with her best-selling single "On the Floor."

Working animals are typically domesticated and trained by humans for tasks such as assistance (e.g., guide dogs), tractive force (e.g., draft horses, logging elephants), milking, or herding. Rarely, wild animals may be trained for novelty or entertainment but lack the trustworthiness and mild temper of domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is Billboard magazine's most important chart for Spanish-language full-length albums in the US market. Regional Mexican Albums is a weekly genre-specific chart published by Billboard in the United States.

Vedam ( English : Chant ) is a 2010 Telugu language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi , starring Allu Arjun , Manoj Manchu , Anushka Shetty , Manoj Bajpayee , Saranya Ponvannan , Deeksha Seth , Lekha Washington , and Siya Gautham .

Men in Black II (stylized as MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra's 1605 novel Don Quixote, serving as Don Quixote's squire. His comments, known as 'sanchismos,' blend broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy ( in a dual role ) and directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler's world premiere took place on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich with Ibsen present.
Brazzers, pronounced [ˈbræzərz], is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A. (from Latin 'iuventūs', meaning 'youth'; colloquially Juve) is based in Turin. Founded in 1897 by Torinese students including Eugenio Canfari (first president) and his brother Enrico, author of the company's historical memory, it is Italy's second oldest active club after Genoa (1893), has worn black and white striped home kits since 1903, and plays at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in films and television series during the late 1990s and early 2000s, including *Kate & Leopold* (2001), *Far from Heaven* (2002), and *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson (born Jenna Marie Massoli; April 9, 1974) is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are an NBA team in the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event from 1983 to 2000, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later pay-per-view, organized by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). From the 1960s to the 1980s, Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) held major events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum. Specific instances include the third annual in 1985 (JCP/NWA), fifth in 1987 (JCP/NWA), and fifteenth in 1997 (PPV).

Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on ABC's legal drama *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's historical drama *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun, born June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted with Girls' Generation in August 2007, a best-selling and globally popular girl group. She has acted in musicals including *Moon Embracing the Sun*, *Gone with the Wind*, and *Mamma Mia*. Her debut solo mini album, *Do n't Say No*, was released on January 17, 2017, making her the third Girls' Generation member to pursue a solo career.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first highly successful mass-produced text command microcomputers, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak with Steve Jobs overseeing the case and Rod Holt developing the power supply. The Apple II series, trademarked as "Apple ] [" and later "Apple / /", was manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.) and introduced in 1977. Stephen Gary Wozniak, nicknamed "Woz", co-founded Apple Inc. and is an inventor, engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and entrepreneur.

A&E (formerly Arts & Entertainment Network) is an American cable and satellite television channel and the flagship of A&E Networks, a joint venture between Hearst Corporation and The Walt Disney Company, each holding a 50% ownership stake.

L.A. Reid has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group, founder and CEO of Hitco Music Publishing, and co-founder of LaFace Records.
Veeram (Valour) is a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

The passage describes two films titled "Home for the Holidays": a 1972 made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam ( born April 1 , 1982 ) is an American actor , comedian , and writer .
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster featuring eight men and eight women competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan (Ջոն Դոլմայան), born July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label that operates as a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim ( [ ˈsɪkᵻm ] ) is a northeastern state of India.
Christa McAuliffe took a teaching position as a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius `` Ron '' Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling 's Harry Potter series .
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, distributed by Columbia Pictures, and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback currently a free agent.
Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society (2016) and reprised Laura Palmer in Showtime's Twin Peaks (2017). Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Broadway's Wicked (2016).
Matteo Renzi, born 11 January 1975, is an Italian politician who served as Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love" by American singer Selena Gomez is from her 2015 second studio album Revival, which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. The album's first three singles—"Good for You," "Same Old Love," and "Hands to Myself"—all topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a genre of rock music that developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, largely in the United Kingdom and the United States. The new wave of British heavy metal began in the late 1970s with bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in romantic comedies including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman, part of the Arcadia Group (which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins), operates men's clothing stores on nearly every UK High Street and has outlets in six Irish cities and towns.

Tool has won three Grammy Awards, performed worldwide tours, and produced albums topping the charts in several countries.

Morse code transmits text via on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understood without special equipment. Character lengths vary inversely with English frequency for speed. Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, ranking as the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Its early 20th-century population was predominantly European immigrants, and a city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film *The Canyons*, directed by Paul Schrader, which was critically derided as an original work.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate, held in seven towns in Illinois.

Homer is the name ascribed by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and Odyssey, central works of ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is an mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974–February 2, 2013), a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was formed by Chris Cornell (ex-Soundgarden) and three former Rage Against the Machine members—Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991 with Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk, was co-founded by Wilk, Morello, and de la Rocha. Wilk began his career with Greta in 1990, played in Rage during 1991–2000 and 2007–2011, Audioslave from 2001–2007, and joined Prophets of Rage in 2016 with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. Her 2010 first full-length studio album, *The ArchAndroid*, a critically acclaimed concept album sequel to her first EP, was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter 's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin .

Lake Providence is a town and parish seat in East Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana. The University of Mississippi has 55% of undergraduates and 60% of all students from Mississippi, with 23% minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The series 'Flaked' was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), served as a U.S. senator from New York (1791–1797), and reached the apex of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch the Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, with 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, remains in service today, succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft, and was originally part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up when de la Rocha quit due to tensions; he started a solo career while the other members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, which released three albums before disbanding in 2007. The band reunited in 2007 for a Coachella performance, and their fourth album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX (BSE 30 or SENSEX) is a free-float market-weighted index of 30 companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the BSE and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, National Stock Exchange of India, and New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With 92.7 million inhabitants, it ranks 14th globally and 9th in Asia by population. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has maintained one of the world's highest economic growth rates, and in 2011, it topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. It remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh (d. 23 March 1931) was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's Dangal, a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film (Wrestling competition) directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (1566–1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 1603. The kingdoms remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments and laws under his personal union. He advocated for a single parliament but faced significant difficulties with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand actress known for roles in Shortland Street (original cast), Xena: Warrior Princess as Ephiny, The Cult as Cynthia Ross, Legend of the Seeker as Shota, Separation City (2009), Rake, Underbelly: Razor as Kate Leigh, and Wentworth as Bea Smith (starred four years until 2016).
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his work with Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser (2015) is an American comedy directed and written by Fred Wolf and David Spade.
Angela Evelyn Bassett ( born August 16 , 1958 ) is an American actress .

Artpop received generally mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States and selling 757,000 copies. It was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.
Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, and he departed the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented Thatcherism. A controversial figure, she has been lauded as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians, with arguments over Thatcherism persisting.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has written weekly columns on a wide variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series in addition to his acting roles.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community, an autonomous community of Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center, and the third largest metropolitan area with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It was announced on April 26, 2012, to end with its third season as the final season, with the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies for recognizing and translating spoken language into text, incorporating linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice dialing, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. Advances are evidenced by academic publications and industry adoption of deep learning, with companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC using deep learning in their systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The convention was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson tied South Africa's Van Zyl at 16 under par. McIlroy shot a third consecutive 67 to reach 15 under, tied with Kiradech Aphibarnrat. He three-putted holes 3 and 10 (throwing his putter after the 10th), birdied the 11th, and eagled holes 12 and 13.
