Recovering from a July ankle injury, he unsuccessfully defended his US PGA title and tied 26th in the Frys.com Open, now targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open. Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12) are fifth and seventh.

Sheikh Ali Salman stated that meaningful dialogue requires concrete government solutions and a royal representative, noting Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa's reformist stance versus hardliners opposing concessions. He acknowledged young protesters' distrust in opposition parties and the monarchy's violence, but stressed collaboration with royal reformists. He referenced a 2011 seven-point agreement with the crown prince halted by GCC troop intervention. He urged the US to pressure Bahrain more directly for human rights and democracy, and criticized the UK for relying on private diplomacy instead of public pressure. Al-Wefaq continues peaceful protests despite bans and demands the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists sentenced to prison terms of five years to life on torture-obtained evidence for plotting to overthrow the government, stating their inclusion is vital for dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, with a private funeral and future memorial. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 Handel's *Messiah* recording with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson was named a BBC Music Magazine top 20. He studied keyboard at Cambridge with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts, later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, and held roles including keyboardist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, co-founding the Early Music Consort of London, artistic director of King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge (honorary professor), and Cornell. Colleagues highlighted his generosity, foundational role in the early-music movement, and lasting impact on musicians worldwide.

In the year to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicides, the lowest since 1976 and half the figure from nine years prior, with one unresolved case. Sharp instruments caused 51% of cases (29), mostly knives. Thirty-one percent of accused were under alcohol/drugs. Justice Secretary Matheson acknowledged progress but stressed continued efforts. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker noted revisions to 2014-15 figures (from 59 to 62), sexual crime at a 45-year high, and a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, their first defeat by the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling's goal was their first in three games. Manager Eddie Howe stated they scored six against Hull before recent matches but struggled to convert chances, calling the lack of goals despite opportunities difficult to accept. Despite Sunderland being reduced to 10 men, Bournemouth failed to equalize. Howe added they had enough chances to win three games today and must move on.

Mr. Abbott stated that stopping boats is the only way to prevent sea deaths, citing Australia's policy of detaining migrants and offshore processing. The New York Times criticized the policy as brutal, inhumane, legally dubious, and contrary to Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees, warning Europe against adopting it. Abbott referenced Alan Kurdi's death but maintained stopping boats prevents drownings. His claim that IS is worse than Nazis for boasting about evil drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups, who noted the Holocaust's systematic genocide differs from IS terrorism. Abbott stood by his comments but said he was not ranking evil.

Washington suspended bilateral talks with Russia over alleged Russian and Syrian regime attacks on civilians in Aleppo, including hospital strikes and blocking humanitarian aid. Russia denied involvement in a September 19 aid convoy attack, blaming ground fire, and accused the US of failing to improve humanitarian conditions and separate jihadist groups from moderates. Over 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo, with hundreds killed since the ceasefire ended. Geneva coordination talks were canceled, US personnel were withdrawn from a joint implementation center, but counter-terrorism discussions will continue.

Policy Exchange report, supported by Downing Street, proposes selling high-value vacant social homes to raise £4.5bn annually for 80,000-170,000 new social homes. The report states 21.8% of UK social housing (816,000 properties) is high-value, potentially raising £159bn total. Selling 28,500 vacant properties yearly (after debt) could reduce the 1.8m waitlist by 500,000. Supporters argue it's fairer to house more families, with 73% public support. Labour and critics oppose, stating it displaces low-income families, creates segregated communities, and worsens the crisis; Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax for 250,000 homes. The government cites existing reforms and £19.5bn funding for 170,000 homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea during a measles outbreak with 942 cases. An inquest will be opened and adjourned to determine if measles caused his death, as initial tests were inconclusive. Since November, 83 people required hospitalization. He had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital, developed a rash after discharge, and saw a GP on 17 April with a full-body rash (excluding arms). Public Health Wales confirmed measles via lab tests but further tests are needed for the cause of death. His family stated they do not know how he contracted it, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, had measles.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, allegedly committed in 2001, and is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1, with Jake Lawlor scoring for Guiseley in the 15th minute and Wes York equalizing for Gateshead in the 62nd minute after Derek Asamoah's slip. Neil Aspin's Gateshead remain unbeaten in nine National League matches, while Adam Lockwood's Guiseley are unbeaten in five.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to the delayed Ashton Vale stadium project, which was hindered by a town green application. Approved by Bristol City Council in November, the plan requires signing a section 106 agreement soon, followed by a six-week judicial review period. If no review occurs by March, redevelopment will start in May.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor—the second in two months—to review British Geological Survey (BGS) data before resuming. The April 1 earthquake (2.3 magnitude) and recent tremor shared similar location and mechanism. Fracking involves hydraulic fracturing to release gas from shale rocks. Cuadrilla’s CEO stated operations are paused for consultation with authorities and experts, with analysis expected to take weeks. BGS confirmed injecting pressurized water can cause earthquakes, noting the April quake was 1.2 miles from the site and the latest had an epicenter within 2km of Preese Hall at 2km depth. Despite US environmental concerns, the UK Commons energy committee supports fracking under strict regulation.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker with over 30 years of experience, was found guilty of one fraud count for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015 while busking, implying he was collecting for the charity. He was cleared of two other counts. The charity's chairman confirmed he permitted the banner's display but not for fundraising, while Carpenter stated it was a tribute and not deceptive. Sentencing is scheduled for January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (after Alex Smithies' miscue), and Tom Lawrence. Despite failing to score in seven of their last 10 Championship games, Ipswich had multiple chances but only converted three. QPR's Sandro hit the post late. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th, while QPR dropped to 15th. McCarthy praised Varney, while Holloway criticized his defenders for the second goal and called for greater mental toughness.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and strike rate of 138.66 in last season's T20 Blast. He stated the club is progressing well with an elite coaching environment that motivates players to join.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for their second consecutive win. Coach Churcher highlighted Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams' leadership, noting the front row and front five made over 70 tackles. They face seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games. Churcher stated the performance wasn't complete but was dogged, emphasizing the need to build on it to avoid it being wasted.

Police allege 28-year-old Bangladeshi Nazrul (Nazu) raped a 74-year-old nun. Arrested at Kolkata railway station, marking the sixth arrest; eight suspects identified, two untraced. Five previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the perpetrator. Police acted on a tip that Nazrul, who fled to Bangladesh after CCTV identification, was returning by train. Milon Sarkar, arrested in May as gang leader, had an unclear role. The March 14 attack in Ranaghat involved theft, ransacking, and rape, sparking nationwide protests.

The interactive video may not work on older browsers, offering a non-interactive version instead. Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explains how domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports influenced UK consumer purchasing. The video's interactive elements cover changing brand ownership and rankings, best viewed in full screen, with links to related content on China's ownership, freezing tips, top UK brands survey, and the museum.

Two scams targeted women in Sandyhills (September 15) and Stranraer (seven days later) where callers impersonated BT technical support, claiming internet issues to gain remote computer access and steal money. Police warn against sharing banking details over calls, emphasizing legitimate companies never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. As Scotland assistant coach, he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised his work at Swinton under difficult circumstances, and he has been replaced by Stuart Littler. Duffy's 16-year playing career included stints at Leigh, Widnes, and Salford.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT Sunday. The rider had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, and was treated before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva allocated radio spectrum for satellite-based flight tracking to address the current ground-based system's 70% airspace coverage gap. The decision follows MH370's 2014 disappearance, enabling real-time global tracking via satellite reception of ADS-B transmissions. ICAO set a November 2016 deadline for guidelines requiring aircraft to transmit position data every 15 minutes or more during emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, is now 18 and living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland. Bobby, 53, was arrested and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with $250,000 bail. The FBI received a tip on October 30 about the teenager possibly being the long-missing child due to college application issues, leading to confirmation by Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. His mother was notified. Bobby is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Authorities suspected him at the time of the disappearance, as a missing persons report states he claimed to take Julian to preschool in August 2002 before fleeing.

A March 2 fire at Duncan Street disrupted train services. The Environment Agency revoked Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's environmental permit effective August 7, requiring waste removal. Despite the site being deemed broadly compliant with fire safety laws by GMFRS, concerns raised in February about potential impacts led to joint inspections and enforcement. The fire's cause remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills tied to Ukraine's crisis. The first allows Russian annexation of territories via referendum or leaders' request if a neighboring state disintegrates, citing Georgia's Abkhazia and South Ossetia post-2008 conflict. The second accelerates Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, eliminating tax, prior residence, financial proof, and citizenship renunciation requirements; applications before August 1 grant citizenship in two months, citing support for Russian-speakers against the "brown threat" (WWII fascists). Russian MPs and celebrities visited Crimea to advance the initiative.

McLaren, with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles (last in 1998), is currently struggling despite having two world champions like Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 due to chassis issues and now Honda engine problems. Historically dominant in the 1980s (15 wins in 1988) and late 1990s with Mercedes, they faced scandals in 2007 (disqualification and $100m fine for Ferrari data theft) and 2009 ("lie-gate"). Ron Dennis, who led past rebuilds, aims to restore success, with Alonso returning in 2015 to pursue a third title. Dennis claims McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance, though current progress remains uncertain.

Thomas Baker (Tommy), a 44-year-old from Everton, was found shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men (two aged 29, one 32) remain in police custody. Detectives state he was shot after leaving Phoenix Gym, with suspects having waited outside for about an hour. A silver VW Polo fled the scene along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. CCTV footage shows individuals who have not come forward but may hold key information.

The passage describes five online Christmas initiatives: virtual church services with global participation and Star Wars-themed sermons; a game teaching Bible stories to children; a viral Nativity video using social media posts; a religious ad rejected from cinemas for being "too religious"; and manga-style Bible stories distributed to refugees. It also notes churches using social media to share spiritual thoughts, with comments that Jesus would be active on Twitter.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to take 250 hectares of common land, with 320 hectares offered as replacement. Experts disagree on whether the development would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales stated replacement land's value is uncertain but does not oppose the project. Developers claim a net biodiversity gain through habitat enhancements, opposed by Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate will recommend, followed by Welsh government's final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, condemning Novaya Gazeta's report on detentions and killings of LGBTQ+ individuals as insulting, calling for retribution. The report, confirmed by the Russian LGBT Network, stated over 100 were detained on suspicion of homosexuality, with at least three killed, and detainees tortured with electric shocks and beatings. Kadyrov denied allegations, claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. The spiritual leader confirmed "retribution" against those "slandering" Chechens. Novaya Gazeta's editor denied insulting Chechens, vowing to continue investigations. Chechens are linked to past murders of journalists, including Anna Politkovskaya. The LGBT Network is aiding victims and may file an ICC case if Russia fails to prosecute.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, based in a south London storage unit, profit from housing benefits by placing multiple unrelated individuals in single properties and claiming benefits for each person, resulting in higher payouts than rent paid to landlords. For example, one property generated £2,114 monthly in benefits with £1,150 going to the landlord, yielding £11,568 annual profit. Both entities, linked through founder Samir Patel, focus on housing single homeless men over 35. Wandsworth Council paid over £2.1m to Investing Solutions in two years. Tenants reported unsuitable conditions, and homeless groups criticized the arrangement as "a new low," though the companies state compliance with regulations and Fresh Start’s independence.

Great Britain lost to the Netherlands in a warm-up game, with Andrew Lawrence scoring 14 points and Ben Gordon adding 13, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to take a 71-60 lead and secured the win despite GB's late comeback. Coach Joe Prunty stressed the need for consistent effort in the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers starting in Hungary, praising Gordon's performance despite his absence from the London 2012 team.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) before the deadline for his fight with Floyd Mayweather. The NAC is debating whether to allow 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz for 154lbs, as Mayweather requested 8oz gloves but had not yet submitted a waiver. NAC executive Bob Bennett emphasized health and safety as the priority. Despite criticism from boxing figures like Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin, Bennett approved the fight after reviewing McGregor's sparring with Nate Diaz (whom McGregor knocked down three times), his age, height, chin strength, and Mayweather's lack of knockouts in a decade. The NAC hired referee Joe Cortez, while Paulie Malignaggi left the camp after being knocked down in a sparring session.

Fleet Street, historically the heart of British journalism since the Daily Courant's 1702 founding, was a hub where most public information originated, with nearly all national papers clustered nearby. Journalists like Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith describe its heyday of typewriters, smoke-filled newsrooms, and heavy drinking culture, while Liz Hodgkinson details gender dynamics, such as the "Piranha Pool" for female reporters. Rupert Murdoch's 1986 move to Wapping triggered a union dispute, leading newspapers to relocate by 1988, adopting digital printing. Buildings were repurposed (e.g., Sainsbury's headquarters, Pizza Express), and the Sunday Post closing its London office marks the end of an era, with remaining journalists reflecting on its legacy.

J.K. Rowling stated that despite abusive comments, she sees more decent people than not and believes in standing up to bullies. She faced criticism for donating £1m to the Scottish independence No campaign and previously to Labour in 2008. After being called a traitor, she blocked some abusive users she believed were SNP supporters but engaged with supportive SNP members. She joked about bringing marshmallows if her books were burned. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats and is the UK's third-largest party.

Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be under statutory supervision than better-off peers for similar crimes. Poverty increased violence risk for all, with boys three times more likely than girls to commit violence, and poor girls twice as likely as affluent girls even after accounting for other factors. Despite Scotland's overall crime decline, high-crime areas remain concentrated in deprived communities with high health issues and unemployment. Researchers noted a destructive cycle where justice system contact exacerbates poverty-related violence, while the government cited record-low crime rates and a £296m investment to address poverty.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, early Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded until 14 August due to evidence of local tension. Two other arrested men were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Police alleged Walsh and two others entered the estate seeking Haugh, leading to a fight with weapons; Haugh suffered a fatal stab wound to the back and died in hospital. A bloody knife blade and handle were recovered.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, falsely accused Tom Elliott of harassing and shooting people during his UDR service (1982-1992) in a tweet. Elliott, now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, has a clear MoD record. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and must issue an apology admitting it was untrue. Compensation is pending, but his insurance refused coverage, leading to a separate legal challenge. Elliott stated he was vindicated, disappointed the matter took 19 months to resolve, but pleased with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, increased weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet demand, driven by strong sales of its new branded range launched in January and growth in private label business. Acquired by Benny Hartop in November last year, the company sells across European markets including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributed the growth to surge in orders from home and abroad for both private label and own-brand products, expressing confidence in continued success.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, in December after Brian Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light. Wright, 55, admitted striking her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming the setting sun blinded him. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, stating he has thought of her family daily since the incident. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting, potentially shining into his eyes, and the trial continues.

NATO's "Dynamic Mongoose" exercise addresses rising Russian submarine threats, using a German U-boat (U33) as a simulated adversary. Russia has expanded its submarine fleet to 60 vessels, including advanced quiet models, with experts stating they lead in submarine technology. The UK lacks maritime patrol aircraft, creating a critical vulnerability that forces reliance on NATO allies for surveillance near UK waters and risks the ability to monitor nuclear deterrent movements. This gap must be addressed in the UK's defense review.

UN officials indicate potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, with nearly a million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda—340,000 fleeing since July violence (more than Syria's 200,000 in 2016), averaging 2,500 daily. Ethnic violence between Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorians involves killings, rape, and civilian targeting. Uganda struggles despite aid efforts, with Bidi Bidi settlement housing over 250,000. UNHCR urges international pressure on South Sudanese leaders.

McKenzie, 38, will face Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight title at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer for Norwich and Peterborough, he turned professional in 2013 after quitting football two years earlier, with a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital's £33m project is part of a £330m coalition NHS investment for new facilities in England. The new hospital will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners, replacing the outdated 1813 building. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will fund the remaining costs. Matron Sue Taylor highlighted the current facility's poor condition and benefits of a modern environment for patient recovery. Three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced in five years, with work also underway on Musgrove Park Hospital's Jubilee Building. The new hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014. Dr. Donal Hynes emphasized improved integrated care delivery through the project.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was in or near a black Mercedes when shot, sustaining a chest wound. Officers arrived at 13:35 GMT; he died at hospital. Residents stated he was part of a local family celebrating when attacked, with neighbors attempting to help. Recent Sheffield shootings include a 25-year-old injured in Shiregreen on Monday, an elderly couple shot through a window in Southey Green (mistaken identity), and January incidents in High Green. All prior cases occurred in northern areas, not near Upperthorpe.

The passage describes three cyber groups involved in the Ukraine conflict: Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conducted DDoS attacks on rebel websites, hacked Russian government servers and payment systems, and monitored rebel-held areas via CCTV. They shared data with Ukraine's security service, though officials deny using it for artillery targeting. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, hacked Ukrainian government sites during Biden's visit, displayed anti-Ukrainian messages on billboards, disrupted election systems, leaked defense ministry data, and made unverified claims about MH17. Anonymous International published Kremlin documents and leaked communications of Russian rebel commander Igor Girkin, focusing on Russian domestic affairs. Inform Napalm analyzed 35GB of data confirming Russian military evacuations from Ukraine.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie are stepping down ahead of the May 5 election. Marwick was emotional during McNeil and Salmond's farewells. Salmond, former first minister, stated Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling unionist pledges, and joked about the UK budget and Cheltenham races. McNeil warned Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system for accountability, referencing Robin Cook's visit. Goldie joked about missing John Swinney's "faux indignation."

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is reviewing residential care quality for older people, collecting experiences from residents, families, and others to develop recommendations. She highlights both positive care impacts and unacceptable variations in quality, examining health, social relationships, and care environments. Her team will consult care providers, staff, and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review but criticizes the lack of care home providers (residents, staff, managers, owners) on the advisory panel, stating it prevents full sector engagement.

Harbro Group's pre-tax profit rose £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016 despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. International sales grew in Europe and new markets. The company manufactures feeds for livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland. It acknowledged agricultural challenges and Brexit uncertainties but expressed confidence in its preparedness for future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday. A man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) for questioning, treating the death as murder. He is described as white, 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair, average build, wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter trousers, and a checked shirt. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers and have increased patrols in the area.

David Lipton, IMF's second-in-command, stated the global economy faces a weakening baseline and delicate juncture, citing China's 25% year-on-year export decline. The IMF is likely to downgrade its 3.4% global growth forecast in April, with ongoing repercussions for businesses dependent on China's growth.

Council leader Dave Stewart announced free Cowes crossings until July 2 and an audit review due to ferry issues since May 14, including breakdowns, grounding, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency for training issues, and vehicle damage. Local businesses reported significant trade losses and sought compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated compensation is under discussion, described the ferry as a prototype with resolved electrical problems, ramp extensions to prevent scraping, and groundings fixed through seamanship improvements.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel, Bramshott, at 07:30 GMT Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models advertised job roles specifying physical traits such as "classic look, brown long hair with B-C cup" and "sexy female driver," drawing condemnation from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's rights campaigners as unlawful and sexist. Legal experts stated such ads breach the 2010 Equality Act, as terms like "beautiful" may discriminate against older women and clothing sizes must be job-essential. Founder Nathalie Jansen defended the practices citing client demands (e.g., a Dior outfit requiring smaller cup size, an Indian businessman seeking blonde, blue-eyed women), while EHRC chief Rebecca Hilsenrath emphasized that first impressions should not rely on superficial attributes and urged compliance with modern equality standards.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. Alleged gunman Mahesh, a school office assistant, shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and severely injured Sirisha, who is out of danger. Police remanded him until April 12 and arrested him after a manhunt. Gun crimes at Indian schools are rare, though many feuds are settled with firearms. In 2007, a 14-year-old was shot dead by peers near Delhi.

GLAAD's 2016-2017 study of scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. Over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. A record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television was attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD's president noted progress is heartening but emphasized numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his resignation, stating it is time for constituents to have a new representative. This follows criticism over his role as borough council leader in approving a £10.25m public loan to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment, with £10.25m now missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half-built, and a majority of his local party executive council intended to deselect him, though he denied wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old Dallas police officer, killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by shooting into a car during a Balch Springs party in April. Initial police claims that the vehicle reversed aggressively were disproven by footage showing it was driving away. Oliver faces murder and four aggravated assault charges, with no trial date set and his lawyer not commenting. He was fired for policy violations and remains free on bail. If convicted, he would be the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. The district attorney stated justice is proceeding, while Edwards' lawyer noted caution due to the rarity of police convictions in Texas. Edwards was described by his coach as possessing all desirable qualities as a player, son, teammate, and friend.

Melania Trump plans to move to Washington after Barron finishes school, with no specific date set, citing school concerns. Social media criticized her decision, though historians note it is not unusual, citing precedents like Grover Cleveland’s wife living elsewhere during social season, John Tyler’s children not moving immediately, and Dolley Madison sending her son to school. The Obamas moved to Washington early to avoid mid-term school changes. Melania’s focus is on Barron, potentially not taking a full-time public role, with interest in cyberbullying. Ivanka Trump may assist, as Chelsea Clinton did for Hillary Clinton. Past First Families maintained normal routines, such as the Obamas’ nightly family dinners and Chelsea’s homework in the Oval Office.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October this year. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) instructed the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is fully engaging and awaiting findings, with a report to be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning was issued for gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), particularly west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction increasing impact. Travel disruption is expected across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which will remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

Giants and Nottingham Panthers played a game where Derrick Walser scored a short-handed goal for the Giants, but Jeff Dimmen equalized. Mike Forney's powerplay breakaway goal made it 2-1, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2 before David Ling scored for Nottingham. The teams meet again Saturday in a double-header, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, Sheffield Steelers on 27, and Belfast on 25.

Hamilton started last, suffered front wing damage and five pit stops, facing a 36-point deficit. Vettel finished second after colliding with Raikkonen on lap one; Raikkonen recovered to fifth using soft tyres over Mercedes' mediums. Kvyat was involved in a first-lap incident with Vettel, leading to a post-race confrontation. Ricciardo took an early lead but had a puncture, allowing Rosberg to dominate. Hamilton's car was damaged by Nasr, with Mercedes confirming significant aerodynamic loss. Rosberg, having won the first three races, faces no historical precedent for failing to win the championship, making Hamilton's comeback challenging.

Thomas Hitzlsperger became the most prominent German footballer to publicly come out as homosexual, aiming to advance discussion on a previously ignored topic. He received widespread support from former teammates, administrators, and public figures including Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Theo Zwanziger, Reinhard Rauball, Gary Lineker, and John Amaechi. The announcement addresses homophobia in German and English football, with Zwanziger noting football remains challenging for open discourse on homosexuality. References to Justin Fashanu's suicide and Philipp Lahm's 2011 advice against coming out highlight past issues. Marcus Urban was the last German footballer to come out in 2007. Chancellor's spokesman and Volker Beck praised his courage, with Beck urging the German FA to embolden active players. Zwanziger expressed optimism that sexual orientation would soon not be an issue in football.

34-year-old Sidwell made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping Brighton secure promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. With his contract expiring, he aims to sign a new deal to help the team stay in the top flight. Brighton, leading by four points over Newcastle, are close to clinching the title. Sidwell previously played for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke in the Premier League. He stated he exceeded expectations at Brighton and believes he deserves another top-flight opportunity, hoping to finalize a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes from Nathan Delfouneso's assist, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester from a corner. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for relegated Sky Blues last season, previously at Charlton, Bradford, Preston; could debut for U's in EFL Cup against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started with 3-1 loss to Accrington. Latest transfers on dedicated page.

PC Keith Palmer's murder prompted greater emphasis on a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m for the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, where a memorial honoring over 1,400 officers and staff killed over 250 years will be built. The government committed £1m towards the £4m total cost, with a brass screen featuring leaf-shaped pieces for families of the fallen. Completion is expected by 2019.

Manchester United won 1-0 at Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top with eight games remaining. Manager Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming matches, citing 25 wins in 30 matches and 50 points from the last 18 Premier League games, aiming to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea led to planned changes for the FA Cup replay against Chelsea, with Rooney, Welbeck, and Cleverley rested due to fatigue. Giggs and Hernandez are available, while Rio Ferdinand was not taken to Sunderland. Ferguson praised the team's defending and courage after a challenging second half.

Mr Schmidt stated Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, asserting compliance with legal requirements and that tax system changes depend on government action. Margaret Hodge proposed a committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements secretly. EU leaders agreed to automatic tax authority information exchange. Google routes UK sales through Ireland, facing criticism for tax minimization. Schmidt argues taxes should be levied where economic activity occurs, not consumption, and calls for international tax reform debate, emphasizing politicians must set rules.

NHS Improvement reported the NHS has fallen behind schedule in reducing its agency staff bill, which was £3.6bn last year, with a target to cut £1bn by year-end. A cap introduced in October saved £600m by limiting payments to 55% above normal rates for staff (excluding senior managers). Trusts are 10% behind target, and figures exclude bank staff and overtime costs. Examples show hospitals quoted rates double the cap (e.g., £130 vs £76 for surgeons). NHS Improvement will publish league tables on agency spending and track top earners. CEO Jim Mackey stated the NHS cannot afford high agency costs and more action is needed.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger, now reflects Ireland's economic crash. Local trader Matt O'Brien reports a 30% decline from boom times but recent improvement through diversification into childrenswear and dress hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for prioritizing water meters over broadband and IDA's failure to attract foreign investment in four years. The government cites Center Parcs' planned 1,000 jobs (pending planning permission), but traders argue for measures like free parking to boost business. Early economic recovery is emerging, but more action is needed.

The competition concludes on 29 May with eight teams competing in a double round-robin format, top four advancing to play-offs. Leading run-scorers: Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249); most sixes: Warner and De Villiers (12 each); highest individual scores: De Kock (108), Warner and Gambhir (90*); most wickets: McClenaghan (9). Four England players participate: Morgan (Sunrisers), Buttler (Mumbai), Billings (Delhi), Pietersen (Rising Pune). Play-offs include Qualifier 1 (24 May), Eliminator (25), Qualifier 2 (27), and Final (29).

DEFRA reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, with many non-recyclable and discarded, causing environmental harm. England will charge 5p per bag from October to encourage reuse, following reductions in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where charges are in place. Campaigners hope this will reduce discarded bags and benefit the environment.

A school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, and hundreds of homes in Wales experienced power cuts. Friday's yellow wind warning led to train delays, bridge restrictions, and ferry cancellations. Highest gusts were recorded at Mona, Anglesey. Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, using cruise services. Arriva Trains Wales imposed speed restrictions on the Llandudno Junction to Holyhead line. National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Restrictions on A55 and M48 bridges were lifted as winds eased, but Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about the Black Panther film, stating he wants to "put a different spin on it" without specifying his role. He will reunite with director Ryan Coogler (from Creed), collaborate with Lupita Nyong'o (Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave) and Chadwick Boseman (who portrayed Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War). Jordan previously starred in the failed Fantastic Four reboot, and Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film is set for release in February 2018.

The Alexandra Palace east wing restoration project, costing £26.6m, includes refurbishing the 1875 theatre for performances, cinema, comedy, and live music, and repairing BBC studios. Heritage Lottery Fund contributes £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, with the Charitable Trust raising the final £1m by summer 2017. The glazed east court will become a public exhibition space, and the theatre, unused for decades but retaining original decor and machinery, was originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 England caps since his 2009 senior debut, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships but playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the England U21 record with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 2014 World Cup qualifier win over Moldova. Milner stated the decision was "about common sense" and wished Sam Allardyce, players, staff, and supporters success.

Marcy Smith's family escaped a fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, after her son David woke them upon seeing flames during a FaceTime call with his father. The house was destroyed, and their pets died; the fire started from rubbish burned in the wood stove, which she had done many times before, and the fire alarm did not activate. The family fled in pajamas, but the community donated clothes, shoes, and a bike. Smith emphasized David’s critical role in their survival, noting he doesn’t yet grasp the extent of his actions but she is immensely proud of him.

An energy drinks giant reportedly considered a £200m offer for West Ham. Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in 2010 for £105m and now own over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium in August, the club has been linked with potential takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan stated a minority share might be sold to clear debts, with ownership intended to pass to their children.

The fan-voted Los Angeles awards ceremony recognized *The Fault in Our Stars* as best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, Trailblazer Award, and best kiss (dedicated to author John Green). Bradley Cooper won best male performance for *American Sniper*, honoring Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, Efron (best shirtless), Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne, Kevin Hart (comedic genius award with his children), and Robert Downey Jr (Generation Award with Avengers stars) also won. The event promoted upcoming summer films, including *Pitch Perfect 2*, *Trainwreck*, and *Avengers: Ultron*.

Smith, 21, was loaned by Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross called him a "brilliant acquisition," noting his previous club was Dundee United and he will strengthen their attack. St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes now that weather conditions are suitable, targeting 145 potholes filled daily over the next four months. Additional staff are also repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

An incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016, where six Wood Group workers were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown work on pipework. EnQuest confirmed the exposure was below 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) but reported it, stating additional precautionary steps were taken. Workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, reported cancer fears, ongoing blood tests, and accused EnQuest of failing in its duty of care. Wood Group emphasized employee safety, conducted medical assessments, and supported a joint investigation. The Unite union criticized the handling of the incident, stressing the need for transparency. The HSE stated the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR and no investigation was conducted as no separate complaint was raised.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought the artwork for $650,000 from Art of the Past in 2007. Art of the Past manager Aaron Freedman admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze, with allegations arising from a 2012 court case. The Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari sculpture is thought stolen from a Tamil Nadu temple. After discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's ASI (which requested return in May), ACM decided to return it. While no conclusive proof of theft exists, ACM noted Freedman's confession of dealing in looted items and criminal possession of 150 stolen objects. ACM purchased 30 items from the dealer; others not listed as stolen but ASI viewed them. The museum will pursue legal action for compensation for apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at 15:48 local time, depth 15.5km, felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna, Modena, and Lucca. No immediate injuries or damage reported, but power and phone lines were disrupted in Garfagnana, and schools were evacuated. Aftershocks occurred. The INGV described it as a "medium-strong," fairly shallow quake. Italy's history includes the 2009 L'Aquila disaster (290 deaths) where scientists were convicted for misleading risk assessments, and last May's two quakes in the same area causing over 20 deaths, including a magnitude-6 tremor.

On 8 September 2016, a fruit remained attached to the plant and unripe. Austin Grant, a 62-year-old from Sheffield who doubted South Yorkshire's climate could support it, expressed joy upon seeing results.

Rockstar delayed the latest version of GTA V's release to 24 March from 27 January for additional testing and polish. Online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC version, which features 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor support. Minimum PC specifications have been published. GTA V was the fastest-selling entertainment product in 2013, earning $1 billion in three days.

Simpson, 76, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for *Squint (19)* at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, he described the painting as part of a series, with some larger works. Judge Ansel Krut called it "quite extraordinary" yet difficult to view, depicting medieval leper squints—holes in churches for undesirables to observe services. The 7ft-tall piece will fund art materials, with Krut noting its subtle technique and sympathetic subject matter. Established in 1957, the biennial prize has past winners including David Hockney, Peter Doig, and Sir Peter Blake (junior winner 1961).

Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both pro-AK Party newspapers, were attacked. Four masked assailants targeted Yeni Safak's offices, while Yeni Akit's offices 20km away were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday. No casualties reported; firefighters extinguished the blaze, windows shattered by gunfire, and spent bullet casings found at both sites. Police cordoned the area and are searching for assailants, with no group claiming responsibility. This follows last September's attack by pro-government protesters on Hurriyet over alleged misquoting of President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player, previously contracted with the Stags, joins Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer effective January 1 after scoring three goals in 23 appearances on loan at Crawley. He is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger, whose contract runs to summer, is linked with the England job but states he focuses on his current role. Southgate succeeded Sam Allardyce in September, with results including a 2-0 win vs Malta and 0-0 draw vs Slovenia. He has a World Cup qualifier vs Scotland on Nov 11 and friendly vs Spain to secure permanent position. Wenger stated Southgate has experience and competency is key, not big names. Bellerin will receive a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Man City, with Wenger stating his future is at Arsenal. Ramsey will miss one or two games due to hamstring injury from August 14.

Officers believe a local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the seafarers' pay dispute, ending a long-running row. The RMT union had alleged some workers on Seatruck-operated freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay were paid less than £4 an hour. Seatruck, contracted by Serco Northlink, argued the national minimum wage did not apply to non-UK crew, despite Serco's offer to bridge the pay gap. The new arrangement, effective early next month after finalizing details, ensures all crew receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds the £243m six-year Scottish government-subsidized contract for Northern Isles services since 2012.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, who had been in a long-term relationship but were in a "down phase." Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and both he and his mother Samantha, 57, admitted attempting to pervert justice by lying to police. They initially claimed Dickie pushed Mrs Mitchell, but later stated Mitchell tried to separate them, causing a "tragic accident." Sentencing is set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the songwriter behind Michael Jackson's "Thriller" and "Rock With You," as well as Heatwave's "Boogie Nights," died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. His work on Thriller contributed to it becoming the best-selling US album with 32 million copies. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, he won a Grammy and was Oscar-nominated. Tributes highlighted his legacy, with Warner/Chappell confirming his death and family's privacy request.

Researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian institutions discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs in Acre, Brazil, dating back 2,000 years. Concealed by rainforest until deforestation, their purpose remains unclear but is likely ritual rather than residential or defensive. Soil analysis revealed they were built amid taller vegetation, making them invisible above the canopy, challenging assumptions of a pristine Amazon. The findings indicate human-managed agroforestry over 6,000 years, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful plants, with possible ecological legacy in today's forests.

Kyrgios, 21, defeated Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance at the Shanghai Masters. Ranked 12th and fresh from a Japan Open title, he cited fatigue and travel issues as reasons for his subdued play, referencing a $1,500 fine last year for calling the Shanghai Masters a 'circus'.

Scientists and charities state HPV vaccination protects against head and neck cancers. Girls aged 12-13 in Wales currently receive the vaccine for cervical cancer, but charities urge extending it to boys due to rising head and neck cancer cases, particularly among non-smoking men averaging 55 years old, with three-quarters of cases affecting males. Dr. Mererid Evans noted demographic shifts over ten years, while Jon Antoniazzi highlighted HPV causes 5% of global cancer burden. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes, despite 85% of girls being vaccinated since 2008.

Jak Trueman, 15, died from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He briefly attended a school prom in his honor before feeling unwell. His mother announced his death on Facebook, expressing grief. His "Jak's Journey" Facebook page, with over 28,000 likes, documented his treatment, positive attitude, and interactions with football players and celebrities. After his cancer spread in January, treatment ceased; he thanked medical staff. His family raised funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with a charity football match planned.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal by El Said assisted by Salah, after Uganda's offside goal was disallowed. Egypt will face Ghana for top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated. Ghana advanced to the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali, and Mali must beat Uganda and have Ghana defeat Egypt by two goals to qualify.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus for a new railway station. A Network Rail study compared these sites with one near the Concourse shopping centre. Plans, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, aim to provide two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Councillor John Fillis noted the site's potential for expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The council will now begin land acquisition. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest northwest England towns without its own railway station.
Plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, leading to the arrest of a man in his late 40s.

Police in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, reported a 28-year-old unidentified woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, handed himself in and is in custody. Hannover prosecutors' spokesman Thomas Klinge stated the motive is unclear, and police have secured the area while appealing for witnesses.

Research by Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found women ask for pay rises as often as men but are less likely to receive them, refuting the "reticent female" theory. The study of 4,600 Australian workers compared full-time and part-time groups separately to eliminate employment-type disparities. Men were 25% more likely to get a raise when requesting one. Factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications were accounted for. Australia's survey uniquely tracks reasons for pay rise requests. Researchers suggested possible discrimination, noting under-40 workers of both genders have equal asking and receiving rates, indicating improved negotiation among young women.

Oxford City Council has used funds for ground investigations of potential burial sites but found none suitable. Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries will fill by 2018 and 2021, respectively. Despite ongoing efforts, suitable land within Oxford is exhausted due to size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants. After closure, only reopening family plots, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible, with the last burial space increase occurring in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) takes place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July. An augmented reality app allows visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews via signs and posters. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan stated the app enhances the festival experience and enables global interaction, with updates providing real-time access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and festival atmosphere from anywhere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed a severe pulmonary haemorrhage as the cause, stating such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no significant underlying health issues. Though he had a history of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), no symptoms were present on race day. He had previously won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, with his trainer calling him the "horse of a lifetime." The report concluded his death resulted from a rare haemorrhage not linked to prior conditions.

Davina (formerly David Ayrton), aged 34, denied raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Sentencing is set for 4 March; she was remanded into custody, likely in a male prison, due to risks of self-harm or failing to attend court. She has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer, changed her name in 2012, and stated no physical changes or medication during trial. The victim recalled the attack clearly after minimal alcohol consumption while others slept, and Davina disclosed the incident to a care home worker in 2014.

Serbs lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Djokovic's singles defeat by Juan Martin del Potro the previous day. Djokovic, world number one, suffered a surprise Wimbledon third-round loss to Sam Querrey and later claimed his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in Saturday's chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, using only chainsaws. Last year's winner Pete Bowsher from Moffat is returning to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old 16-cap Wales player, hasn't played since a September foot injury during a World Cup warm-up with Italy. He is close to returning for the Six Nations starting February 7 against Ireland, having adjusted his timeline with physios. He has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers, stating Ospreys is his home region and he aims to play for Wales.

US border agents intercepted two men smuggling MDMA near Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday. One fled after firing at agents; Jeffrey Laviolette was arrested. Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was later arrested in Canada with 58lb of ecstasy and a California driver's license in William Nickerson's name but Hall's photo. Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert were arrested for planning to transport the drugs, with Lambert to be paid $11,000. Three defendants face conspiracy and drug charges. The area is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

Childline counselled over 4,500 children last year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12, with actual online abuse numbers likely higher. Children as young as seven reported torment and fear of school. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized cyberbullying's inescapable nature and the need for adult intervention. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, and a child described online threats to self-harm with parental unawareness. The passage mentions advice from young people on dealing with bullying.

Following US abstention on a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements as illegal, Prime Minister Netanyahu reacted strongly, summoning US and other council ambassadors, recalling Israeli envoys, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a Ukrainian PM visit. The Jerusalem Planning Committee postponed a vote on 492 new settlement homes at Netanyahu's request to avoid straining relations before Secretary Kerry's speech. The resolution, which Israel rejected, particularly angered it over East Jerusalem condemnation. Kerry is expected to address the conflict and counter Israeli criticisms, while Palestinian President Abbas stated the resolution paves the way for a planned peace conference in France.

Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday celebrations included Prince William's tribute calling her a "guiding example" of a good monarch. Stamps featuring four royal generations were released. Windsor events included a Royal Mail visit marking the postal service's 500th anniversary, a bandstand opening with schoolchildren, and political leaders' comments. William addressed "work-shy" criticism, stating he takes duty seriously while developing his role. Activities also included unveiling The Queen's Walkway plaque, lighting global beacons, and a lunch with US President Obama. Republic criticized BBC coverage as biased and unbalanced.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring before halftime. Cheltenham, unchanged from their previous match, had limited chances including Harry Pell's volley and Dan Holman's near miss but failed to score. West Ham made seven changes after recent Premier League losses, ending League Two's representation in the competition ahead of the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old father of four from Leipzig, failed to spot him while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, received a £1,000 fine, and a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family accepted it was a momentary lapse with no value in jail, and Werner's defense cited his remorse and inability to explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, London, attempted to re-enter the UK after fighting with ISIS-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. Using the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, he produced slick propaganda targeting young British Muslims, including videos and images of combat and gruesome scenes such as a bloodied hand and holding a head in a bag. MI5 monitored him; he faked his death online before attempting to return, but was arrested at Dover. Police state he is a dangerous terrorist who concealed his entry. He faces up to life imprisonment, admitted four offenses, with a soliciting to murder charge on file. His cousin Tahir Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth. He has signed for Barnsley as their third signing for next season after rejecting a Wrexham contract offer. Barnsley caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and suitability to their playing style ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

Bottles of 'Vanish' washed up at Poldhu Cove and other Cornish coves, prompting National Trust volunteers to clear them due to wildlife risks, though sealed, some leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed the MV Blue Ocean lost a 'Vanish' container near Land's End in May but stated no evidence links the bottles to it, citing circumstantial evidence. Vanish has not commented. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed concern for marine life impacts. Authorities advise keeping children and dogs away and not attempting recovery.

An incident on the A9 north of Berriedale, Caithness, at 14:00 resulted in minor injuries to several other people. The road was closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland are investigating.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Bolton finish second in League One and secure promotion. Joined from Charlton in 2014 with 83 total appearances, he was praised by manager Phil Parkinson for his late-season contribution despite being overlooked. He is among David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan to sign new contracts following promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of conceding everything, while Labour's Baroness Smith criticized Lib Dems for giving "false hope." The parties previously cooperated to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal amendments but split when MPs rejected the amendments—Lib Dems insisted on them, Labour deferred to the Commons. Labour sources called Lib Dem actions "grandstanding" for campaign leaflets, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite past collaborations on issues like higher education and housing, Labour cited "residual tensions" and dismissed prospects of close cooperation beyond business-like relations.

Defense is a low election priority, ranked below economy, NHS, and immigration. UK military cuts have reduced the Army to 82,000, Navy to 19 warships, and RAF to seven front-line squadrons, creating capability gaps like no Maritime Patrol Aircraft. Defense spending has fallen to sixth globally and is projected to drop below NATO's 2% target, risking US credibility. Trident renewal costs dominate spending, with parties divided on replacement plans. Aircraft carriers face crewing shortages and reduced F-35 allocations, leading to "hollow force" concerns. No party pledges to protect defense budgets from further cuts.

Barcelona denies wrongdoing in Neymar's transfer, stating they covered potential contract interpretations. The total cost of the signing, including initial fee, wages, agents' fees, and tax payments, amounts to £106.8m, with £48.6m initially paid and £34m going to his parents. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation allegations he denies. A Spanish judge ruled to continue the investigation, and Barcelona made an additional tax payment of €13.55m to address discrepancies while maintaining their original tax payment was correct. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three in the Champions League this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father of a baby girl, died when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. His family and the van driver, Andy Harrington, called for regular driving tests and medical exams for older drivers, citing safety concerns. Age UK emphasized supporting older people to drive safely for independence, while the DVLA stated no age-based license restrictions, citing no evidence older drivers cause more accidents, and current self-assessment requirements every three years for those over 70.

Many women have questioned the safety of incontinence implants due to debilitating side effects. Two review group members quit protesting a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the review process and lessons learned. The report advises against routine use for pelvic organ prolapse, recommends informed choices and mandatory adverse event reporting. The government cannot ban the procedures, as this is the MHRA's responsibility. Review chair Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to achieve consensus, having no contact with the prior chair, and facing public criticism. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes resigned, citing dismay and claims of report modifications, and a consultant also quit. Over 20,000 Scottish women received implants, with more than 400 currently suing health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5000m record with a time of 14:49.12 at Glasgow's Emirates Arena. McColgan initially questioned if the race met UK Athletics criteria, citing Muir as the only 5K competitor in a mixed 3K event and drug testing concerns, but British Athletics confirmed ratification, noting no drug test was required without doping control. McColgan stated Muir could run faster (14.30), is world-class, and needs better tactics for medals. Muir also holds the British 1500m record and reached the Rio 2016 Olympic final.

Jung won gold aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou's infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and America's Phillip Dutton bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, having led after dressage but dropped to 21st in cross-country due to time penalties before a faultless show-jumping phase. He competed 10 months after an induced coma from a fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes, with match point at 20:57 BST. Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to advance to the fourth round against Benoit Paire. Johanna Konta also progressed with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. Murray described the match as tense and up-and-down, noting concerns about fading light but expressing relief at finishing in four sets. He acknowledged his movement wasn't optimal but aims to improve before Monday's match.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar, Dungiven, on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST. Police found patrons present with till receipts confirming alcohol served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered a three-month closure. Colleen O'Neill (43) faced two charges of serving liquor outside licensing hours, and James Thomas (44) one charge. The defense stated licensing laws were not strictly enforced, and the judge described O'Neill's record as "appalling," fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, while noting inability to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist manifesto with "Domination doesn't work, partnership does," shifting focus to his remarks after Danny Kennedy distanced himself, which Nesbitt called "reaffirming," drawing laughter. He denied regrets, would not withdraw his remarks, and preferred partnering with SDLP over Sinn Féin. He cited support in unionist areas and confidence in candidates' vote transfer positions. The manifesto includes tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI to 7,500, York Street interchange, LGBT support, and Brexit protections. Nesbitt framed the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, corruption related to the RHI scandal and DUP/Sinn Féin's governance.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion to the assembly for automatic pardons under 'Turing's Law', aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales. The motion provides posthumous pardons and allows living gay and bisexual men convicted of abolished sexual offences to apply, secured via executive agreement to correct past injustices and ensure equal treatment faster than an assembly bill.

Laura Muir, 23, from Kinross, finished second to Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record (4:22.60) and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. She holds Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed satisfaction at breaking the Scottish record, and is excited to be close to Kipyegon. Her husband shared Yvonne Murray's congratulations on Facebook. Muir aims to qualify for Rio Olympics at the British trials in June, following an 800m win in France last week and a 1500m race in Stockholm next week. She balances training with veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year.
Pictures of 26 Scottish beaches ranked 'most excellent' for water quality.

Richard Horwell QC stated suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive, but the Russian state likely sponsored the plot due to Litvinenko's defection, accusations against FSB, and criticism of Putin. UK officials believe they poisoned him with polonium-210 in 2006, leading to his death three weeks later. Horwell confirmed Russian state involvement but not necessarily Putin's direct role, with public radiation risks unknown and Litvinenko poisoned twice. Suspects left a polonium trail with no credible explanations; extradition failed, they remain in Russia. Kovtun was criticized for not testifying, and the inquiry was adjourned.

Steve Smith (26) is appointed Australia's Test captain following Michael Clarke's retirement, continuing as ODI captain and taking over Twenty20 duties due to Aaron Finch's injury. David Warner is vice-captain. Smith previously captained three Tests during Clarke's absence, with 32 Tests and 2,952 runs at 54.66 average. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and Warner's maturity despite past issues. They will lead limited-overs matches after the Ashes final Test starting August 20.

Mr. Farron refused multiple times to answer whether homosexual sex is a sin, stating "we are all sinners." He affirmed passion for LGBT-plus rights, prioritizing equal marriage and extending transgender marital rights by addressing the spousal veto. He explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill was due to the Lib Dems' amendment on individual liberties concerns being defeated, though he did not specify the concerns, while asserting support for equal legal access regardless of sexuality.

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare now operates the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire former Sanofi staff. Accord's spokesman stated the investment would have an "extremely positive" impact, and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes highlighted it as "fantastic news" for the region, strengthening its science and healthcare reputation while boosting the local economy. Accord develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, with Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland departing under voluntary redundancy and early retirement. SNP leader Stephen Flynn stated the departures indicate the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more to leave. Mr Ellis is the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Mr Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, and Mr Sutherland is head of HR and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

IS militants attacked Kabul's Sardar Daud hospital, detonating explosives at the gate and firing on staff and patients, killing four attackers after hours of fighting and wounding over 50. IS claimed responsibility; Taliban denied involvement. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack as "trampling all human values," noting hospitals are immune sites. The attack marked IS's first direct engagement with security forces in the capital, shifting from previous civilian-targeted attacks to Taliban-style tactics, suggesting expanded capabilities. Since declaring Khorasan Province in 2015, IS has carried out multiple attacks including a July 2016 rally (80 killed), Ashura attacks (30), November 2016 mosque (30+), and Supreme Court attack (22). Government claims to have rooted out IS from some eastern bases but not mountainous areas. Taliban recently killed 16 in Kabul suicide attacks after starting their Spring offensive.

English rider Martin crashed at this year's TT with a Fireblade bike plagued by mechanical issues. After initially stating he was quitting road racing, he clarified on Facebook he hasn't given up but won't race Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster," only enjoying walking the dog and racing the Mugen. After struggling and acting as a test rider, he informed the team the bike wouldn't be competitive at Ulster, leading to his withdrawal (though he wasn't informed of the decision). Martin stated there's no unfinished business and plans to race classics and oddball events.

APC won 19 governorships, marking PDP's largest defeat since 1999 and its first presidential loss. PDP lost key northern states (Katsina, Kaduna, Adamawa) but retained Rivers State and secured eight governorships in the southeast. Taraba's result is pending, Imo's election was inconclusive. APC gained control of Lagos and northern states but failed to win any oil-producing states, raising concerns for Buhari over oil revenue and militant disruptions. Elections saw 66 violent incidents, primarily in southern states, though overall more peaceful than past polls. PDP faces introspection after 16 years in power due to defections, corruption allegations, and failure to address the northeast insurgency.

An environmental group Mighty accused Olam and Temasek of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices contributing to Southeast Asian haze caused by Indonesian slash-and-burn agriculture. Both companies deny the allegations, with Olam stating it has a strict "no burn, no peat, no deforestation" policy and buys 99% of palm oil from third-party suppliers. Mighty claims Olam created a secretive market for rogue suppliers, while Temasek, as Olam's majority stakeholder, asserts it does not control Olam's operations. The palm oil industry faces criticism for labor issues, deforestation, and burning, with NGOs and executives disputing responsibility. Olam also denies accusations of rainforest destruction in Gabon, citing transparent partnerships.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri (knee) is a doubt after only playing from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall following a late equalizer as a substitute against the Terriers.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version.
