The PTA confirmed restored access, with Google reviewing government requests to block content for Pakistani users, though not automatically granting them, and recording requests in Transparency Reports. While many welcomed the lift, activists seek transparency on the agreement terms. The ban was imposed in 2012 following protests over the 'Innocence of Muslims' film, which led to deaths due to blasphemy concerns. Google also launched local versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility demands Scala step down by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of FIFA's Electoral Regulations on conflict of interest. In 2015, Scala and Claudio Sulser withdrew when candidates shared nationality (Blatter was Swiss), but Scala's spokesman states no regulation prohibits same nationality, and his 2015 withdrawal was voluntary due to Blatter's incumbency. With no incumbent this time and five candidates, Scala's camp says no conflict exists. Bility, previously denied candidacy, now supports Prince Ali, threatens CAS action if Scala doesn't resign. The election on 26 February features five candidates: Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, decided by 209 FIFA members in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments, which makes buckets for diggers, in Spar Road on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. Forensic evidence indicates toxic fume build-up and ignition caused the fireball, and the Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to CAF for complaints about a contentious penalty incident during the 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, denying corruption allegations but criticizing referee selection due to age and experience. Morocco's participation was secured after CAS overturned their ban and reduced a $1m fine to $50,000 following their refusal to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola concerns, leading to Equatorial Guinea stepping in as hosts. Both nations qualified for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia in Group A (Togo, Liberia, Djibouti) and Morocco in Group F (Cape Verde, Libya, São Tomé).

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of Chelsea's 3-1 win at Etihad Stadium, Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct (his second this season after a challenge on David Luiz), and Fernandinho was banned for three matches after clashing with Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas faces no further action, Pep Guardiola apologized, and both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales and parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in developed countries. A pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot targets patients whose GPs have concerns but no urgent symptoms, inspired by Denmark's diagnostic systems. Currently, patients without clear symptoms face long diagnosis delays due to unclear pathways, leading to multiple referrals over weeks. The new system involves 40 GPs in Cwm Cynon referring patients to Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant within seven days for same-day testing, targeting six patients weekly. Only 35% of those with worrying symptoms in Cwm Taf currently receive a diagnosis. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital under Swansea Bay Health Board. Developed over 12 months after experts returned from Aarhus, Denmark, the trials aim to reassure patients and speed up diagnosis to improve early detection. If successful, other health boards will adopt the service.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. They declared at 589-8 and 173-1, securing their second-largest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root was man of the match with 254 and 71 not out, praised by Alastair Cook and Trevor Bayliss for his maturity and improvement. Pakistan struggled, with captain Misbah-ul-Haq citing poor shot selection and low confidence, while Geoffrey Boycott and Michael Vaughan noted England's dominance but cautioned the series could remain tight.

Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley in his backroom team. McBryde, who previously coached Wales in 2009 and 2013, assumes head coach responsibilities for the summer tour. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for McBryde and aims to confirm the management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies stated the involvement of Welsh coaches benefits national rugby, with the 2017 tour providing development opportunities and inspiration.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game league losing streak. Southampton took an early lead via Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty, but Hull's first-half injuries to Abel Hernandez and Will Keane were countered by Robert Snodgrass' substitute impact, scoring and assisting Michael Dawson's goal. David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas cleared off the line in added time. Despite the win, Hull remain in the bottom three. Managers cited concentration lapses and injury challenges as key factors.

A motorcyclist died in a crash on the B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa, at 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses and have closed the B1191 both ways between B1192 Tattershall Road (Woodhall Spa) and A158 Jubilee Way (Horncastle).

President Ivanov canceled an investigation into abuse of power claims from covert recordings, stating he aimed to "put an end to the agony" ahead of June elections. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, with EU Commissioner Hahn stating it violates rule of law and risks Macedonia's EU membership. Macedonia has been in turmoil since the 2015 recordings surfaced, allegedly showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and murder cover-ups. Opposition leader Zaev has released recordings since February 2015 accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and high-level corruption, which the government denies while accusing Zaev of destabilization—a claim he rejects.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's next match after Bob Bradley's sacking, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the preferred new boss. Curtis warned that relegation would make promotion difficult due to the stronger Championship, citing Norwich and Burnley's success but noting Swansea lacks Newcastle's resources. The club, promoted in 2011 after rising from near bankruptcy and 2003 relegation threats, has struggled since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes and diluted "Swansea Way." Curtis believes the current squad can stay up, with new signings aware of the club's history via *Jack to a King*, stressing its importance for the club and local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient, who kept their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached League One in 2010, have League Two's worst goal difference and conceded 20 more goals than the same point last season. Jamie Cureton scored nine goals this term, down from 20 in 2014-15. Manager John Still, who previously took the club from the Conference to League One, is committed to promotion next season. Leyton Orient are two points from play-offs after Kevin Nolan was removed as player-manager four days prior. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler stressed professionalism and fan importance, while Still cited lack of organization and discipline as reasons for the defeat.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to the club as a youth coach in February, his first role since retiring. Klopp praised the appointment, stating Gerrard aims to become a manager and is ready to learn. Gerrard debuted in 1998, won multiple trophies including the Champions League, retired in November after 19 years, and is working toward his UEFA A coaching licence after previously declining a managerial role at MK Dons as "too soon."

McManus opened the scoring in the 15th minute, Ross Forbes doubled Morton's lead with a deflected strike. Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back into the game before halftime, but late goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted found children taught in squalid conditions in three closed Birmingham schools, with operators facing up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are consulting on regulations for schools teaching over six to eight hours weekly. Sir Michael Wilshaw noted inspectors were shocked by conditions, with 18 unregulated schools (mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands) visited; three Birmingham schools closed and owners investigated. He warned cases may be the "tip of the iceberg" with children at risk of abuse or radicalization. Schools teaching over 20 hours must register; some "flexi schools" are legal for home education, but Ofsted suspects misuse. Officials were criticized for slow action and confusing advice. A six-inspector team is investigating, with inspections applying to all religious groups. The Education Secretary seeks prosecutions requiring her consent, with a consultation ending mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years. Using local Teviot Valley botanicals to capture regional terroir, it operates on a small scale in a cowshed with one of the UK's smallest stills. Named after a 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor heroine, it reflects the landscape and female-led team, complementing the existing brewery, while whisky distillery proposals for the region's first since 1837 are in planning.

Harry Whitlam died when Gary Green reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, on 9 August 2013. Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit (equivalent to 13 pints of beer), was prosecuted under health and safety law due to the incident occurring on private land. He received a 16-month and two-week jail sentence after admitting to failing to ensure others' safety. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, stated the family was "changed forever," emphasizing that drunk driving is unacceptable on any land, and noted her memories of Harry are now solely tied to the accident day. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green’s actions as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, 27, can now train and play in friendly matches following a CAS ruling that modified FIFA's ban. He must serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games, with his Barcelona competitive debut likely against Real Madrid on 26 October. CAS confirmed FIFA's sanctions but deemed the total ban on all football activities excessive, allowing training and friendlies. Suarez is eligible for Uruguay's September and October friendlies. His legal team called the appeal a success, arguing FIFA misapplied rules, while Fifpro expressed disappointment. Previously banned for biting incidents and racial abuse, Suarez's £75m transfer to Barcelona was confirmed, with a public presentation scheduled for Monday at Camp Nou, though his participation in Monday's game against Club Leon remains uncertain.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna defeated Lithuania's Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. They trained for a week on a local athletics track, facing strong competition. The race involved a 380-metre course with haystack hurdles, steep slopes, and dodging water pistols. Participants need not be married, and teams included men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. They will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond confirmed that scrapping car tax discs in October 2014 would lead to job role changes and redeployment of the DVLA's 5,000 workers rather than redundancies under the new electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. Mike Hedges welcomed the assurance, acknowledging reduced job opportunities but appreciating the system's benefits and redeployment commitment.

Hungary's government under PM Viktor Orban refuses to repeal three EU-criticized laws: asylum seeker containment in shipping containers, NGO regulations labeling groups as "foreign-backed," and a higher education law threatening the closure of George Soros-founded Central European University (CEU). Poland has pledged to veto EU sanctions, which require unanimous approval. Protests have occurred, and EU Commission deputy Frans Timmermans warned of imminent action if no changes are made.

The live-action film casts a star as Mrs. Potts (previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version), Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, directed by Bill Condon. Released March 17, 2017, with filming beginning in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a Sunday Times columnist diagnosed with multiple cancers ("the full English"), wrote a final column about his diagnosis before dying suddenly. Colleagues hailed him as a "giant among journalists" and "heart and soul" of the paper, praising his wit, fearless writing, and controversies including offensive remarks about Welsh people, Rhyl, Norfolk, Isle of Man, and Clare Balding. Born in 1954, he overcame dyslexia, had multiple marriages, and children from different relationships.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (Amraa), lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was attacked in Ulaanbaatar while performing in a swastika-embroidered Mongolian robe. The swastika is a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Hitler, which he used to clarify it is not a hate symbol. His father stated he was hit with a metal object, causing serious brain injuries and a 10-day coma. The Russian embassy called press reports "distorted" regarding details like date and circumstances. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not detained due to non-serious injuries, with police denying diplomatic immunity as the reason. His lawyer, father, and band denied claims he shouted "Heil Hitler," and the case remains under investigation.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested airport expansion on Monday, charging with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area. They will appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, prompting a Metropolitan Police review of airport security.

Nick Selman scored 101 for Glamorgan, his second first-class century, after being dropped early. He had four ducks following his previous century against Northants. Aneurin Donald contributed 36. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets, bowling Glamorgan out for 220. Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten secured a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire struggled in their innings, with the day ending evenly balanced. Michael Hogan captained Glamorgan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck injury. Selman cited the slow wicket and disappointment at getting out post-century. Taylor highlighted hitting the stumps three times and the challenge for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after contacting the Tennessee Hope Line Crisis Centre online, raising fears of a planned police ambush based on a non-existent crime. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Prosecutors stated he planned to make a false report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary for a shooting, with threats made twice while drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, citing a prior 2009 firearm conviction. His legal team claimed he had no intent to kill himself or carry out the threats, and North Wales Police were concerned as he was on bail for firearms offences (later cleared). The Hope Line provides confidential support.

Surrey scored 255-7, with Ben Foakes (90) and Davies adding 130 runs. Yorkshire's chase collapsed after Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls, including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, they were bowled out for 236. Yorkshire were well-placed at 75-2 before Meaker's burst, with Matthew Waite dropping Davies (43) but later taking 3-48. Having lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals, they aimed to reach Lord's but failed. Surrey's captain praised the partnership and timely wickets, while Yorkshire's captain cited insufficient top-order contributions.
A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced pump failure at 07:00 BST. RNLI lifeboat crew installed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24-year-old veterinary medicine student, will miss the Commonwealth Games due to exam conflicts. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the latter. She expressed disappointment but prioritized her degree, stating she has potential for multiple future Olympics and may target the World Indoor Championships in March.

Liverpool are miles away from repeating last season's title challenge, needing top-four as success. Loss of key strikers Suarez and Sturridge has reduced goals, with current attackers lacking quality and work rate. First-half goals dropped from 59 to four in 10 games, set-pieces less effective. Defense remains weak despite spending on Sakho and Lovren, with Mignolet lacking command. Against Chelsea, a loss is expected as the Blues are superior. Steven Gerrard, despite a past slip, remains vital but faces mental and physical challenges at 34 to prove mobility and stay competitive.

A £45m facility at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, will be named after William McIlvanney pending family permission. Born and educated in Kilmarnock, McIlvanney was an English teacher who became a full-time writer in 1975. His debut novel *Remedy Is None* brought immediate recognition, earning him the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" through works like the *Laidlaw* trilogy, *Docherty*, and *The Big Man*. He was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scottish political and sporting life. He died on 5 December at his Glasgow home.

An evacuation near Gourock's swimming pool affected three streets, with safety advice for residents within 500m. Exclusion zones on the river and half-mile at sea disrupted ferry services. A 1940s/50s British sea mine, deemed unsafe due to deterioration, was being moved safely as its explosive content was uncertain. Authorities confirmed no immediate danger, calling it a precautionary measure, and thanked residents for their patience.

UK Sport allocated £345m for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than Rio's £347m. Medal targets are set at 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Cycling funding was cut by over £4m to £25.98m, while badminton lost all funding despite winning a Rio bronze, drawing criticism. Judo received a slight funding increase despite also securing a bronze. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball, previously defunded, accuse UK Sport of neglecting their development. New sports added for Tokyo (baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, etc.) have pending funding decisions, with £9m unallocated. UK Sport states prioritization is necessary to protect medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View—in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished for a six-storey four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys with 122 units). Despite English Heritage and 49 objectors citing severe harm to the historic character, councillors approved the project 7-3, citing tourism benefits and the buildings' outdated functionality. The council received 246 supporting letters.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was killed by Jake Vallely, 24, during a night out in Brecon. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. CCTV showed Boyd being punched and beaten outside The Cellar bar until unconscious, after which Vallely dragged his body away. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon." Police called the attack "despicable," urging avoidance of violence. Boyd's family described him as loving, loyal, and with a promising career cut short, stating Vallely created an unfillable void, while the community's support demonstrated true strength.

Andrew Travers left by mutual agreement after a voting error where all 155 Barnet polling stations turned away voters due to missing names; only 3 of the first 30 voters were registered. An independent investigation was launched, with Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton temporarily taking over. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and voters questioned the election's fairness. Travers blamed electoral registration lists, and a review concluding by end of May will examine EU Referendum arrangements, with findings presented publicly.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick to give Gateshead the lead, Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before halftime with a set-piece, and Ryan Bowman headed in the winning goal. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised the team's second-half improvement after a disappointing first half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills cited poor second-half performance and missed chances.
Norway ranks highest, Afghanistan lowest, and Mozambique second lowest in the 2014 Global AgeWatch Index measuring social and economic welfare for those over 60 across 96 countries.

Airbus and OneWeb are constructing a satellite constellation starting with at least 600 spacecraft, potentially exceeding 2,000, to deliver global broadband, including schools. They are using new assembly lines in Toulouse and Florida for high-volume, low-cost production (three units per shift under $1 million each), moving away from traditional 'gold-plated' methods. Over 20 Soyuz rockets will launch satellites in clusters, targeting ~300 by late 2020/early 2021, over 600 by mid-2021, and 800+ by mid-decade. OneWeb commits to de-orbiting satellites within two years, exceeding the ESA's recommended five years, with added hardware and adapter devices. Registered in the UK Channel Islands, it expects significant UK economic benefits and regulatory leadership. Competitors like SpaceX are also planning constellations, but OneWeb has first-mover advantage with $1.7bn raised. Airbus notes some missions, such as Jupiter probes, still require bespoke satellites.

Mr. Swinney stated the UK government's spending review imposed a 12.5% real-terms reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with over £1bn more cuts before 2020, but pledged to protect schools, hospitals, police, free university education, and maintain record health spending. The UK government highlighted Scotland would receive £390m more next year (rising to £750m with underspend) and a £30bn block grant, urging focus on new powers rather than grievance. Labour criticized Swinney for lacking concrete plans, demanding a long-term budget and alternative tax policies distinct from the Tories and SNP.

People with severe disabilities and their carers face isolation due to inadequate toilet facilities, as standard accessible toilets don't meet needs for hoist users or those requiring two carers. Changing Places toilets, larger and equipped with extra features, exist in 893 UK locations but are only recommended, not compulsory, in building regulations. Campaigners push for mandatory installation in new large buildings like shopping centres and stadiums, citing psychological distress from their absence. Over 250,000 people need these facilities, with examples including Lorna Fillingham's petition and Arsenal Football Club's successful installation.

Italian consumer groups filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. McDonald's stated it shares risks and rewards with licensees, claiming this approach has been successful. Supported by SEIU and European unions, the complaint alleges McDonald's abuses its market dominance, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. Franchisees are reportedly locked into long contracts preventing them from switching competitors and lease premises above market rates, leading to reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores versus company-owned ones. Franchisees own 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, and the company earned $9.27bn from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014. The European Commission will review the complaint to determine if an investigation is warranted.

A #prayforjosh billboard was erected at Holywood playing fields by a mystery donor last week as part of a social media campaign for 13-year-old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down, diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors discovered a large primary cancer and five smaller growths during his scheduled appendix operation. Initiated by Bangor Elim Church (where his father serves), the hashtag went viral with 948 shares and 79,000 views, prompting global support via Twitter and social media.

The UK government is reorganizing military facilities, including closing Brecon Barracks, which has operated since 1805 and hosted troops in conflicts like Rorke's Drift. Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the closure, citing historical significance, high local unemployment, and potential harm to military tourism, though no job losses are expected for the 85 civilian and 90 military staff. Nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon confirmed a light infantry center will be established at St Athan, with Cawdor Barracks closing in 2024 and Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Labour's Nia Griffith supported restructuring but warned of livelihood impacts and uncertainty for affected communities.

The passage states that UK fishing communities, which heavily voted to leave the EU, may face marginalization in Brexit negotiations despite contributing only 0.5% to GDP and employing 12,000 people. While the industry sees Brexit as an opportunity to regain control of UK waters and boost exports, the House of Lords report warns of trade-offs, including potential EU access to UK waters for tariff-free market access. Shared fish stocks, reliance on EU markets for exports, and the need for scientific quotas and international cooperation complicate negotiations. The report also notes risks of divergent fisheries management across UK nations post-Brexit. Recent EU quota increases for key species and industry optimism about control over the 200-mile exclusive economic zone highlight potential opportunities, though the government emphasizes balancing trade freedom with sustainable fisheries management.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA contractor, leaked documents revealing NSA surveillance programs like Prism, which allegedly accesses chat logs, social media, phone records (including Verizon data), and data from nine major tech companies. The NSA claims the program aids security, but companies deny involvement and experts question its scope. US laws such as the Patriot Act and FISA permit broad data access, including non-US citizens' data stored in the US, prompting EU concerns. Privacy advocates warn of pervasive surveillance, with Snowden stating he acted to prevent a society where all activity is recorded.

Backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, OpenAI aims to advance AI for humanity's benefit without financial constraints. Scientists like Musk and Hawking warn AI could pose existential risks, while others deem the threat remote. OpenAI states AI should extend human will and be broadly distributed, with only a small fraction of its $1 billion pledged funds used in the near term.

L/Bdr Parkinson, injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on June 26, receiving over 5,000 Facebook friend requests beyond the platform's limit. His nomination highlighted his recovered speech and unchanged personality despite brain injury. He spends 12 hours daily in rehab and gym, uses crutches, and supports military charities as a Pilgrim Bandits patron. His mother described the overwhelming support as "phenomenal," with 19,000 update hits and increased mail. Facebook advised switching to a public page or using subscribe. The torch relay involves 8,000 bearers over 8,000 miles for 70 days until the London Olympics opening on July 27.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate was 15% (46.2 million people), staying flat after three previous years of increases. Real median household income dropped by 1.5%, the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021 (£14,300), and income inequality (Gini index) rose 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The uninsured rate fell to 15.7% from 16.3%, with poverty peaking at 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, 25, moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and signed a new deal until 2019. A short-format specialist, he holds England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised his talent, role in the T20 Blast final victory, and positive influence in the squad. Currently with Mumbai Indians in the IPL, he will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register interest, with no preservation proposals submitted. Final bids are being finalized, with viewings in late February and March, and a spring decision. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one to a UK recycler to assess industry capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports UK recyclers but prefers reefing one as a diving attraction for tourism. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for best financial return. The frigates were originally anti-submarine vessels but evolved into multi-role combatants with 280 crew. HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m last year.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation in Fiji, marked by coups in 1987 (overthrowing an Indian-dominated government), 2000 (hostaging the Indian prime minister), and 2006 (military takeover). These events harmed the economy and reputation, leading to a 2009 Commonwealth suspension, later reinstated after 2014 elections. The population, divided between indigenous Fijians (now a small majority after Indo-Fijians fled), Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian indentured laborers), and smaller minorities, faces segregation. Despite a diverse economy (sugar, tourism, mining, services), persistent deficits make Fiji a top per capita aid recipient.

Syria missed a deadline to hand over its chemical weapons stockpile, with a shipment attacked twice during transport. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad blamed terrorist groups for the attacks and denied using barrel bombs in Aleppo, despite reports of 246 deaths (including 73 children) from such attacks. The Syrian government disputes rebel claims of capturing Aleppo's central prison, which holds 3,000 detainees. Of Syria's 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, only 30 tonnes (4%) have been removed. The US expressed concern over delays, Russia urged completion by March 1, and the OPCW cited security issues slowing the process, though Syria affirmed commitment to its obligations.

Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" is the 5/2 favorite for the Booker Prize, the first year open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes Howard Jacobson (2010 winner), Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, Richard Flanagan, and another British writer. Fowler's novel is the best-seller with over 55,000 copies sold, while Mukherjee's sales rose from 97 to 507 after the announcement. Critic David Brauner called the list weak but highlighted Jacobson's "J" as strongest, citing possible reluctance to award him a second time. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500, with the winner announced at London's Guildhall.

The Supreme Court will consider whether to hear an appeal against a ruling lifting a media ban on naming PJS, with an interim injunction remaining until the hearing. The Court of Appeal determined the story's widespread publication in the US, Scotland, and online has eroded confidentiality, making a permanent injunction unlikely. PJS, who has young children and a public spouse, sought to block publication of alleged extra-marital activities involving a three-way encounter with AB and CD, but publishers argued the information was already public.

Fosse Park near M1 junction 21, opened in 1989, was purchased for £345.5m in August. Plans are underway to improve parking, traffic congestion, and unit appearances. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White stated it serves as the gateway to the city, currently displaying "too many backs of sheds," and new owners view it as an investment for enhancement. Crown Estates' Paul Clarke highlighted addressing parking, congestion, and the "tired" state of common areas and facilities to elevate the location.

Disney's live-action "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia over a "gay moment" in LeFou's subplot, leading to a content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved it with a minor edit and P13 classification, though the release date is pending and cinema chains are offering refunds. The tourism minister called a ban "ridiculous," while critics highlighted inconsistencies, noting approval of other films deemed lacking moral values.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people must obtain an HMO licence, costing £1,000 but risking £20,000 fines if unlicensed. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs, with tenants facing eviction fears and poor conditions due to affordable housing shortages, prompting 5-6 Shelter helpline calls daily. National mandatory licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. Southampton’s Designation 1 (2013) covers Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, and Swaythling; Designation 2 (2015) includes Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. The council reports general landlord cooperation but has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Fianna Fáil's Micheál Martin aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but not support its programme, with water charges a key dispute—Fianna Fáil seeks immediate removal while Fine Gael supports them. A commission for Irish Water is under consideration. After the election, Fine Gael (50 seats), Fianna Fáil (44), Sinn Féin (23), and Labour (7) failed to form a majority or elect a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire on a car deck while en route to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. The fire spread rapidly, leading to passenger evacuation onto lifeboats, which were rescued by the Puglia ferry. Three people were injured, one seriously, and transported to hospital by helicopter. Initially, the captain did not believe evacuation was necessary, but the fire's intensity forced a full evacuation. Rescued passengers were en route to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists providing support. The Balearic Islands port authority warned the ship may sink in its current position.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs highlighted alleged cases of double voting (a criminal offense), citing unlinked electoral registers causing duplicate applications. A record 46.8 million registered for the June election, with 68.7% turnout—the highest since 1997. Between December 2016 and May 22, 4.9 million applications were submitted, but net registration increased by only 1.4 million, suggesting 30-70% duplicates due to disconnected online and local systems. The watchdog noted administrative burdens and recommended verification tools like those in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland. While no evidence confirmed widespread double voting, voting twice in a general election is illegal, though students and those with second homes may legally register in multiple constituencies for local elections. Labour warned against policies that could hinder young people’s registration, stressing the need to balance fraud prevention with accessibility.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, died by suicide. A former University of Nebraska star and NFL player for the Rams, Dolphins, and 49ers until 1999, he faced repeated legal issues, including assault convictions for driving into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend, leading to over 30 years in prison. Accused of killing his cellmate Damion Soward, a judge found sufficient evidence to try him for the death. His Nebraska coach noted his intelligence and good qualities but stated he could not overcome anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classified as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at a Chester event marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. Awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour", he is the 30th mascot in a lineage dating to the Indian Mutiny in the mid-19th century. The first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th Regiment in 1858, and the current mascot joined the Mercian Regiment in 2014. He has an army number, receives pay for rations, takes holidays during mating season at Chatsworth Estate, and has participated in events including switching on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic Europa League quarter-final, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winner in injury time. The victory advances them to the semi-finals, moving them closer to Champions League qualification through winning the tournament. Overcoming a 3-1 deficit, the team's resilience was inspired by Klopp’s leadership and the 2005 Istanbul comeback. The match featured intense atmosphere, including a Hillsborough memorial, and key performances from Origi, Coutinho, and Sakho, though defensive vulnerabilities were noted. Klopp enforced a ban on players touching the 'This Is Anfield' sign until they win a trophy.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr Davis stated the UK government would hold monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland for two-way information sharing on Brexit negotiations, describing the discussion as constructive. Mr Russell emphasized the UK government's lack of clarity on single market and customs union membership four months post-referendum, stressing single market access is essential for Scotland's economy. The UK government seeks to overturn the High Court's Article 50 ruling, while Scotland plans to oppose this appeal in the Supreme Court, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe applying to participate.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four clones from the same cell line as Dolly the sheep, are being studied to assess aging and health impacts of cloning. Researchers, led by Prof. Kevin Sinclair, investigate whether cloning transfers "age-memory" from adult cells, potentially causing premature aging. Dolly died at 6.5 years from osteoarthritis and a viral infection, prompting the study. The sheep underwent tests for cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Current results show the clones, aged 9-10, are healthy, with findings set for publication next week.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes as the 4-7 favorite, defeating Vintage Folly by 1.75 lengths. She will now compete in the French Oaks at Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks, where Enable and Coronet are Gosden's entries. Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Dettori noted the soft ground made the race challenging but praised Shutter Speed's quality, expecting improvement on better surfaces. Gosden is concerned about Cracksman's readiness for the Dante Stakes due to ground conditions and the 16-day gap before the Derby, possibly skipping the race.

The pound fluctuated, down 0.2% vs dollar, 0.6% vs euro, and 1% vs yen, with volatility index at 2008 crisis levels. Polls showed Leave ahead, Remain probability dropping to 68.5% from 80%. Analysts warned of increased volatility, with hedge funds short-selling sterling. Asian markets fell sharply (Nikkei -3.5%, Hong Kong -2.5%), FTSE 100 down 1.1%. Leave campaign claimed the pound retreated to March levels, while Nigel Farage stated sterling had strengthened since March, citing a narrowed April trade deficit.

Braintree (The Iron) are sixth in the National League, one point and place outside the play-offs. After a long journey and conceding early, they lost to Barrow, whose unbeaten run extended to nine games, while Braintree's losing streak reached three. Manager Cowley remained positive, stating it is their toughest challenge as a part-time team but they will embrace it.

From April 2015, Northern Ireland councils will take over most planning decisions previously managed by the Planning Service, with councillors now having final authority. Supporters, like Michael Corr of PLACE, view this as a democratic opportunity for community-led development, emphasizing the need for politicians skilled in urban planning. Critics, including Friends of the Earth, warn of potential discrimination in planning approvals, citing historical issues like 1960s housing allocation bias, and stress the need for strict transparency to prevent undue influence from developers and political parties. Concerns also exist over political donations, with debates about the relevance of the £7,500 disclosure limit and the Northern Ireland Secretary's role in determining transparency measures.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in amputation of her left leg and is now learning to hop. Found in Winchburgh on March 14, her owner noted the gun's power caused severe damage and highlighted crossfire risks in a housing estate. The Scottish SPCA stressed the need for urgent airgun licensing, citing a consultation where 87% of respondents opposed the proposal, some calling it "draconian." They urged anyone with information to come forward.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke as their second most expensive player on a long-term contract, triggering his release clause after selling Raheem Sterling for £49m. The Belgium international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa since joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. Following Luis Suarez's £75m sale and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, Liverpool's strikers netted only eight goals last season (including three from Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert), finishing sixth. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup but returned to score 15 times for Villa, aiding their survival and FA Cup final. He joins Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and returning Divock Origi. Former managers and ex-players highlighted his physical presence and potential to strengthen the attack.

Study by Tablets for Schools found no clear academic improvement from tablets despite widespread use (68% primary, 69% secondary schools; 9% 1:1; higher in academies). Tablet numbers expected to rise from 430k to 900k (2014-2016). Dr. Clarke states no definitive link to results but notes positive impacts on motivation and family involvement, with technology's role growing. A separate National Literacy Trust and Pearson study found touch-screens aid reading for boys and poorer pupils, who prefer digital over print. Ofcom reports 70% of 5-15-year-olds have home tablets. In 1:1 schools, 25% of secondary pupils self-identify as internet addicts, and two-thirds take devices to bed for social media or videos. Simon Mason emphasizes tablets' portability, empowerment, and alignment with real-world technology use.

Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs from the 1880s to 1990s, capturing childhood experiences and Liverpool's social history. Includes images like the 1887 Rollo family portrait at a Bootle ball and a 1900s young maid working. Curated by Kay Jones, highlighting both joyful and difficult aspects of childhood, running until September 25.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, cancelled his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join their National League rivals and could feature against his old club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, was recommended by Micky Adams, with previous spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps; move subject to clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson stated Anderson is a leader despite limited games and Keating is young, raw, and hungry. The Gulls are four points above relegation with one win in their last six games.

Bolivia's new law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, despite ILO guidelines setting 14 as the minimum working age for developing countries. It imposes harsher punishments for child violence, including 30 years in jail for child homicide. Approved by Congress and signed by Vice-President Garcia during President Morales' absence, the law aims to address extreme poverty while balancing Bolivia's reality with international treaties. Over 500,000 children work to supplement family income, often in hazardous conditions. The ILO is reviewing whether the legislation breaches international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old actress, O'Donnell, stated she was "lucky to be here" after researching heart attack symptoms online (including sudden nausea and aches), taking aspirin, and visiting a cardiologist who inserted a stent for a 99% blocked artery. Symptoms began after helping a woman in Nyack, New York, with chest pain, nausea, and fever. In her blog poem "my heart attack," she identified the attack as the "widow maker," did not call 911 herself, but warned others to recognize symptoms and call 911. Her show, *The Rosie Show* on OWN, was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton. A 16-year-old was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police stated the party was well-run with adults present, and Che was not involved in an initial altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old was arrested for murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old was held for possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized cancer diagnosis for non-obvious cases after poor survival rates compared to Europe. Three routes were implemented: fast-track for alarm symptoms with strict time targets; diagnosis centers for unclear symptoms (addressing over 25% of cancer cases initially non-obvious); and "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms (detecting serious cases in 1% quickly). This improved survival rates, helping Denmark catch up with Nordic countries. Wales is considering adopting similar methods to enhance GP-specialist collaboration.

Powys has taken over the UK government's role in regulating estate agents following the OFT's disbandment, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders for dishonest practices or law breaches. Local authorities will refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is violated, with team leader James Munro expressing hope for future contracts.

NHS Employers approved a workforce reshaping plan based on a Nuffield Trust review, which found nurses and pharmacists filling roles of doctors and GPs. Unions warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS shortages, citing documented gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP patient pressures. The report highlighted the need for reshaping due to increased focus on long-term conditions, with doctors comprising only 10% of staff, requiring funding for training. MPs stated the NHS is short of front-line staff, and BMA and Unison emphasized that expanding roles must not compromise doctor training or serve as a cost-cutting measure.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the A36 at Rackfield Place outside the First depot in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, causing commuter and bus service disruptions during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing. First stated some services resumed but full normality would take hours, with management expecting full service by evening commute and thanking the public and staff.

NRW estimated the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21% annual salmon and 25% sea trout deaths during migration, which Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed as lacking scientific basis and claimed NRW did not share methodology; TLP's modeling suggested a worst-case 2% fish mortality. The £1.3bn project is a test for larger schemes, with the UK government reviewing its viability. Wales' Environment Secretary supports the project but seeks clarity on the UK government's position. NRW defended its figures, stating it shared data and methodology with TLP over 18 months, assessed by independent experts.

Stormont's DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of an industry-led agri-food marketing body, modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, to coordinate sector efforts. The agri-food industry supports nearly 100,000 jobs in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, citing its role in export-led growth and the need for better marketing coordination, but noted potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and stated she would discuss plans with the Agri-Food Strategy Board.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in Faughan Valley on Saturday, part of a four-year UK-wide project to plant millions of native trees commemorating WW1 casualties. Specifically, 40,000 trees will be planted there to honor the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. Volunteers are invited to plant saplings provided by the charity, advised to wear sturdy footwear. The site is seven miles outside Derry with limited parking, aiming to create a living memorial with wildflowers and wildlife habitat for reflection.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for *Someone Else's Skin*, a thriller addressing domestic violence and honor crime, featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Judges praised its emotional power, tight writing, and atmosphere. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for creating VI Warshawski, a pioneering female protagonist, and founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers. The awards were presented at the start of the Harrogate crime writing festival.

Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second Worcestershire game in 2016, a significant setback that hindered the team's qualification hopes. The left-arm batsman and spinner, who debuted in Tests in 2015, will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy to make up for lost time and contribute with bat and ball. Worcestershire also signed Australia's John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in Kiev in 2008 by a speeding car with stolen plates while hailing a taxi on a hard shoulder. A coroner ruled his death unlawful killing, citing inebriation and the vehicle not braking. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, married after a four-day engagement in 2007, was accused by family and a friend of orchestrating the incident to inherit his assets, having sold his car, moved funds, and having an affair. Ukrainian police reopened the case as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, requires urgent experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital as it is unavailable in the UK. After a third relapse in April left no UK treatment options and a previous transplant failed, an anonymous donor covered the costs. The family received hospital confirmation via email, enabling treatment to start soon, with the date expected next week. Parents expressed deep gratitude for the anonymous support.

Apple addressed security flaws exploited by third-party software (Elcomsoft) that stole celebrities' iCloud photos. It now applies two-step verification to backups, requiring a four-digit code for new devices and a 14-character recovery key, though the security measure remains opt-in. Experts confirmed the fix blocks Elcomsoft's tool but warned recovery keys are prone to loss or theft. Prof. Alan Woodward urged making two-factor authentication default, while Apple plans to encourage users to enable it and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves said the finer points of Wright's proposed 20% club purchase are undisclosed, though The Sun reported the 30-year-old will become a director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off spot. Wright, a 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, played non-league for Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who committed to investing £10,000 weekly, and signed 35-year-old former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United, must respond by 21 March to a request from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright to provide evidence on worker treatment following a BBC investigation. The Business, Innovation and Skills Committee, chaired by Wright, invited him to a public meeting but he has not accepted any proposed dates. Failure to comply may lead to contempt proceedings. Sports Direct has not commented, though it previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley's oversight.

An unfinished report by murdered politician Boris Nemtsov was completed by colleagues led by Ilya Yashin. Titled "Putin. War," it compiles existing media facts since Crimea's 2014 annexation to accuse Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. Despite Russia denying troop deployment, Yashin states Russian army units secured rebel victories, with soldiers admitting direct orders from Russian generals and receiving salaries up to $3,000 monthly. Russian spending is estimated at 53bn roubles. The report documents military units and weaponry but faces verification challenges and publishing obstacles due to fear among publishers. While some Russians acknowledge involvement but accept it as supporting independence, the opposition claims Putin used the conflict to boost popularity, though past similar reports failed to provoke protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones criticized the UK government for not sharing the Article 50 letter before publication or involving devolved administrations in drafting, calling it disrespectful. Alun Cairns stated discussions occurred over months and the government acts in the UK's interest, specifically mentioning Wales. The letter states consultation on which powers return to Westminster or devolve to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with an expectation of increased devolved decision-making, but specifics on powers (e.g., farming, economic aid) and funding are unclear. Jones fears no funding after 2020, while Labour pledges to maintain EU regional aid. Whitehall's concerns about EU spending in Wales may argue for Westminster control, but this is politically less likely now. Further details may emerge from the Great Repeal Bill white paper, but current power devolution plans remain uncertain.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry's Nursery Drive and Parkhead area on Friday night, during which PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community," and the PSNI appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and misuse of company funds. The board stated he would not return. His lawyer denied allegations, calling them false and accusing the company of privacy invasion and extortion. Court filings cited illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts in response to Charney's defamation lawsuit. American Apparel's papers claimed he violated harassment and anti-discrimination policies, with the board asserting he is unfit for any role. A restraining order prevents him from making negative statements or attempting to remove board members.

GB will face Greece at the Copper Box, with coverage on BBC iPlayer and BBC Sport website/app from 17:30-19:30 BST. Greece, European title contenders, defeated GB 92-64 in Patras earlier this month, but three of their players are missing this time, offering GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor highlighted the game's importance for EuroBasket preparation and excitement about playing in London. This is GB's only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, starting in September with a qualifier in Istanbul, followed by a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up.

The passage recounts the 2007 iPhone launch, where the author initially struggled to access the device but obtained it through an interview with Phil Schiller. Despite criticism of BBC's coverage, the author defended the reporting by comparing the iPhone to the Model T Ford, a comparison validated by the smartphone's transformative impact—putting powerful computers in two billion hands and disrupting industries. A photo comparison illustrates how the iPhone revolutionized mobile photography and sharing, with prior phones lacking user-friendly interfaces. Though initially skeptical of the hype, the author now recognizes the iPhone as the catalyst for the mobile connected era, with later innovations by Amazon and Google building on this foundation.

RSPCA confirmed multiple cats near Victor Avenue, Melton Mowbray, ingested antifreeze. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday after consuming it, with three other cats dying in the past week and another two weeks prior. Owner Adria Pearce described Meereen's symptoms and death. The RSPCA stated the cause of poisoning is unclear but urged safe storage of antifreeze to prevent leaks and spills.

Despite Syriza agreeing to new austerity measures, there are no protests in Athens, with tourism rising to 25 million arrivals. Greeks may not be demonstrating due to awaiting details of Tsipras's concessions for an €86bn bailout. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end austerity, while bank closures are causing credit shortages, threatening Christmas sales. The economic squeeze is worsening poverty, requiring debt relief of 30-50% for recovery, necessitating creditors avoid triumphalism and offer forgiveness.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for a brief role to reunite the Mitchell family as Barbara Windsor's character Peggy Mitchell, who returned after a 2010 absence, reveals her cancer has returned and will die in spring episodes. The storyline brings the Mitchell brothers together for their mother's final moments.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected him when police informed them of her death. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice to ignore Dhillon and dismissing her daughter Emma's warning that he would kill Alice. Prof Ruggles stated they did not realize the severity of the situation despite warning signs. The parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers and honor Alice's vibrant personality. Dhillon was convicted of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF approved £18bn funding for Hinkley Point, with Chinese investors covering a third of the cost. The UK government is reviewing the project, causing uncertainty. Critics cite environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign involvement. EDF faces financial strain, including €4bn share issuance and executive resignations. The project will supply 7% of UK electricity, involving 5,600 workers, 4,000km cabling, 230,000 tonnes of steel, and 5.6m cubic metres of earth moved. Environmental groups argue it is poor value and urge renewable energy investment.

The new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the third party in adultery cases, though the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to provide it. Family lawyers warn this increases conflict and complexity, as naming the third party makes them part of the court case, risking delays and additional costs. Despite guidance stating it is "not normally necessary," many petitioners may still include the name, which judges view negatively. In 2015, adultery accounted for 12,148 of over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales.

Ministers prioritize environmental concerns over timber production despite Britain being the third-largest wood importer. Confor reports 16,000 hectares of commercial forest lost since 2001, requiring replanting. The Welsh forestry industry, worth over £450m annually, faces conflict between environmental policies (promoting native species and public access) and commercial needs, with only 90 hectares planted last year against a target of 20,000. The government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social factors through schemes like Glastir and the Woodlands for Wales strategy, while industry representatives cite bureaucratic hurdles and high timber demand.

Police reported a boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews responded to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at 16:40; he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with a serious condition.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans. The Foreign Office initially blocked Russian honours due to rules against foreign medals awarded over five years ago. The Russian Embassy stated the convoys supplied the Soviet Union with weapons and ammunition critical for defeating Germany on the Eastern Front, with Churchill calling the missions "the worst journey on earth." Over 3,000 Allied seamen died, with 104 merchant and 16 military vessels lost. The UK created the Arctic Star in 2012, but campaigners sought the Russian medal. After an exception in 2013, President Putin presented the first medals. The Ushakov medal is awarded for courage in defending Russia.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in starting unpaid work sentences and leniency for non-attendance, with one offender completing only 16 hours over 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations. Community payback involves 40-300 hours for offenses like shoplifting, with 70,000 offenders in 2014. Inspectors identified challenges in organizing attendance due to offenders' chaotic lives and substance issues. While some high-quality work was noted, the chief inspector stated unpaid work was often viewed as mere punishment, a "wasted opportunity," requiring urgent action. The MoJ accepts all recommendations and is implementing changes to ensure attendance and consequences for non-compliance.

Russell Brand faces accusations of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic revolution while living in luxury. During a protest against evictions, he dismissed a journalist's question about his rent as "snide" and left. He did not reply to Newsbeat's inquiry about legal action against *The Sun* but tweeted using #TheSunLogic. Brand acknowledges his wealth and past mistakes but argues systemic change is essential to address inequality and ecological disaster, stating the hypocrisy accusation itself is part of the problem to resolve incrementally.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping through competition, drawing scientific criticism despite his non-modest claims and wealth (Lear Jets, yachts). His Vietnam service inspired urgency to become a doctor. At NIH, he pioneered RNA-based gene sequencing, founded The Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR), and published the first complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae in 1995. Founded Celera Genomics in 1998 to sequence the human genome in three years, publishing results in 2001. Established the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to create Synthia, the first synthetic life form, and conducted ocean expeditions to sequence marine microbes. He posits synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry and aid environmental efforts.

Four out of five children in England eating school lunches tried new foods at school not tried at home, with half of parents reporting their children requested those foods at home. A survey of 1,000 parents (628 with school lunch-eating children) found carrots, sweetcorn, and peas most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after Mumsnet suggested parents gave packed lunches due to perceived fussiness. Trust chairman Rob Rees noted school meals help children try new foods, and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton highlighted peer pressure and improved meal variety. School meals must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with 40% of primary school children in England eating them (slightly more than secondary), compared to 46% in Scotland. The survey was conducted online from February 26 to March 5 among parents of children aged 4-17.

Morata, a 6ft 3in striker aged 23, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons at Real Madrid, with a buy-back clause up to €30m. Previously linked to Arsenal and Chelsea, he scored three times for Spain at Euro 2016. At Juventus, he netted 27 goals in two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat to Barcelona in 2015. He debuted for Real at 18, scoring 10 goals for the club.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but was released in May and is currently without a team. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell after four prior seasons at the club and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco is selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy US chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles private equity firm run by Ron Burkle, in an orderly exit. Around 4,000 of 5,000 employees will transfer, with 50 stores closing. Tesco will provide an £80m loan as part of a £150m disposal cost, part of which may be repaid, and retains an option to buy a stake if profitable. This follows its first annual profit decline in 20 years.
He overcame racial abuse, explained his journey to BBC Sport's Nick Hope, briefly considered representing France, and is targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics; a martial arts guide is available.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, French Alps glaciers covered 375 sq km, decreasing to 275 sq km by the late 2000s—a 26% loss over 40 years. Research by Marie Gardent and colleagues used manual verification of satellite data to address debris cover and shadow issues. Southern sectors like Belledonne (nearly gone) and Ecrins (three times faster retreat than Mont Blanc) experienced greater losses due to lower elevation and climate differences, while northern areas, including La Mer de Glace (~30 sq km today), had slower retreat due to higher precipitation and cloud cover. Similar accelerating glacier loss was reported in Swiss Alps.

Scotland's women's team, having won all five qualifiers, face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium with victory nearly securing qualification. Player Evans, who missed previous play-offs for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, emphasizes avoiding further heartbreak. Iceland, ranked 20th and unbeaten in four games, are strong contenders, with the group's top spot hinging on Friday's match and a September return fixture. Scotland is in pole position for automatic qualification to the Netherlands finals. The squad includes 12 players abroad, with Evans highlighting benefits of international experience, including her Bundesliga win at Bayern Munich and interactions with stars like Ribery and Robben, noting improved competitiveness strengthens the national team.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London alleged harassment over two years. He was released on bail until mid-September and stated the claims relate solely to non-threatening tweets, which remain publicly visible, accusing media of spreading innuendo. A Metropolitan Police spokesman confirmed an investigation into online harassment following a report from a woman in her 30s. Campbell, a former games reviewer and Scottish independence campaigner who runs the Wings Over Scotland blog, said no further details would be provided.

PETA proposes replacing Skegness's Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-themed "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" slogan, citing animal cruelty concerns such as fish being impaled and crushed in nets. Skegness mayor Carl Macey stated the mascot is beloved and not perceived as cruel, saying "if it isn't broken we won't try and fix it," though the suggestion will be reviewed by the council. The original 1908 poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway for 12 guineas, featured "Skegness is so bracing."

Scotland defeated Georgia with six tries to two, dominating possession (91% in the first 30 minutes). After an early Georgian lead via Vasil Lobzhanidze, Scotland scored through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), and Hamish Watson. Georgia's second try came from a scrum, but Scotland's strategic play and counter-attacks secured the victory.

Widnes led 14-6 at half-time, extending to 38-12 with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in four minutes (Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Paddy Flynn's hat-trick), Widnes held on. Mellor's try gave a 26-point lead. Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh, while Castleford remained sixth, one point ahead, suffering their fourth consecutive home defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel determined he posed no continuing significant threat. Detained since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on al-Qaeda and Taliban links, which he denies, he challenged his detention in the Supreme Court. Boarding a Kuwaiti government plane, his lawyer stated there was "no bitterness, no anger" but "excitement and joy" at returning home. The Periodic Review Board concluded in July his detention was unnecessary. He must spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti rehabilitation center, as Kuwait advocated for his release. Al-Odah claimed he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide aid. His release reduces Guantanamo's inmate count to 148, following the May exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The facility opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, with President Obama vowing to close it.

PPAP, a viral song by fictional DJ Piko-Taro (played by Kazuhiko Kosaka), features repetitive lyrics about a pen, apple, and pineapple. It gained over 4 million YouTube views and 44 million Facebook views on 9GAG, with mixed reactions—some users found it addictive while others called it irritating. Dubbed the next Psy, the song became a global phenomenon through digital influencers and inspired numerous covers and tributes globally, though it received little coverage in mainstream Japanese media.

Thousands attended Anzac Day dawn services at Hyde Park Corner and a parade with up to 400 participants before Cenotaph wreath-laying. The day commemorates the first major WWI battle of Australian and New Zealand forces. Services included Westminster Abbey, first held in the capital in 1916 with King George V. National anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK were sung. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer spoke of Gallipoli landings and troops' courage. Veterans, families, and expatriates participated with schoolchildren's prayers. The Gallipoli campaign was an eight-month bloody conflict where Allied forces aimed to oust the Ottoman Empire from the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and could make his St Mirren debut against Alloa in the Championship. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been mainly a substitute this term, stating he is fit and ready after playing for the U20s. With two Scotland caps and nearly 400 senior appearances, including stints at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, he aims to help St Mirren climb the table from eighth place, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan, with Unite confirming current pension agreements—including the closed 2004 final salary scheme and alternative scheme—remain unaffected. Boparan stated pension continuity and plans to restore profitability through investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity for chicken processing.

The council announced free Cowes crossings until July 2, ordered an audit, and described the ferry's start as "frustrating and disappointing" due to breakdowns, grounding, Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspension over training issues, and vehicle damage during boarding. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about business survival from six months of lost trade and requested compensation for businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated compensation is under discussion, the ferry is a prototype with resolved electrical problems, ramp extensions to prevent scraping, and groundings resolved via seamanship improvements.

The UK fishing industry, which contributes 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, voted heavily to leave the EU, seeking to regain control of its waters. A House of Lords report warns the sector must not be marginalized in Brexit talks despite its small economic role. Shared fish stocks with EU states and reliance on EU markets for exports (and imports) mean continued market access is critical, potentially requiring trade-offs like allowing EU vessels into UK waters. The report highlights risks of fragmented fisheries management across UK nations but notes industry optimism about post-Brexit control over the 200-mile zone, fairer quotas, and sustainable management. Recent EU quota agreements for key species are seen positively, and the government aims to ensure trade freedom while reviewing fisheries for sustainability.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses (with no sexual activity) between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and was removed from the teaching register after a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher. The panel cited the prolonged nature of the offense, volume of images, lack of remedial action, and high recurrence risk. Prohibited from re-registering for two years, he was 69 and absent during the hearing.

A fire on March 2 at Duncan Street reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency revoked Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's environmental permit effective August 7, suspending waste acceptance, after the fire service raised concerns about fire risks to residents, transport, and the environment. The site operator, Asset and Land Group, was deemed broadly compliant with fire safety laws, but the company must remove all waste and can appeal the decision. The fire's cause remains undetermined.

Syria missed the chemical weapons destruction deadline, with a second shipment attacked en route. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad denied using barrel bombs in Aleppo despite Syrian Observatory reports of 246 killed (73 children), accusing the US of supporting terrorists. Conflicting accounts exist over Aleppo prison control. Syria has 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons; only 4% (30 tonnes) removed. US expressed concern, Russia set a March 1 transfer deadline, and OPCW cited security delays. Mekdad affirmed Syria's commitment to agreements.

England secured a dominant victory at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root was man of the match with 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, alongside four catches and a wicket. Alastair Cook and Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s improved performance, while Misbah-ul-Haq admitted Pakistan’s disappointment and lack of confidence after collapsing to 198 and 234. Geoffrey Boycott stated England would likely win again, though Vaughan suggested the series might remain tight. The third Test begins August 3 at Edgbaston after a two-day tour game against Worcestershire.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is reviewing residential care quality by gathering evidence from older people, families, and friends to develop recommendations. She assesses health, social relationships, and care environment, noting both positive care and unacceptable variations. Her team will consult care providers, staff, and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but criticizes the exclusion of care home providers (those who lived in, worked in, managed, or owned care homes) from the advisory panel, stating this misses partnership opportunities.

Paul Sheerin, 39, former Aberdeen midfielder and Arbroath player-manager since 2010, replaces Neil Cooper at Aberdeen. Aberdeen CEO Duncan Fraser stated manager Derek McInnes selected him after a comprehensive process. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two in 2013-14. Sheerin, who played for multiple Scottish clubs and Sweden's Östersunds, earned a Scotland U21 cap in the 1990s and led Arbroath to their first national trophy with a Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match after Bob Bradley's sacking, with Swansea seeking a new permanent manager, prioritizing Paul Clement. Curtis emphasizes the need for someone to "get us out of trouble," noting the Championship's increased strength and difficulty in returning if relegated, citing Newcastle, Norwich, and Burnley as examples. Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy in 2003 to 2011 Premier League promotion is highlighted. Curtis states the club has "lost its way" since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure, with diluted "Swansea Way" and uncertain player replacements, but believes the current squad can stay up. He reminds new signings of the club's history via the documentary *Jack to a King*, stressing its importance to the club and local area.

Dr. Craig Venter, a controversial biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping through competition with public efforts, drawing criticism for his methods and lack of open data sharing.
