His Vietnam service inspired urgency, leading to RNA-based sequencing breakthroughs, founding Celera Genomics, and sequencing the first free-living organism's genome. He later created Synthia, the first synthetic life form, and conducted oceanic genetic research. Funded independently due to financial rewards, he envisions synthetic microbes revolutionizing industry and aiding environmental solutions like carbon capture.

The Sutton Trust warns that UK apprenticeships are often low quality and short compared to European peers, with only 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts in England at level three (A-level equivalent). England has 20% of employers offering apprenticeships versus 51% in Germany, which has 570,000 new starts for young people (90% A-level equivalent) versus England's 61,000. Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships were below level three and 75% targeted those over 25, with 11 young people competing for each position. The report calls for expanding to 300,000 new apprenticeships yearly, prioritizing level three or higher for 3-4 years, with no more than 10% at level two. The Department for Education states reforms are underway to raise standards, while the Association of Colleges notes challenges in meeting targets but supports preserving respected level two roles like construction.

Storey, a British athlete, finished over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race. The 37-year-old, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across six Paralympics, has four golds from London 2012 and 21 world titles. She began in swimming, earning six medals in 1992, before switching to cycling in 2005 while targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Rio Games.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference Premier after failing to meet financial deadlines for £148,000 owed to creditors, including players and staff. Despite multiple deadline extensions, they could not pay. Chester was reinstated as Conference Premier club, taking Hereford's place. Total debts reached £225,000, with £70,000 still owed to HMRC. Attendance dropped from 3,270 to 1,758, and fan fundraising efforts failed to resolve the crisis.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 England caps since his 2009 senior debut. He was part of two World Cup and two European Championship squads but played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most England U21 caps (46), debuting in 2004, and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 2014 World Cup qualifier win against Moldova. He stated, "The decision we've reached is about common sense. I wish Sam [Allardyce], the players, staff and supporters success in the future."

Christopher Hogwood died in Cambridge after a months-long illness, with a private funeral and memorial service planned. A leading exponent of the early-music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 Handel's Messiah recording. Educated at Cambridge and with prominent musicians, he held roles with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, Early Music Consort of London, King's Lynn Festival, Handel and Haydn Society, and academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, mentorship of top musicians, academic expertise, and dedication to historically informed performance.

An unnamed Northern Ireland boy's mother quit her job to care for him after he was removed from mainstream school in June due to struggling. The family is waiting for a special school place, but all in the South Eastern Education Board area are full with no timeline. The mother says he feels isolated, though a new classroom assistant may allow enrollment soon. She warns of systemic capacity issues. The Education Authority declined to comment on the case due to privacy but stated it is reviewing special school needs to ensure local placements by 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has proposed a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons, aiming to use Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County Football Club holds a lease until 2023 with fixture priority if in the Football League, with Foxall stating the contract must be honored. A shareholder vote on the WRU bid is set for May 9. The WRU's plan for an artificial pitch conflicts with Football League rules. County is two points clear of relegation in League Two, needing a win and Hartlepool's loss to survive, with Foxall calling relegation "devastating" for the city and fans. Newport RFC chairman Godfrey confirmed County and the Squash Club are protected under current agreements, which the WRU is aware of.

Sierra Leone was declared Ebola-free after nearly 4,000 deaths over 18 months. A survivor of the civil war, kidnapped by RUF rebels at 15, forced to commit atrocities, branded, and drugged, later escaped and was rehabilitated through the Lifeline Nehemiah project. During the 2014 Ebola outbreak, the individual helped educate over 10,000 people, provide food aid to 11,000, and establish treatment units with community support, saving lives. Now focused on investing in youth for national and global change.

About 80,000 art pieces faced auction to settle pension debt, but a public campaign led by the Art Fund met its target in a month. The collection will remain at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, via a gift to the Victoria and Albert Museum and subsequent loan. Administrators credited collaborative efforts for the outcome. The debt originated from Waterford Wedgwood's 2009 collapse, with the museum entering administration in 2010 and a 2011 court ruling allowing sale to the Pension Protection Fund. Stakeholders emphasized the collection's cultural significance and risk of global dispersal without intervention.

Dan Groves stated the 'finer points' of Wright's potential 20% stake purchase are undisclosed, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off spot. Wright, the 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, previously played non-league football for Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who committed to investing £10,000 weekly, and signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mark Carney announced a one-year extension of his term as Bank of England Governor, rejecting the options of staying until 2021 or leaving in 2018 as originally planned. He cited purely personal reasons, specifically his family's need to return to Canada when his daughters complete their education milestones in 2018. He emphasized the decision was unrelated to government policy or political pressure, and the extension ensures the Article 50 Brexit process concludes before a new governor takes over.

Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalized via Kurtis Guthrie from a corner. Sam Slocombe made key saves, including denying George Elokobi before halftime and Guthrie hitting the bar. Blackpool missed a chance when Tom Aldred headed wide. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time, resulting in a 1-1 draw.

The Healthy Me programme by Action Mental Health targets P6 and P7 children in Northern Ireland to address stress from the transfer test and transition to secondary school. After a pilot in five schools, it aims for statewide rollout. Workshops focus on emotional wellbeing, seeking help, identifying support sources, and teacher training. Launched at Carrick Primary School, the initiative addresses anxiety among pupils and parents about the school transition, with teacher Helen Hamilton noting the shift from primary to secondary environments. Transfer test entrants rose to 14,681 this year. Action Mental Health's David Babington emphasized coping strategies for mental health, including breathing exercises. Chief inspector Noelle Buick highlighted strengthening resilience as a key challenge due to changing social contexts, requiring preventative education in pastoral care.

The disused Fawley Power Station chimney will be the centrepiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside, set to be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. The project includes a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 2,000 MW oil-fired station, commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013, powered one million homes, had a 198m chimney, and was fuelled by the nearby Esso refinery. The 300-acre site was sold in 2016, with planning permission due later this year and construction starting in 2018. Developers state retaining the existing chimney is more cost-effective than building new structures like Brighton's i360 or Portsmouth's Spinnaker Tower.

GB's 23-year-old Latham won bronze in the men's scratch event, securing GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver. GB's men's team pursuit missed bronze to Italy. Chris Boardman and Chris Hoy praised Latham's strategic ride. The women's team pursuit finished fifth with a young squad, expressing optimism for future improvement. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the women's sprint first round but will compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin.

Ross Kemp is making a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Peggy Mitchell (Windsor's character) returned after a 2010 absence to reveal her cancer has recurred and will die in spring. Kemp's return reunites the Mitchell brothers (Grant and Phil) for their mother's last moments, as highlighted by executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as second-placed Spurs lost at Anfield. Pochettino criticized their lack of desire and poor start, stating it hinders Premier League challenges, and warned a 12-point lead for Chelsea would be problematic. Spurs have only two away wins since September 24, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United and draws at Arsenal and Manchester City. In 17 away games against top-six teams, they've won once. Danny Murphy highlighted defensive issues, inconsistent formation (back four vs three), lack of pace, and need for improvement.

APC won 19 of 28 governor posts, marking the PDP's biggest defeat since 1999. The PDP lost the presidential election to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, set for inauguration on May 29. PDP lost key northern states (Katsina, Kaduna, Adamawa) but retained Rivers and secured eight governorships in the southeast. Taraba's result is pending, Imo's election was inconclusive, and seven states did not hold elections. APC did not win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, posing concerns for Buhari's revenue and security. Elections had 66 violent incidents, mostly in southern states, but were more peaceful overall. APC retained Lagos for the first time since 1999. The PDP faces introspection due to defections, corruption allegations, and failure to address the northern insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) takes place from July 19-22 in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, featuring acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. An augmented reality app allows visitors to access videos, band interviews, and other online content via signs and posters, with real-time updates for information, ticket purchases, and global access to the festival atmosphere, as stated by HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, have had their funding agreements terminated. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned of termination unless breaches are addressed. Ofsted reports cited failures including inadequate safeguarding, unvetted speakers with extremist views, segregation of boys and girls, and failure to promote spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. Park View challenged the Ofsted report legally. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw described a "culture of fear and intimidation" and an organized campaign to impose a narrow faith-based ideology. Parents accused Ofsted of bias, claiming inspectors used loaded questions. Birmingham City Council is working with Saltley School (in special measures) to install a temporary governing board.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years for allegedly plotting to overthrow Iran's government, with undisclosed charges. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticized UK inaction, stating his wife is a diplomatic bargaining chip, and noted the secret appeal in Tehran on Wednesday, which the family cannot attend, with an unpredictable outcome. She has been in solitary confinement since April's arrest, experiencing suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike but showing more resilience after moving out of solitary over Christmas. Her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with grandparents after passport confiscation, having lost English fluency and now speaking Farsi, with communication via Skype and physical play. Ratcliffe is seeking a visa to visit, and Amnesty International considers her a prisoner of conscience held for exercising freedom of expression and association, hoping for release.

Vincent Barker (Vinnie) died in July 2012 five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Prosecution alleges optometrist Honey Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs, leading to fatal brain fluid buildup and death, and her conduct was criminally negligent. She denies gross negligence manslaughter; trial ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse between September 2013 and September 2014, causing her sister and father to view sexual images, and behaving threateningly on December 25, 2014. He set up meetings via an adult website, filmed the encounters, and sent an explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. The woman testified she felt "blackmailed." Placed on the sex offenders register, his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. The judge stated the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence, noting Weatherhogg, a first offender, posed a moderate re-offending risk. His defense counsel described his remand as a "dramatic shock."

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida (Stuart Thompson 56, Gary Wilson 41*, William Porterfield 39), but Afghanistan chased 171-4 (Samiullah Shenwari 56, Mohammad Shahzad 47) with two overs remaining. The teams meet again Friday. Ireland lost Paul Stirling for a duck early; Thompson and Porterfield steadied the innings. Afghanistan’s Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai added 51 for the opening stand. Amir Hamza took 2-23 as batting dominated. Porterfield noted Ireland fell short of 180 and bowling issues, while Boyd Rankin is sidelined for T20s due to a back injury but expected for ODIs starting March 15.

Barcelona denies wrongdoing in Neymar's transfer, stating the aim was to cover contract interpretations. The total cost, including initial fee, wages, agents' fees, and tax payments, amounts to £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid money misappropriation accusations, which he denies. A Spanish judge ruled sufficient evidence exists to continue investigations. The club made a supplementary tax payment of €13.55m while maintaining the original payment was correct. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league matches and three in seven Champions League games this season.

David Miller (24) and Hannah Witheridge (23) were found dead on Koh Tao beach on September 15. UK Metropolitan Police worked with Thai authorities, completing their review to compile a report and update the families. Suspects Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (21, Myanmar migrants) face charges of conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, with possible death penalty; Thai police deny claims they retracted confessions. The UK Foreign Office raised concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment. A UK police delegation was sent after Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha met UK Prime Minister Cameron in Italy, following prior rejection of assistance. Post-mortem results showed Miller died from drowning and head injury, Witheridge from head wounds, with suspect DNA matching hers.

VR is applied across sectors to enhance understanding: National Autistic Society's film addresses autism awareness gaps (99% aware, 16% understand) and public exclusion issues; Alzheimer's Research UK simulates dementia challenges. Retailers like Ikea use VR for kitchens, including virtual meatballs, with high demand. Healthcare employs VR for surgical training, PTSD therapy, and phobia treatment, with 83% improvement in spider phobia studies. Google Expeditions offers virtual school trips, while language apps and engagement-monitoring tools are being tested, though schools face cost and hardware challenges.

The Su-24 jet's black box was opened in Moscow with missing flight data; analysis expected next week. The downing by Turkish F-16s on November 24 caused a Russia-Turkey crisis. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings in its airspace, while Russia asserts it was shot down in Syrian airspace. Putin accused Turkey of US subservience and "creeping Islamisation." Both crew ejected; pilot killed by militants, navigator rescued. A Russian marine and helicopter were lost during rescue. Russia demanded an apology and imposed sanctions, including a package holiday ban costing Turkey billions.

Scotland's women's team have won all five qualifiers and host Iceland, with victory likely securing their place at the Netherlands finals. Evans, recalling past play-off failures for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, says missing out now would be devastating. Iceland, ranked 20th and unbeaten, are key opponents. Scotland are in pole position to qualify automatically. Evans highlights the benefits of 12 squad members playing abroad in top leagues, enhancing the national team's competitiveness.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no "magic bullet" to fix council tax defects inherent from the start. Property tax, used by most OECD countries, is stable and hard to avoid but causes confusion and perceived unfairness due to not linking to income. Local income tax is fairer but creates income fluctuations and limits local rate adjustments. Reform is difficult due to past experiences. The commission will conduct public consultation before its autumn report, with the Scottish government acknowledging the current system's unfairness.

Apple enhanced iCloud security after third-party software stole celebrities' photos. The new two-factor authentication blocks Elcomsoft's tool by requiring verification for backups, which previously allowed unauthorized access. Users must enter a code for new devices and keep a recovery key, though concerns exist about losing it. Experts recommend making two-factor authentication default, and Apple plans to encourage users to enable it and use stronger passwords.

UKIP won the election with £2.96m spending (68p per vote), Conservatives spent £2.98m (79p), Lib Dems spent £1.58m (£1.45 per vote) losing all but one MEP, Labour came second spending £1.03m (26p), Greens spent £534k (43p), and SNP £267k. Total spending by six parties was £9.35m, with all except Labour exceeding 2009 levels.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival, possibly facing them on February 18. He previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, joined the Gulls after a recommendation from Micky Adams, with prior spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson stated Anderson is a leader despite limited game time and Keating is young but hungry. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone with one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, died after collapsing following his victory in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed a severe pulmonary haemorrhage as the cause, noting such incidents are rare even in horses without underlying health issues. Though he had previously experienced post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he showed no symptoms on race day. Trained by Oliver Sherwood, he had won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup and was described as the "horse of a lifetime."

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was emotional during farewell speeches by departing MSPs Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond ahead of the May 5 election. Salmond, former first minister (2007-2014), stated Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" with consensus for greater parliamentary responsibility, but the Scotland Bill did not fulfill unionist referendum pledges. He joked about the UK budget and Cheltenham racecourse, concluding by praising the honor of serving in parliament. McNeil warned Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system for accountability and scrutiny, referencing Robin Cook's prior interest. Annabel Goldie joked about missing John Swinney's "faux indignation."

The live-action Beauty and the Beast features Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and a star as Mrs. Potts. Directed by Bill Condon, it releases March 17, 2017, and begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST regarding the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 fans died. New inquests concluded the deaths were unlawful. Evidence from 23 suspects (15 related to Operation Resolve's investigation into the disaster causes, 8 to police conduct probes) was referred to the CPS. Sue Hemming, CPS head of special crime, will inform relatives in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group stated the families seek accountability after a long struggle, with mixed emotions expected.

Chelmsford Prison reported numerous incidents of packages being hurled over the wall, with a former inmate stating the jail is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged staff efforts but stated more action is needed, citing the Justice Secretary's review of tools to tackle the issue. A nearby resident witnessed four such incidents in two weeks and mentioned the prison is holding a meeting for residents. The MoJ denied evidence of drone use despite claims, and noted new laws allow up to two years in jail for smuggling contraband over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright admitted hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall the traffic light color. Mrs. Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, was escorting a woman and child across the road when traffic in the opposite direction had stopped, but Wright’s VW Golf failed to stop. He expressed remorse, stating he has thought of her and her family since the incident. The judge paused the trial briefly for Wright to compose himself, and proceedings continue.

Muir, 24, will miss the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to veterinary studies conflicting with the April event, returning to university for her final year with exams in May. She placed fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new 5000m personal best of 14:52.07, where Hellen Obiri won gold, defeating Almaz Ayana with Sifan Hassan third. Despite disappointment at missing the Commonwealths, she prioritized her degree, stated potential for multiple future Olympics, and aims for the World Indoor Championships in March and Birmingham races, expressing satisfaction with her performance despite running five races in ten days.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after a Christmas party. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving three acres of Woodlands by the R112 and River Liffey, began Saturday with excavations expected to last weeks. Detectives reviewed the case this year, enhancing CCTV footage showing him talking to a man in black outside Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street (where he worked) before returning for an umbrella. The same man was seen following him on Haddington Road; he remains unidentified, and authorities have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro, a former US Open champion and world number four, defeated Stan Wawrinka in four sets despite being ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injuries and three wrist surgeries. He next faces Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios came from two sets to one down to beat Dustin Brown and will play Feliciano Lopez, who recovered from two sets behind to defeat Fabio Fognini. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to CAF over complaints about a disputed penalty incident in the 2015 Nations Cup quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, clarifying they did not accuse CAF or the referee of corruption but criticized referee selection. Morocco's ban from the 2017 qualifiers was overturned by CAS, reducing their fine from $1m to $50,000 after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns. Both nations will participate in the 2017 AFCON, with Tunisia in Group A (vs Togo, Liberia, Djibouti) and Morocco in Group F (vs Cape Verde, Libya, Sao Tome), while Tunisia aims for a record 13th consecutive appearance.

McLaren, with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' titles, and eight constructors' championships, currently struggles, qualifying in the fourth grid row. After a 2013 chassis slump, Honda power-unit issues now hinder their strong car. Historical highs include 1988 dominance with Senna and Prost (15/16 wins) and 1998-99 Mercedes era (last constructors' title in 1998). Scandals in 2007 (disqualification for Ferrari data theft) and 2009 ('lie-gate') compounded issues. Ron Dennis asserts recovery is imminent, with Alonso returning in 2015 to aid this, though current success depends on belief.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found patrons present, with till receipts confirming alcohol served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill (43), the license holder, faced two charges for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours; James Thomas (44) faced one charge. The defense noted lax adherence to licensing laws, but the judge described O'Neill’s record as "appalling" and stated he could not impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record with eight made shots, finishing with 45 points as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Klay Thompson added 26 points. Portland's LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 and Damian Lillard added 20, though they had already secured the Northwest division. Separately, the Chicago Bulls beat the Miami Heat 89-78 after trailing by 19 at halftime, outscoring them 57-27 in the second half. Miami missed their first 12 shots after halftime. Pau Gasol (16 points, 15 rebounds) and Derrick Rose (12 points) led Chicago, which moved into third place in the Eastern Conference. Miami's Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade shot 4-of-20.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic met YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood, initially believing he was a competition winner for a free-kick session. However, van Velzen demonstrated his skills, surprising the team. He described the experience as amazing, enjoyed pretending not to be good at free-kicks, and revealed Balotelli's infamous slogan from his 2011 Manchester City t-shirt.

A study in JAMA Oncology found BRCA1 mutation carriers diagnosed with breast cancer who underwent oophorectomy reduced breast cancer death risk by 62% and all-cause mortality by 65%, with a 73% reduction if surgery occurred within two years of diagnosis. The protective effect lasted 15 years, but no significant benefit was seen in BRCA2 carriers. Researchers recommend oophorectomy be discussed as part of treatment for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer, citing Angelina Jolie's case as an example.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed when struck by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 a.m. on Train No. 80 (Carolinian) traveling from Charlotte to New York City. Authorities confirmed no injuries among the 166 passengers, though one man fell ill during the approximately two-hour and 45-minute delay and received treatment. Witnesses suggested the couple may have been homeless, living in a camp near the tracks.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellín Cartel member who served 27 years as a DEA undercover informant in exchange for U.S. citizenship, now faces deportation after the agency failed to honor its promise. He aided in prosecuting Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega but remains in the U.S. illegally following his visa expiration in January. Toro states he would be killed within hours if deported, and the DEA has refused to assist his status, preventing him from collecting Social Security. A former colleague recently provided $5,000 after the DEA declined help.

Vox Populi Registry Ltd. uses the '.sucks' domain to extract high fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Visa, and Bank of America seeking reputation protection. ICANN is investigating potential illegality after industry groups labeled it a "shakedown scheme," with the company charging $2,499 annually. Kevin Spacey reportedly paid to have his domain removed.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. DNA from the exhumed remains identified her; she admitted to a stillbirth and concealed pregnancy. Infanticide charges were dropped, but she may face charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied as "Peter" with a new headstone funded by a support group, and police confirmed no foul play.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks after Hicks suffered severe brain injuries when jumping from the moving taxi. Young mistakenly believed Hicks would not pay the fare and drove him back to the rank, leading Hicks to jump at over 20mph. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care due to brain damage, epilepsy, and other impairments. The court ruled unlawful imprisonment, with compensation set at approximately 50% of the family’s requested hundreds of thousands of pounds, plus £250. Both parties may appeal the ruling.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms brought multiple tornado reports, including one 6 miles northwest of Goddard that moved northeast away from Wichita but threatened other areas. CNN expert Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. In Missouri, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, and roof damage, with baseball-sized hail reported in Farmington. More storms are expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold faces Lyoto Machida in New Jersey this Saturday, with both aiming for a title shot. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive win since a 2015 loss to Vitor Belfort, plans to dominate by cutting off Machida's movement, leveraging his mixed martial arts skills, and exploiting perceived weaknesses, noting Machida has limited options on the feet and ground. Machida, coming off a victory over C.B. Dollaway, expresses confidence in his strategy and training, stating the winner deserves a title shot and acknowledging Rockhold's strengths while highlighting his own preparation. Both fighters respect each other but are focused on securing victory.

A light general aviation Aerostar aircraft landed without landing gear in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding on its belly. Pilot Chris Georgaklis, 85, with 50 years of flying experience and his dog Buddy, later flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The incident, captured on video, showed propellers impacting the runway before the pilot re-engaged engines and took off. The FAA is investigating, with human error or mechanical failure cited as common causes.

Manuel Pellegrini admitted disappointment in Yaya Touré's performance but pledged support until season's end. Manchester City are open to offers for Touré as part of squad overhaul. Touré, on a £220,000 weekly contract for two more years, faces criticism amid City's faltering campaign (18 points from 39). Vincent Kompany may miss the rest of the season. Joe Hart stated players must take responsibility, with the dressing room backing Pellegrini. Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against joining City, citing Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair's limited playing time.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his extradition was halted because his seven-year Italian sentence expired under Italian law, which extinguishes sentences after more than double the penalty period. His case expired in October 2014, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. The Crown Prosecution Service admitted a procedural error in 2014 that delayed proceedings, allowing the sentence to expire. Italian court of appeal confirmed the conviction's extinction, and the matter will now be discharged once paperwork is finalized.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is a 7-2 co-favourite alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown. AP McCoy will ride Mr. Mole in his final Grade One race, with his final day's schedule pending until Friday. His retirement announcement followed a victory with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter Marcia was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was found 33 days later in a garage with severe injuries, including vomit, pulled-out hair, blood on her scalp, and scattered cookies. Ritter, advised by her then-husband not to see the crime scene photos, viewed them for the first time last year after decades of avoidance, expressing regret and stating she wants revenge. Barrett was convicted in 2009 of second-degree murder after DNA evidence linked him to the case following his arrest for another 1975 murder; he received a 44-year sentence. The case remained unsolved for 33 years, with a prior suspect charged in 1979 but charges dropped due to insufficient evidence.

Rory McIlroy states it is "unthinkable" he will not win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, calling his 2011 collapse the most important day of his career. He aims to become the sixth player to win all four majors, with one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances (joint eighth last year). Despite personal distractions like canceling his wedding and legal disputes, he uses golf as a sanctuary, focusing on playing well rather than the outcome.

Four rainbows appeared over New York after rain, photographed by Amanda Curtis; China cracking down on exotic dancers at wakes; RDJ agitated during UK Channel 4 interview; lip plumping trend via jar-sucking (#kyliejennerchallenge); 102-year-old Alice Barker's time travel project; prom-posal referencing bombs rejected by school with racism accusations; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp nearly unrecognizable in Black Mass trailer; pregnancy announcement referencing Fresh Prince of Bel-Air; military dad photobombs son.

272 children were hospitalized in England last year due to fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), with experts stating the true number affected is higher and the condition is vastly under-diagnosed. WHO estimates at least 1 in 100 UK babies (7,500 annually) suffer learning, behavioral, and physical issues from prenatal alcohol exposure. A case study of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, diagnosed at age five, shows lifelong challenges. Medical complications include liver, kidney, heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current UK advice permits up to two alcohol units twice weekly during pregnancy, but advocates recommend complete abstinence.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, nicknamed "boomerang boy" for returning home after crimes, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a Shildon store on March 15. Masked and wielding an axe, he was tackled by owner Sab Dhillon and struck twice with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam, leading to his arrest. McKerry, with a history of over 80 arrests by age 15 and convictions for burglary and other offenses, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault following an alcohol-fuelled party at a Canadian barracks must remain in Nova Scotia until trial. Bail conditions require each to pay £2,000, surrender passports, reside at Stadacona naval base, and continue Royal Navy employment. The alleged incident occurred on April 10 after a hockey game at Shearwater base; the victim is an early 20s Halifax resident. Charges carry a maximum 14-year sentence, with possible additional charges pending forensic tests. They are prohibited from contacting the victim or six witnesses, leaving Nova Scotia, obtaining new passports, or resigning from the Navy without court approval. Canadian authorities described the allegations as "disturbing," and the British High Commission is assisting the investigation.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son RJ has Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin condition affecting only 70 people worldwide, causing red, inflamed, scaly skin. A stranger reported her for child abuse after mistaking his symptoms for burns, resulting in armed police being called during a shopping trip. She faces public ignorance, including bullying, denial of entry to facilities like play centers, and accusatory comments. There is no cure, but symptoms may improve with age, and she manages his condition with frequent cream applications. She discovered the diagnosis through online support groups after initial confusion following his birth.

Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts were removed by Transport for London (TFL) after their scheduled three-week advertising period ended. The campaign faced backlash including a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), social media criticism, and defaced posters. TFL stated removal was not due to complaints but part of the scheduled end, though they would consider public reaction for future similar ads. Protein World defended the campaign as unphotoshopped, reported bomb threats to police, and said they would not change advertising methods. ASA is assessing complaints, protein powder sales continue to rise, and supporters like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick endorsed the adverts.

Rail firms announced fare hikes up to 87% just ten days after the general election despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron urged First Great Western (FGW) to review increases on the London-Cotswolds route, where a Charlbury to London off-peak return will rise from £33.30 to £62.40 (87%) from May 17. Other increases include London Midlands' Crewe-Northampton first-class single from £30 to £37, Virgin's Stafford-Liverpool anytime return up 24.5%, and Manchester-Stoke first-class day return up 22%. FGW stated the changes align with other services and offer advance tickets at lower prices. Virgin said most hikes affect their own fares, which are cheaper than rivals, with a 1.65% overall West Coast increase. Trainsplit.com noted passenger surprise as parties promised freezes, with some tickets rising 40% in January.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown through his front door in Oldham when he confronted individuals pelting his property with stones. The attack occurred on April 18 while he and his wife Elaine, 54, were writing wedding thank-you cards three weeks after their marriage. Police state no motive is known, suggesting the offenders may have been "messing around," but the incident caused permanent disability. The couple has relocated to Southport due to safety concerns.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, signed a one-year contract extension following his return from injury. He missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father, Keith, in April, requiring ankle surgery. He made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi and will be available for the new season, committed until the end of 2016. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised his character, work ethic, and form, expressing hope the contract will boost his confidence this summer.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, diagnosed with neuroblastoma—a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 UK children annually—with tumors in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been declared cancer-free after intensive treatment including chemotherapy, surgery, stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. His decorated Ninja Turtle mask during radiotherapy drew global attention and Nickelodeon sent him presents. Now recovering, he hopes to return to school, with his family supporting Cancer Research UK's child cancer campaign.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his Aston Villa career over international decisions, as he is contested by England and the Republic of Ireland. Sherwood emphasizes Grealish must continue impressing for Villa to earn the right to choose, citing his FA Cup semi-final performance. His father supports this, stating club football should come first before international commitments. Sherwood referenced Nabil Bentaleb's choice to play for Algeria, advising Grealish to follow his heart but focus on Villa first.

Private jet landing fees vary significantly, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo charging the highest at £4,559 for a 767-400 jet. The top three airports for landing fees are all in Japan (Haneda, Narita, Kansai), followed by Toronto, Darwin, Bristol (only UK in top 10), Chubu Centrair, Dublin, La Guardia (only US in top 10), and Salzburg. In 2013, the US had 2.5 million private flights and Europe 705,000, with market values of $16.7 trillion and $15.8 trillion respectively. Peak demand occurs during events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with flights such as New York to Glendale costing up to $54,000 round-trip. Landing fees at these top airports exceed costs of popular routes like Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) or Milan to Rome ($5,880 one-way).

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs Cooper (a Labrador) and Daisy to McDonald's for ice cream; Cooper gobbled the cone in one bite while Daisy licked slowly. The viral video, with over seven million views, drew criticism for feeding ice cream, but Gallegos defended it, citing Cooper's health as an athlete and her previous dog's weekly ice cream until age 19, with Daisy receiving minimal portions due to size. Another video shows them at Starbucks for pupuccinos (whipped cream only), which Cooper consumed rapidly.

Gary Locke has been appointed Kilmarnock's permanent manager on a three-year deal. The former Hearts boss joined as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and took over in February when Johnston quit. The 41-year-old has lost only once in seven games since taking charge and will speak at a press conference on Friday. He signed the deal with chairman Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp of Eustis, claims Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for wearing Doterra essential oils applied to his head and neck to help him stay calm. Teachers cited the scent as a distraction, prompting a school board letter stating the oils caused a problem. Kemp argues against the policy, questioning why natural oils are prohibited when chemicals are allowed. Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend the child, calling it a health issue. The oils used include lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A Sandpiper complex beachfront apartment building in Westhampton Beach was obliterated by fire on Wednesday at 3 PM, collapsing after flames spread through 90 condos. The cause is under investigation, with claims it started near a parked car. Intense heat melted paint on nearby buildings, and smoke was visible three miles away. Firefighters used cranes but could not enter, resulting in total loss for residents and the building manager. The complex operates seasonally from May to November.

The Queen, aged 88, rode her fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park without a helmet, wearing a silk scarf due to her hair. She has ridden since age four, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy, and continues breeding fell and highland ponies despite a knee injury reducing her riding. Fell ponies, an ancient breed dating to Neolithic times, were historically used for transport and trade and became popular riding ponies in the 1950s.

A Brisbane neighbor dispute over noise resulted in Leon Yeaman's death and Phillip Pama's manslaughter charge. Yeaman, 55, was making noise when Pama, 28, a married father of three working a night shift, confronted him. Pama's defense stated Yeaman was known for drunkenness, loud music, and yelling. During the altercation, Pama allegedly punched Yeaman blindly while being pushed, causing fatal injuries. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Neighbors described him as "king and generous," while a friend noted he was a schizophrenic pensioner. Pama, with no prior violence, was granted bail with conditions including passport surrender, curfew, and police check-ins; the case returns to court May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and instructed an undercover police officer posing as a hitman to break Vanya’s arms and legs, damage his kidneys to cause bleeding, and finish him. Police filmed the exchange during a sting operation in Shatura, Russia; Simonova was arrested after handing over money, charged with attempted murder, and faces 15 years in prison. Vanya, who ended the affair for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped she would receive a harsh sentence.

José Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea manager, states he prays daily to God but never discusses football with Him or his wife. A father of two, he has worked with the World Food Programme against hunger and emphasizes separating professional and personal life. He attends church only when needed, regularly in Portugal, and prays solely for personal matters. Despite his competitive persona, he claims to be a good person and family-oriented, admitting professional mistakes. Chelsea are top of the league, he was fined £25,000 for claiming a 'campaign' against the team after Cesc Fabregas' booking, and his son celebrated the Capital One Cup victory.

Bob Barker returned to host "The Price Is Right" on April 1 for the first time in eight years, hosting the "Lucky Seven" game before handing over to Drew Carey. The 91-year-old former 35-year host, despite his absence, didn't miss a beat.

Arthur Baldwin, an off-duty Secret Service agent, was arrested in Southeast Washington, D.C., on Friday morning for attempted burglary and destruction of property. Charged with felonies, his security clearance was revoked and he was placed on leave. Baldwin works in the State Department's Foreign Missions Branch. Arraigned Friday with no attorney listed, his arrest follows a supervisor's misconduct leave two days prior, under police and Homeland Security Inspector General investigation. These incidents, including a March 4 incident where officials drove into a secure White House area after drinking, are recent setbacks for the Secret Service.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, captured images of a hungry lion from just 10 feet away at a safari park. He exited his car, lay on the ground, and took photos until the camera's shutter alerted the lion, prompting it to charge. He narrowly escaped into his car, later describing it as a close encounter he would not repeat.

NYPD released a tattoo image to identify an unidentified woman who died in Brooklyn nearly a month ago. The woman, aged 25-45, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend and pronounced dead that evening. She had no identification but a distinctive heart tattoo with "Monique" on a ribbon topped with a rose. Police await the medical examiner's report and ask for tips via Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 due to affordability issues. The $25,000 project took 18 months, featuring wood and steel construction, solar electricity, wood-fired heating, gas hot water, spring water, and nearly self-sufficient living in Nelson surrounded by nature.

Researchers found children sharing iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher in early literacy tests than those using individual devices or no iPads, contradicting skepticism from the National Association of Head Teachers' general secretary. Courtney Blackwell's study of 352 students attributed the improvement to collaborative learning around technology, advising schools to reconsider tablet usage in early grades for effectiveness; findings to be presented at an international conference.

A piglet born without hind legs has become an internet sensation by walking on its front trotters, as shown in a People's Daily video. Belonging to Ms. Duan in Sichuan's Qionglai City, it's nicknamed 'Super Pig' and draws villagers. China has also seen similar cases, such as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo walking on front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana in Avondale on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was struck by Francesco Dracone's car as Dracone spun while exiting the pit box on lap 25, injuring his leg. Phillips received stitches and was released. Many cars faced traction issues due to prior rain. Dracone, a 19-year-old Italian, did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

Horrific CCTV footage showed Milton Vieira Severiano (32) murdering his wife Cicera Alves de Sena (29), a dancer in Jaula das Gostozuedas known as Amanda Bueno, by slamming her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her five times in the face due to jealousy over men looking at her. They had been married four days. A neighbor heard him accuse her of being a slut before gunshots were heard. After the murder, Severiano stole a car, crashed it, and was arrested with four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest found in his vehicle. He faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her near-suicide attempt due to anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and isolation. She emphasized the link between depression and anxiety, calling anxiety the "new depression," citing Beyond Blue's report that one in three Australian women experience anxiety, and provided contact details for Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) and Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault for striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom in November 2014 while seven months pregnant. Prosecutors dropped the charges, stating she was "completely justified" under Oregon law allowing force against an intruder refusing to leave. Her defense cited the ex's harassment, theft, and efforts to relapse the boyfriend. A conviction would have resulted in nearly six years in prison. Curtin gave birth in January, the boyfriend is not involved in their child's life, and she is now living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, reacted with disgust to broccoli added to her treats by her owner, chewing and spitting it out. The passage notes she may not be a good example for the two children she lives with regarding eating vegetables, and mentions her other activities include sleeping and bonding with her family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its website directed users to a pornographic page. The link led to the discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was taken over by a porn site after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the registration expired. HSBC removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, apologized for the inconvenience, and confirmed its website remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 during a Sunday morning fire at his Clinton home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah on the second floor. He provided calm instructions to the dispatcher, soothed his sister, and guided firefighters to their location. Prince George's County firefighters rescued them by breaking a window, with Lt. Kenny Ward handing Marcus out and giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae illuminated Australia's east coast, captured in Jervis Bay, NSW. Photograher Andy Hutchinson described the neon glow as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar event occurred at Manly Beach in August 2014. UNSW's Iain Suthers explained the glow is from Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, typically due to natural causes, and glows as a defense mechanism when preying on diatoms.

New tests like endopredict analyze genetic markers in breast tumors to assess recurrence risk, potentially sparing patients chemotherapy. Some women with a 5% recurrence risk find chemo offers no significant benefit over monitoring. Currently, most patients receive routine chemo post-surgery despite severe side effects like hair loss and fatigue. While the tests are privately available for £2,500, experts advocate NHS adoption for cost savings and informed decisions. A patient example shows avoiding chemo based on low-risk results, as chemotherapy's risks may outweigh benefits when recurrence probability is already low.

More than 25 Royal Navy personnel were airlifted due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. The MoD confirmed a 'no touching' rule, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first female warship captain, was repatriated following sexual relationship allegations. Additionally, 99 female soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq under strict pregnancy bans in war zones, with evacuations on medical flights and no mandatory pregnancy tests.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on Japan's Prime Minister's residence rooftop, raising terrorism concerns. The discovery occurred the same day a court approved restarting two Sendai nuclear reactors. Authorities confirmed the cesium levels were not immediately harmful but warned of potential future drone-based terrorism during events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Current Japanese law restricts drones near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's to work daily on his motorbike, securing them with a sash. After his father's death, with his wife working elsewhere and son in school, he ensures her safety as she previously wandered off when alone. The four-kilometer commute takes an hour, and his employer provided her a room at work. He states, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple," expressing his duty to care for her as she cared for him.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, the first to track drinking patterns at the county level, found heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% from 2005-2012, driven largely by women. CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men; binge drinking as four or more for women and five or more for men in a single occasion. Women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times those of men nationwide. In 2012, 8% were heavy drinkers and 18% binge drinkers, though overall alcohol consumption rates remained stable. County data showed Madison County, Idaho, with the lowest binge rate (6%) and Menominee, Wisconsin, the highest (36%); Hancock County, Tennessee, had the fewest heavy drinkers (2%), Esmeralda County, Nevada, the most (22%). Alcohol-related deaths totaled 88,600 in 2010, costing over $220 billion annually. Contributing factors included changing social norms, affordability (alcohol cheaper in real terms), increased advertising ($3.45B in 2011), weakened alcohol policies, and affluent professionals in tech hubs.

UN officials warn doctors are overusing caesarean sections, risking women's and babies' health. England's rate exceeds 25% (more than doubled since the 1990s), while WHO recommends 10-15%. The procedure can cause infections, complications, death, and costs £2,369 versus £1,665 for natural birth. WHO contradicts NHS guidelines permitting C-sections without medical justification, such as for tokophobia, with 1 in 10 C-sections causing infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested for breaking into a Martha's Vineyard home, living there for a week, and selling the owners' items in a yard sale. Charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her on April 17; she claimed ownership and fled in a gray Nissan pickup. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket. She was arrested later attempting to re-enter. Missing items include deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. Police urge recipients to return items, stating they may be victims eligible for restitution.

Police reunited Bella Crooke's lost iPhone by posting humorous messages and photos on her Facebook using the unlocked device. After the phone was handed to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border, officers shared selfies, a photo in a holding cell, and jokes like "put a password on your phone," battery-related puns, and "great cell phone." Bella, who lost it at a birthday party, reclaimed it without providing her name as officers recognized her from Facebook. She thanked them and added a password.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa, after being grabbed by a sub-adult hippo during a fight between adult males. The mother, staying with her herd for safety, watched helplessly as the calf was thrown into the air and dragged through the water, dying hours later despite her attempts to intervene, according to tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A three-bedroom Knightsbridge apartment listed at £575,000 with only three years remaining on its lease, requiring renovation. The price is significantly lower than neighboring properties, but extending the lease for 90 years would cost £3.35–4.5 million, after which the property could be worth up to £6 million. Experts note the rarity of such short leases in the area and caution that the low initial price masks high extension costs, with current rental rates comparable to market rates for similar properties.

Starbucks resolved a computer outage affecting 8,000 US and Canadian stores due to a system refresh failure, causing free drink giveaways and some store closures. The outage also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores, occurring just one day after the company reported record $4.6 billion quarterly earnings and a 4.4% stock increase.

Terrorists are training in rural West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, to radicalise Muslims, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These individuals participate in ordinary community activities with ulterior motives. Historical incidents include 1998 training in Brecon Beacons by Abu Hamza's group, 2005 7/7 bombers photographed white water rafting in Bala, 2010 arrests of Cardiff-based Al-Qaeda plotters, Michael Adebowale's Arabic studies at a European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder (set up by Iraqi clerics), and secret meetings by Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah in a Welsh country park. Jones emphasized terrorism isn't confined to cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence.

Omura's whale, a species feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting in WA and second in Australia. A 5.68m juvenile female was confirmed via DNA after initial identification difficulties. The environment minister noted its significance, as the species was only described in 2003 and is restricted to tropical/subtropical waters, typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. It has a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits per pectoral fin. The carcass was buried, with the skeleton to be recovered later for scientific study and possible museum display.

The passage addresses claims that women's hormones disqualify them from presidential leadership, citing Cheryl Rios' argument against Hillary Clinton, countered by evidence showing female leaders take fewer risks and male leaders have hormone-related issues (e.g., cheating politicians). It highlights pervasive workplace gender bias, such as corporate boards dominated by men with common names and biased student evaluations, and notes benefits of gender equality for businesses, families, and society. It also corrects a claim about Canada’s first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, noting prior inaccuracies regarding her election.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning his extensive antique collection for £100,000 to downsize, featuring over 200 items including a 1960s Battle of Agincourt diorama, Victorian furniture by Gillows, a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, portraits, 17th-century books, swords, rifles, and chandeliers. Known for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small*, Churchill portrayals, and *Harry Potter* films, he studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien, authored books on the longbow, and consulted on the Mary Rose recovery. He expressed sadness at parting with his collection but trusts the auctioneers and will continue television work despite retiring from stage acting.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, found dead at their Winter Garden home after a well-being check. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son, prompting police involvement. Shemansky, on parole for battery on law enforcement and with a history of bipolar disorder and involuntary psychiatric commitment, was reportedly stressed by divorce proceedings and received bad paperwork Friday. Neighbors indicated his mother prevented him from the visit to avoid court issues. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed the cause of death. He fled on foot without provisions or medication, and his estranged wife is preparing to protect herself. Tips can be directed to 407-656-3636.

Eugene, USA, was awarded the 2021 IAAF World Championships without a bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. The city had previously lost its bid for the 2019 event to Doha but convinced the IAAF through a recent presentation. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted collaboration between public authorities, private sector, NOC, NBC, and public enthusiasm. The 2007 championships in Osaka were also awarded without bidding, and Mo Farah won the men's 10,000m gold at the 2013 championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death via a honey trap to steal his winnings. She befriended Hassan at a casino, leading him to his Islington flat where accomplices Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler tied him up, kicked him to death, and stole cash. Jackson and Chandler received life sentences for murder. The judge condemned the attack as "pitiless and wicked," stating it defied reason and compassion. Hassan kept large sums of cash in his flat, including in his microwave, making him vulnerable to exploitation.

Cesc Fabregas has struggled in the second half of the season, with his form declining significantly after a strong start around Christmas. Barcelona noted a recurring post-Christmas slump in his stats, where his contributions diminish as seasons progress. His Premier League assists dropped from 15 by mid-January to just one in five games, jeopardizing his pursuit of Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists. Despite Chelsea's potential title win, his recent poor performances, including a 2-0 loss to Holland where he was rated poorly, raise durability concerns. With nine games remaining, his resurgence is critical for Chelsea to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are close to signing Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old who impressed during a two-week trial and has offers from Belgian clubs, while season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Premier League for the 2016-17 season.

Police have closed an investigation into the assault on huntsman Mike Lane three months after the incident despite evidence including video and a dossier with suspect details. Lane suffered severe injuries, including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Authorities cited insufficient evidence to identify or prosecute suspects, prompting criticism from Lane and supporters. The case remains undetected but may reopen with new evidence. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid prosecutions.

Adam Gadahn, al-Qaeda's American mouthpiece, was killed in a January U.S. counterterrorism operation. The White House stated neither he nor Ahmed Farouq (killed in a separate operation) was specifically targeted; U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto died in Farouq's strike. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995, joined al-Qaeda in 1998, and became its chief English-language propagandist. Indicted for treason in 2006, he appeared in videos threatening attacks, criticized U.S. presidents, and urged lone-wolf shootings. A 2011 letter from him on media strategy was found in Bin Laden's compound. He was married with at least one child.

Chinese parents' passion for raising child prodigies is exemplified by five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, whose viral basketball video showcases skills surpassing professionals, including dribbling two balls and scoring hoops since age two and a half. Netizens reacted with disbelief, curiosity about his father, and self-comparison shame, while Yao Ming remains China's previous top basketball star.

Tom O'Carroll, a former Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) activist who campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s-80s, has joined Hacked Off. PIE allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to push for lowering the age of consent to ten and legalising incest; O'Carroll was part of NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. Jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," he attended a Hacked Off rally chaired by John Cleese to lobby for statutory press regulation per the Leveson Inquiry, causing embarrassment to the group.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia's Ten Pieces presentation. The unisex capsule collection by founders Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss featured ten monochrome pieces designed to be worn in 20 ways. Models walked through the empty pool and break wall against an ocean backdrop on a 28°C day, with guests and beachgoers observing.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent his Friday alongside some fellow natural born fighters during a family trip to a Northern California safari park, posing with and feeding a white tiger and interacting with giraffes and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. He announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30 at welterweight, ending speculation about facing Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, or Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager's name was removed from an Israeli memorial at Mount Herzl after family and Almagor organization objections. Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, was killed by three Israelis in July. His father stated he was not consulted and refused his name being listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor called his death a "rogue attack" not a terror victim, demanding removal. Israel's National Insurance Institute complied, deleting his name from the memorial wall and website. A trial against the three suspects began in January.

California-based YouTuber Lionel Hutz filmed his young son repeatedly using the family cat as a pillow in the garden. After the cat licked its fur and the boy sat on it, the cat moved to another spot. The boy followed and repeated the action once more before the cat wandered off indoors. A later video showed them reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial involving six officers charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing, lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying that police stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. The school was unaware of his past as he passed a background check in 2010, with 2007 charges expunged. Kushner had subsequent arrests in 2011 (probation) and 2008 (DUI), but claims innocence of the 2011 charges and describes his past as a "bad phase" he's moved past. Defense attorneys argue the government's case relies on "19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop."

Six people were injured in an explosion at a reportedly carcinogenic paraxylene (PX) plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, caused by an oil leak. Five were hospitalized for glass injuries, with no toxic chemical spill reported. Over 600 firefighters contained the fire. The plant, originally planned for Xiamen but relocated to Zhangzhou in 2007 due to pollution protests, had a previous explosion in 2013 with no casualties. PX plants have sparked protests in China despite demonstrations being illegal.

Jack Grealish refuses to adjust his sock-wearing style despite referee requests, maintaining a superstition of wearing socks low over children's shinpads. He made his first Premier League start in Aston Villa's 3-3 draw against QPR, describing it as a tough relegation battle game but expressing gratitude for the manager's faith and hope for more starts.

Bobbi Kristina Brown's grandmother reported she has global irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, with doctors indicating she may live in this condition indefinitely. A source confirmed her neurological state unchanged for three months, with no response to visitors or voices, eyes not following movement, and a tracheostomy. However, family members, including her father and attorney, stated her condition improved, with her out of ICU, opening eyes, and beginning rehabilitation, though long-term outcomes remain uncertain.

Russia leads 2-0 in the Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, and Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova had 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved critical. Russia needs one more win to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents face warnings of further floods and damage as an east coast low system, similar to last week's but positioned further from the coast, is predicted to impact the region from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) has 4,409 outstanding jobs out of 24,196 requests and is concerned additional storms will impede cleanup, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter Region. Meteorologists indicate heavy rain will affect northern NSW and southeast Queensland more than Sydney, with rainfall peaking midweek. The Bureau of Meteorology states severity remains uncertain, but catchments already flooded last week are at risk. The SES is deploying over 1,000 personnel, including 200 from other states, to address tasks before the next storm arrives.

Nina Moric, a model featured in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" video, denied attempting suicide, stating she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure and a domestic accident involving a fall and head injury. Italian media reported she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother, with her boyfriend quoted as confirming the attempt, though Moric said he was in Naples at the time. She posted bruising photos on Instagram, refuting suicide claims and confirming recovery. The passage also notes Italian media's claim of a 2009 suicide attempt and her marriage to jailed paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, convicted of blackmailing celebrities and recorded admitting to ruining lives.

A YouGov poll for The Sunday Times shows Diana as the top choice for a royal baby girl (12%), followed by Alice (9%, Queen's aunt) and Charlotte (9%, nod to Charles). For boys, James (13%) and Alexander are preferred. A quarter of respondents hope for a girl (sister to Prince George), only 3% a brother. Social media supports naming after Diana, and 68% back William’s six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bombing in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killed 17 people and wounded 64, including a provincial MP, during a protest en route to a rally against the governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no group has claimed the attack. The incident occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old spent seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed negotiations are over after he refused a three-year extension contingent on playing 60% of matches, criticizing Barcelona for delaying renewal talks until April.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan from Southampton and scoring three goals in six games, urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join Boca Juniors, stating they have a South American style suited to the club and would be beloved by fans at La Bombonera. Pirlo is a top midfielder, and Totti, a Roma legend, would be equally popular in Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, sustained only a nose cut after a viral double somersault fall from favorite Merrion Square in a Wincanton race. Despite the incident, he resumed mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls' yard with no special treatment, joked about pursuing gymnastics, and gained Twitter followers while remaining undeterred.

James Haskell, London Wasps captain, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron. After starting with Wasps in 2002 and playing eight seasons, he moved to Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since then, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 England caps.

Wide leg trousers are a key SS15 trend, offering an alternative to skinny jeans. Styles include denim, cropped, printed, and striped. Stylists recommend pairing with high heels for elongation, simple tops for proportion, and high-waisted longer lengths. Gucci and Topshop’s Miller jean feature denim versions, while Celine and Stella McCartney offer dressier options. Finery London provides affordable alternatives. Poppy Delevingne wore them at the AW15 Chloe show, and the trend suits spring regardless of weather.

University of Michigan reversed its cancellation of 'American Sniper' screening after backlash and a counter-petition, stating the initial cancellation conflicted with freedom of expression. Students objected due to the film's portrayal of the Iraq War and Middle East. The screening will proceed with 'Paddington' offered as an alternative, and the decision was praised by coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists aged 18 and 24 set a quokka on fire using aerosol and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. They were evicted, charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas, cat-sized, inhabit islands like Rottnest and Bald.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at 1930s-40s New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar alongside Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen footage of herself due to lost photos and memorabilia. Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled "soundies" (early music videos) for her, which she viewed at her nursing home, delighting her with the remark "it's just fabulous."

A study by OSV reveals declining self-car washing in Britain, with 31% of men and 75% of women never washing their own cars. Only 12% of men who wash do so regularly, and 5% asked children for pocket money. Factors include Sunday shop openings, live football, rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes. During Easter, 15 million cars were self-washed, though 25% did it as an excuse to leave home. Weekly washing is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, least in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners wash most often; Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes least. An OSV spokesperson cited time constraints, bigger cars, and affordable alternatives as reasons for the tradition's decline.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's impact since joining Liverpool in 2008, stating he remains one of the best players in the world and is synonymous with the club. He believes Liverpool can replace Gerrard with existing players if given proper support. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with a potential final on May 30 before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel, signed by Rafael Benitez seven years ago, credited Gerrard for helping him settle and become a defensive mainstay. Both players could return for the Villa match after serving three-match bans from a March incident against Manchester United.
