Jack Nicklaus, 75, scored a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during Augusta National's Par-3 Contest, his first at Augusta. Playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, he celebrated with the crowd. Camilo Villegas recorded two aces but lost to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Five hole-in-ones tied the 2002 record. Nicklaus, youngest Masters winner in 1963 and six-time champion (1986), is one of five to complete the career grand slam; Rory McIlroy could achieve it with three consecutive major wins.

Kansas experienced tornado sirens Wednesday night as storms brought multiple twister reports, including a tornado 6 miles northwest of Goddard (17 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast, missing the city but threatening other areas. CNN's Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. Southwestern Kansas had three tornado sightings near Aetna (125 miles southwest of Wichita). Missouri's Potosi (70 miles from St. Louis) reported wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage, while Farmington experienced baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation, claiming the shooting was accidental. The judge allowed him to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as showing apathy. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates' lawyers released training documents to confirm his qualifications, while the Harris family's lawyer alleged he received preferential treatment due to donations and ties to the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denied allegations of forged records reported by the Tulsa World, and two deputies involved were reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for his July 11 featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo in Las Vegas, where Aldo is defending his belt for the eighth time. He revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach with the caption "if you see the tiger, it's too late. you're food," following a previous gorilla tattoo. McGregor claims Aldo lacks motivation, stating he doesn't want the belt in his presence. During a March promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it before 5,000 fans, highlighting their fractious relationship.

Tony Abbott faced criticism after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with anti-drinking campaigners accusing him of glorifying binge drinking and linking masculinity to alcohol consumption. Professor Julie Robert stated it was problematic for the Prime Minister to showcase masculinity this way, promoting a culture focused on speed and quantity over socializing. The incident, where he downed a schooner in six seconds amid cheers, elicited mixed responses, including opposition leader Bill Shorten's joke and Health Minister Sussan Ley's defense. Critics stressed the need for Abbott to set an example that heavy drinking isn't required to be a "true blue Aussie bloke," highlighting changing attitudes toward binge drinking despite past instances by leaders like Bob Hawke.

Indiana's Scott County has seen 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary HIV cases, up from 106 last week, linked to intravenous drug use of Opana. Governor Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, providing 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collecting 1,400 used ones. Health officials expect more cases, and the program's extension beyond April 25 is under review. A legislative bill to expand exchanges to other counties passed the House but faces federal funding restrictions since 1989, with debates over whether needle exchanges are harm-reduction or promote drug use.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend take a test on the club, scoring 87% (43.5/50). The exam included multiple-choice questions, tables, and written sections with instructions like "read every question twice" and "calculators may be used." She made errors in player positions (e.g., misidentifying Ozil and Welbeck’s roles) and gave humorous answers, such as claiming Alexis Sanchez was better than Eden Hazard for being "buff" and Chilean. Her boyfriend corrected mistakes in capitals and drew angry faces but stated he wouldn’t dump her. Twitter reactions were mixed: some praised him as a "legend" and her as "proper GF material," while others criticized the test as excessive, with one calling him a "biff-head."

Carlos Toro, 66, worked 27 years as a DEA informant under a promise of US citizenship but now faces deportation. He aided in prosecuting Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. The DEA refused assistance after he publicized his plight, leaving him undocumented with an expired visa, unable to collect social security, and fearing death if returned to Colombia. A former colleague provided $5,000 after DEA declined help, and his handler criticized government bureaucracy, stating Toro has "done his debt" and deserves to remain in the US.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men, suffering 70% burns and requiring hospitalization; her family reportedly told her to stay quiet, and the accused were arrested. This follows heightened sensitivity in India over sexual assault, including the banned documentary *India's Daughter* about the 2012 gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, which sparked nationwide protests. Recent mob violence includes the killing of a man accused of raping and murdering an 11-year-old in Nagaland (Ibo Cha) and Syed Sarif Khan, accused but not convicted of raping a 19-year-old, who was beaten to death by a mob, with the Nagaland government later stating his innocence.

Louis van Gaal ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw for Manchester United's derby against Manchester City due to fitness concerns. He stated that a victory would secure third place, surpassing pre-season goals and ensuring Champions League qualification, with City coming off a recent defeat. Van Gaal downplayed revenge motives from a previous 1-0 loss, emphasizing the need to control aggression, and praised the fans' support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans left seats empty for the first 10 minutes at Emirates Stadium to protest rising ticket prices following the Premier League's £5.14bn TV deal. Tickets started at £64, with banners stating "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing". Organizers called prices "extortionate", stating football has "sold its soul" and fans face late fixtures, unreasonable kick-off times, and restrictive treatment. They demand price reductions aligned with working-class earnings, warning of losing a generation of supporters without action, with further protests planned.

A newborn named Star, diagnosed with biliary atresia after persistent jaundice, required a liver transplant following an unsuccessful Kasai procedure. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but her mother’s twin sister, Shanell, donated part of her liver. The November surgery led to Star’s recovery, with ongoing weekly tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Biliary atresia affects approximately 1 in 16,000 births and can be fatal if untreated.

Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake defeated Loic Remy and Willian in the first two challenges of Audi's football challenge, including a close-range boot shot round (5-3) and a tennis court game using a £127,000 Audi R8 as the net. Remy and Willian won the final long-range shooting round, during which Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off an Audi but avoided repair costs. Willian later drove one of the cars involved.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a December 2013 highway crash killing Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant), her fiancé Jason Timmons (29), and their unborn child. During sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal, contradicting prosecutors who stated he told investigators he intended to kill himself. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus’s death, facing 12–24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. His defense cited Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug effects, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis, while prosecutors alleged he argued with his wife over medications and intentionally crashed.

Lacey Spears was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt via his feeding tube, receiving a 20-year-to-life sentence. Prosecutors stated she fabricated his medical conditions (including Crohn's and celiac disease) for attention, causing repeated hospitalizations and unnecessary procedures. Her social media posts about his illnesses were used as evidence. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, wishing she would die in prison and criticizing her lack of emotion during sentencing. The judge acknowledged her mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty," while her defense plans to appeal, blaming hospital negligence.

Australia's influenza vaccine is delayed by a month to include protection against H3N2 and B/Phuket strains after a spike in deaths in Europe and the US due to the previous vaccine's ineffectiveness. High-risk groups (young, elderly, Indigenous Australians) can access free shots from April 20. Experts urge all individuals to get vaccinated to protect vulnerable contacts, noting the new vaccine matches global strains and will be used in the next Northern Hemisphere winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending against a National Geographic critique describing it as "all the historical character of an office lobby" and historian Adam Goodheart's criticism of its "incongruous art deco style," amid commemorations of the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. Illinois' financial crisis and Governor Rauner's proposal to eliminate the state historic preservation agency managing the site have led to budget cuts reducing hours and staffing. The agency cites over $2.5 million in recent renovations, including lighting upgrades and waterproofing, while supporters and visitors dispute the critique's accuracy.

The passage details the resurgence of 1990s and 2000s fashion trends, including JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers, with examples of past and current celebrity usage.

New York saw four rainbows photographed by Amanda Curtis; China cracked down on exotic dancers at wakes; RDJ became agitated during a UK interview; Kardashians' lip-plumping trend via jar-sucking (#KylieJennerChallenge); 102-year-old Alice Barker's time-travel project; school rejected bomb-themed prom-posal with racism accusations; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp unrecognizable in 'Black Mass' trailer; pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'; military dad's original photobomb.

Serena Williams and Andy Murray received celebratory cakes at the Miami Open, dubbed "national cake week," following their respective 700th and 500th career victories. Williams defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3) to reach the semi-finals, avenging her 2013 Wimbledon loss, while Murray's cake marked his 500th win. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep beat Sloane Stephens, with Venus Williams' loss to Carla Suarez Navarro preventing a potential sister matchup.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and owner of Karachi's T2F cafe, was shot dead by two gunmen after closing her establishment. She had recently hosted a discussion on Balochistan's issues, which authorities had shut down at Lahore University, prompting her to move it to T2F despite prior death threats. Her mother was injured but expected to recover. Mahmud was a prominent advocate for free speech, human rights, and tolerance, becoming a symbol of progressive values in Pakistan. No group claimed responsibility, and police have not identified a motive. Social media mourned her loss, highlighting her role in fostering open dialogue and secular wisdom.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee from Punjab (now Pakistan), has lived in Indian Kashmir for 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote. Around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), mostly in Jammu and never having visited Pakistan, face similar denial of rights due to fears of disrupting the Muslim-majority state's demographic balance. A pre-independence law grants citizenship only to those born in the old undivided Kashmir, excluding WPRs though allowing 35,000 Hindus from Pakistan-administered Kashmir citizenship. With the BJP's recent power share in Kashmir, hope exists for change as they pledged to normalize WPR status. Generations live in poverty, barred from state jobs and education, with activists demanding state-subject rights and warning of protests if ignored.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after they made a £4 million offer, with plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto seeks a club where he can play regularly and develop. Former manager Ranko Popovic praised his intelligence, confidence, speed, strength, and educational background. Chelsea's Jose Mourinho acknowledged commercial interests (including a £200m Yokohama Rubber sponsorship) in transfers but emphasized signing only quality players, declining to comment directly on Muto.

Australia has abandoned its policy of excluding overseas-based players, setting a precedent for England to follow. The passage argues England's coach Stuart Lancaster must select the best players regardless of club location, citing examples like Matt Giteau, Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson, who improved while playing in France. It compares rugby to football, where the FA selects players from clubs like Bayern Munich or Barcelona, and stresses the World Cup requires the world’s best talent. Toulon’s inclusion of international stars like Bryan Habana (South Africa) and Leigh Halfpenny (Wales) further highlights the outdated nature of England’s current policy, which risks their performance as hosts and undermines the tournament’s integrity.

FireChat enables off-grid messaging via wireless mesh networks using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework and Android Bluetooth, with devices relaying messages up to ~30 feet (total ~200 feet). Open Garden's Greenstone, an egg-shaped beacon, extends the network beyond this limit, currently operating at 20 feet with a one-year battery and storage for 1,000 messages. It's designed for crowded or low-connectivity areas like festivals and airports, and is under development pending manufacturer partnerships.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle advocates for "fat" as a neutral self-descriptor, not synonymous with "ugly," in her TED Talk. She cites rising workplace size discrimination (66% over 30 years) and girls' top wish to be thinner, but notes studies show exposure to body diversity increases acceptance. Her burlesque performances normalize larger bodies, with her TED Talk garnering 38,000 views and positive feedback, including stories of changed perceptions, leading her to state "we are winning" in body positivity.

Theo Walcott, frequently benched this season, participated in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer. Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013, featured the group in an official portrait. Arsenal's first team will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott has been a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games, last started on March 14, and aims to feature in the upcoming match against Hull.

An auction of props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker will take place on May 29 at Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and PropStore.com. The 417-item collection, valued at approximately $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions such as *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, and *Planet of the Apes*. Notable pieces include the Alien Edgar Bug ($40,000), Mikey costume ($30,000), Worm Guy from *Men in Black II* ($10,000), Grinch costume ($8,000), and Two-Face mask ($1,500). The no-reserve auction features items spanning Baker's 30-year career.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died in the French Alps after falling 164ft while skiing with his family. Separated from his mother during their last run, he entered dense woodland towards the resort, and his body was found via footprints. His family described him as a "daring, outgoing and determined" youngster with a "handsome smile lit up any room," leaving a "vast void in their hearts."

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to societal pressure to be a "size zero," hiding food and consuming as little as 100 calories daily, often just one piece of fruit. Her condition led to collapse and hospitalization on a heart monitor. After recovery with medical support, she now competes in Miss Teen GB, which promotes positive body image. The NHS identifies anorexia as a serious mental health condition, with approximately 725,000 people in the UK affected by eating disorders, 10% of whom have anorexia.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit designed by New Balance under a £300 million four-year deal, replacing Warrior. Players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, and Simon Mignolet presented the kit at Anfield, where fans urged Sterling to stay despite his recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and Arsenal speculation, though the club insists he remains. The kit features a Hillsborough disaster tribute and the "hold nothing back" message. Players also focused on their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

University of Manchester researchers, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, produced the largest high-definition dark matter map covering 0.4% of the sky (150 times the moon's area), released at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore. Using Dark Energy Survey data from Chile's Victor M. Blanco telescope, the map reveals dark matter density via gravitational lensing (red for more, blue for less). Dark matter constitutes 85% of the universe's matter but is invisible, detectable only through gravitational effects. The survey aims to map 12.5% of the sky by 2018, with current data supporting theories that galaxies form in high dark matter density regions and aiding studies of dark energy's role in cosmic expansion.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, confirmed by PSV. Louis van Gaal, who included Depay in his 2014 World Cup squad, aims to sign him this summer. Tottenham's £15m bid last year was rejected, with PSV's Marcel Brands stating current offers from United, PSG, and another European club involve higher amounts. Depay scored 20 goals in 26 league games, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. His career began at VV Moordrecht (age six), moved to Sparta Rotterdam at nine, joined PSV at 12, and has made over 100 appearances. Described as pacy with good dribbling but occasional poor passes, he has been compared to Arjen Robben by Cocu and claimed by Ed van Steijn to surpass young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay scored in Holland's 3-20 win over Australia at the World Cup, netted against Chile, and was nominated for best young player (lost to Pogba).
Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth team 3-1 in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke adding a late third goal.

Marco Rubio stated people are born with their sexual preference but believes same-sex marriage should be decided by state legislatures, not courts, and that marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. He also said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreeing and announced his presidential campaign with over $51 million in donor commitments.

Spanish Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian Ilze Zebolde (31) quit Manchester restaurant jobs to cycle the world with no agenda. In 356 days, they've covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on under €3 per person daily using camping, Couchsurfing, and free food sources like foraged items and dumpster diving. After traveling through Europe and into Armenia, they plan to cycle across Asia and the Americas, crossing the Pacific.

A Texas couple from a 2012 wedding alleges their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed racial slurs, including "poor n***** party," on photo booth snapshots. They discovered the issue months later when the bride's sister informed them to avoid spoiling the wedding day. Attorney Cathy Hale represents them in a lawsuit under Texas deceptive trade practices for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, claiming no evidence links his company to the slur and that the couple showed no mental anguish. The couple seeks only an apology, not monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if unresolved.

Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recover from a concussion, unsure of his return after withdrawing from Harlequins' match. George North has been advised not to play this season after four concussions and will see a neurosurgeon, while Johnny Sexton was sidelined for 12 weeks. Brown, who suffered a concussion against Italy in February and withdrew from the Ireland game, credits World Rugby's online modules for raising awareness of symptoms and dangers, stating it's crucial not to risk further injury like Sexton or Geoff Parling. He is part of Land Rover's 'We Deal in Real' campaign promoting grassroots rugby.

British heterosexual couples' monthly sex frequency has declined from five times in 1990 to four in 2000 and three currently, attributed to smartphone and internet use blurring work-life boundaries, increasing busyness, and reducing sex priority due to constant connectivity like email checks, according to Cambridge University's Professor David Spiegelhalter and researcher Catherine Mercer.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued up to £1.2 million each as status symbols, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat in hotpots and leather due to China's anti-corruption crackdown (reducing gift-giving) and city bans on dogs over 50kg. Rescued dogs were found in poor condition, with some dead, while gangs steal them and breeders offload inferior stock. Cross-breeding for profit degraded quality, causing a surplus. Urbanization has also made them unsuitable for city living.

A survey of 600 Paris-area women found all experienced sexual harassment on public transport, including some unaware due to conditioned acceptance of low-level abuse. Half were assaulted before age 18, with harassment ranging from verbal abuse to sexual assault. This led to 60% of women fearing attacks (vs 30% of men), altered daily routines, and exclusion from public spaces. The report to the French women's rights ministry called for a campaign addressing sexist behavior, emphasizing legal penalties like five-year prison terms and €75,005 fines for sexual assault, and education for victims, aggressors, and witnesses.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition, based on a survey of 2,000 people identifying common emergencies like sleep issues (46%), lost keys (37%), and being stuck in traffic (35%), shortlisted three prototypes: Snooze (alarm silencing phone notifications), Forget Me Lock (key device indicating door status via color), and Nipper (smallest mobile charger using household batteries). Public voting via Twitter with #everydayfix will determine the winner for Kickstarter funding.

Vera Baird, Northumbria's Police and Crime Commissioner, allocated over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs, while Chief Constable Sue Sim also serves as a director. The Ministry of Justice is investigating potential conflict of interest after criticism that the allocation is inappropriate. Critics, including Keith Vaz, argue PCCs should not use public money for charities they're involved with and that the Home Secretary should not have granted such powers. Baird defended the decision, stating procedures were followed, while Sim is retiring in June after prior bullying allegations investigated by Baird. The charity was established after Victim Support's client numbers declined, though sources cite reluctance to engage due to Sim's misconduct proceedings.

Three people were sentenced to prison and two others await sentencing or trial for torturing Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive symbols. Corey Campbell, the ringleader of the 'tattoo terrorists', believed Valecce harmed his cat and stole money. The assault occurred in a Philadelphia basement over 42 hours in March-April 2014. Campbell and Carl Halin received 20-year sentences; Sandra Ng was sentenced to 23 months. David Thomas awaits sentencing, Jennifer Pratt awaits trial. Valecce suffered severe injuries and ongoing psychological trauma.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal seeking to make him a key summer signing after their collaboration during the 2014 World Cup. PSV confirmed interest from United and Paris Saint-Germain, with bids exceeding Tottenham's rejected £15m offer last year. Depay scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Scouts and coaches have compared his potential to Arjen Robben and suggested he could surpass a young Cristiano Ronaldo.
Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth team 3-1 at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had equalized for City.

Marco Rubio stated people are born with a sexual preference but believes state legislatures, not courts, should decide same-sex marriage laws, maintaining marriage is between one man and one woman. He said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreement and, as a Catholic, considers divorce wrong but would still love divorced individuals. He announced his presidential run, with donors committing over $47 million for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian), who met in Riga in 2011, quit their Manchester restaurant jobs to cycle the world with no plans or agenda. In 356 days, they’ve covered nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries. Living under €3 daily each (€0.10/km), they rely on free camping (161 nights), Couchsurfing (66 nights), Warmshowers (44 nights), and occasional meals from strangers. Food costs €2.74/day from pasta, bread, seasonal produce, foraging, and dumpster diving. Starting in London, they traveled through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, planning to continue into Asia and the Americas for years.

Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recover from a concussion setback, unsure of his return after withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens. George North has been advised not to play again this season following four concussions, while Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks. Brown cited headaches after the France game and highlighted awareness from World Rugby modules, leading him to withdraw from the Ireland match. He emphasized avoiding long-term absences and urged teammates to prioritize health over playing. Brown is part of Land Rover's "We Deal in Real" campaign for the Rugby World Cup 2028.

A leading expert suggests smartphone use contributes to declining monthly sex frequency among couples, with current averages at three times per month compared to four in 2000 and five in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this to blurred work-life boundaries and constant email checking due to technological connectivity, reducing intimacy time. Catherine Mercer notes competing demands make sex a lower priority, with work emails hindering focus on partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized as luxury status symbols priced up to £1.2 million each, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather due to China's anti-corruption crackdown (which ended their use as gifts to officials), city bans on dogs over 50 kg, urbanization making them unsuitable for city living, and poor breeding practices leading to a surplus of low-quality dogs. Rescuers found 20 dogs in cramped, inhumane conditions en route to a slaughterhouse, with many dead or injured, and fears hundreds face similar fates. The breed's market collapse follows a boom starting in 2005, where they were celebrated for loyalty and size (up to 80 kg), but now face neglect and cruelty.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition surveyed 2,000 people, identifying inability to sleep (46%) as the top emergency. Three shortlisted prototypes include "Snooze" (alarm clock silencing phone notifications), "Forget Me Lock" (key device indicating door lock status via color), and "Nipper" (smallest phone charger using household batteries). The winning product, selected via Twitter retweets with #everydayfix by April 40, will be funded through Kickstarter.
The 2009 convention featured over 512 guests and musical performers, including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
